headline: Topping Off the Biggest Gas Tank
abstract: U.S. taxpayers have invested about $20 billion to stock the U.S. Strategic Petroleum Reserve, which is about to be filled to the brim for the first time.

headline: Balance Sheet : The limits of expertise
Research in Motion, Maker of the BlackBerry, Says Sales More Than Double
abstract: Research in Motion Ltd says profit for third quarter rose to $90.4 million; sales rose to $365.9 million from $153.9 million (M)

headline: Gadget of the week: Connectivity on a key ring
S.E.C. Makes Its Point on Small Errors, and Auditor Pays $10 Million
abstract: Securities and Exchange Commission reaches settlement with accounting firm KPMG over its audits of Gemstar-TV Guide International; KPMG agrees to pay $10 million to shareholders of company, whose share price has plunged since it restated its financial results in 2002; SEC bars KPMG accountants Brian E Palbaum, John Wong, Kenneth B Janeski and David A Hori from auditing public companies (M)

headline: For Hobbyists, (Almost) Blank Canvas
abstract: Michelle Slatalla Online Shopper column finds paint-by-numbers kits online; drawing (M)

headline: Doubts Emerge Over Colombian Disarmament
abstract: Colombian officials celebrate disarmament of 1,400 right-wing paramilitary fighters in Catatumbo region, but rights groups and some lawmakers warn that effort to demobilize groups is moving too fast, with no verification of results and no assurance it can bring lasting peace; map (M)i

headline: New Round of Cuts at SBC Will Eliminate 10,000 Jobs
abstract: SBC Communications will eliminate 10,000 jobs by end of next year, roughly 6.1 percent of its work force, through attrition and layoffs; they come on top of 7,000 jobs SBC plans to cut this year as well (S)

headline: World Business Briefing | Europe: Ireland: Possible Bid For Porcelain Concern
abstract: Waterford Wedgwood might bid for Royal Doulton, British producer of procelain and china figurines; graph (S)

headline: Marsh to Create Restitution Fund Using Incentive Fee Proceeds
abstract: Marsh & McLennan, which has been accused of bid-rigging and price-fixing, plans to set up restitution fund of up to $230 million to be used in any settlement accords; says money will come from uncollected incentive fees owed it by insurance companies under longstanding accords it suspended Oct 15; New York Atty Gen Eliot Spitzer's office says move was made by Marsh on its own (M)

headline: More Air Force Deals With Boeing Are Questioned
abstract: Favoritism that Darleen A Druyun showed toward Boeing Co when she was No. 2 weapons buyer for Air Force, whose full extent was not revealed until her sentencing on Oct 1, is scandal that grows day by day; is subject of potential lawsuits by Lockheed Martin, a Boeing rival, almost certain Congressional hearings, expanded federal investigations, possible reopening of many of Boeing's contracts and additional scrutiny of Pentagon's procurement process and people who oversee it; there are political ramifications as well, with Justice Department investigating three top Bush administration officials: Air Force Sec James G Roche, Marvin Sambur, Air Force acquisition chief, and Robin Cleveland, associate director of Office of Management and Budget; photo; table shows deals on which Druyun favored Boeing (M)

headline: High oil prices weigh on U.K. economy
Lego CEO resigns after profit warning
World Business Briefing | Europe: Italy: Airline Rescue Advances
abstract: Italy and unions at Alitalia, government-controlled airline, agree on unemployment package for 3,700 workers to be laid off as part of reorganization plan (S)

headline: Despite Pact, New Violence Stymies Aid in Sudan
abstract: Fresh surge of violence is engulfing Darfur just two weeks after Sudanese authorities and their guerrilla enemies signed preliminary peace agreement, with rebels sharply ratcheting up attacks, government offering heavy-handed retaliation and large patches of land becoming closed to relief efforts; 1,000 African Union troops in Darfur are authorized to do little more than monitor cease-fire violations; map; photos (M)

headline: Arafat's Feud With Israel May Outlive Him
abstract: Yasir Arafat has feuded with Israel throughout his adult life, and it appears quarrel will continue with his death; Arafat has expressed wish to be buried in East Jerusalem, place that Palestinians hope to make capital of future state; Israel, which claims all of Jerusalem as its capital, is adamant that Arafat will not be laid to rest in city (M)

headline: Letter from America : Democrats, at last, trying to get religion
The Kid Stays in His Home, Dressed in PJ's, With a Live Mike
abstract: Robert Evans, fabled Hollywood producer, will anchor a weekly program for Sirius radio subscribers, which will be broadcast from his home; photo (S)

headline: Time Is on My Side (but in a Goth Way)
abstract: Vestal Watches has created line o√Ñ

headline: CONTINENTAL PROJECTS LOSSES THROUGH 2005
abstract: Continental Airlines posts third-quarter loss of $16 million compared with profit of $133 million year ago; chief executive Gordon Bethune says airline might be forced to ask for worker concessions (S)

headline: Citigroup Sues Italy Over Parmalat Case
abstract: Citigroup sues Italy, claiming Enrico Bondi, government appointee who runs bankrupt Parmalat, will unfairly pay only 2 million euros of Citigroup's claim of 538 million euro debt; judge in Parma has until Nov 18 to rule on Bondi's recommendations on debt claims suit comes about three months after Parmalat sued Citigroup to recover damages roughly estimated at $10 billion; Parmalat contends Citigroup knowingly helped create complex transactions that misled shareholders and cost them billions of dollars; photo (M)

headline: World Briefing | Africa: South Africa: Thatcher's Son Protests
abstract: Mark Thatcher, 51, the son of the former British prime minister Margaret Thatcher, appeared in a Cape Town court to contest South Africa's decision to allow prosecutors from Equatorial Guinea to question him about an alleged plot to overthrow that nation's government. South African prosecutors accuse Mr. Thatcher, 51, of helping finance the coup plot, which collapsed in March; his lawyers told the court that Mr. Thatcher was innocent and that allowing Equatorial Guinea officials to question him could prejudice his trial. Mr. Thatcher's hearing on the issue, the first court proceeding ever to be broadcast in South Africa, is expected to end today.   Michael Wines (NYT)

headline: German banks clean up as bad debt becomes good business
CHIEF OF HALLIBURTON'S OIL FIELD SERVICES UNIT IS LEAVING
abstract: Halliburton Co says John Gibson is leaving his position as chief executive of company's oil field services unit; Andrew Lane, chief executive of company's Kellogg Brown & Root unit, is promoted to chief operating officer (S)

headline: World Briefing | Middle East: Iran: Ex-President Says Missiles Have Range Of 1,250 Miles
abstract: Iran has improved the range of its missiles to 1,250 miles, the IRNA news agency reported, quoting Hashemi Rafsanjani, the former president and one of the country's most influential figures. Last month, Iran said it had tested a new version of its Shahab-3 missile but did not release any information about its range. The old version had a range of 800 miles. ''Experts know that a country that possesses this can obtain all subsequent stages in missile production,'' Mr. Rafsanjani reportedly said in a speech to staff members at the Aerospace Research Institute in Tehran.   Nazila Fathi (NYT)

headline: Camcorders Finally Find Hard Drives
abstract: David Pogue State of the Art column on tape-free camcorders from JVC; devices store video recordings on hard drive, but lack some qualities of video tape camcorders; photo; drawing (M)

headline: Japan's Export Growth Rises 13.4%
abstract: Japanese export growth accelerated to 13.4 percent in November, led by autos and steel, easing concern that overseas demand for goods is faltering.     Export growth from a year earlier exceeded October's revised 11.7 percent gain, the Ministry of Finance said yesterday. On higher oil prices, imports rose 28 percent to a record, reducing the trade surplus to 602 billion yen ($5.77 billion) from 1.16 trillion yen.

headline: Venture funds bloom in Japan
Tiny Collective of Jews Agrees to Leave Gaza Under Plan
abstract: Residents of small Jewish settlement in southwest corner of Gaza Strip are first to agree to leave under Israeli government's Gaza withdrawal plan; settlement consists of just 20 farming families, but its collective decision is significant because Jewish settlers in Gaza, more than 8,000 in 21 settlements, have sought to present united front against Prime Min Ariel Sharon's plan to uproot them; photo (M)

headline: MARSHALL & ILSLEY BUYS TRANSACTION PROCESSOR
abstract: Marshall & Ilsley Corp, biggest bank in Wisconsin, will buy VECTORsgi from Thoma Cressey Equity Partners for $100 million to add check-clearing and bill-paying services (S)

headline: Technology Briefing | Software: Game Maker Purses S.E.C. Settlement
abstract: Take-Two Interactive Software says Securities and Exchange Commission staff will recommend settlement to end probe of company's accounting; reports earnings of $62.6 million in quarter ended Oct 31, up from $26.3 million year earlier; sales rose 58 percent, to $438 million; graph (S)

headline: World Business Briefing | Europe: Germany: BASF Plans Job Cuts
abstract: BASF, in cost-cutting move, plans to cut about 10 percent of work force in Ludwigshafen, Ger, to about 32,000, over next three years (S)

headline: LUCENT GETS FINAL APPROVAL FOR BIG TAX REFUND
abstract: Lucent Technologies says that Congressional joint tax committee had given final approval to its refund agreement with Internal Revenue Service; under agreement, Lucent would get $861 million, which includes $45 million of interest, because of how it reported loss in 2001; refund will be booked in fourth quarter, which ended on Sept 30; company says that refund raises its fourth-quarter income to $1.21 billion, or 23 cents a share, from previously reported $348 million, or 7 cents a share (S)

headline: BRIEFLY:MANILA:
'Unbridled Spirit' Wins Kentucky Slogan Vote
abstract: Kentucky selects new brand image for state's promotional campaigns as part of efforts that began in spring with help of ad agencies New West and Fitzgerald & Co; new slogan will be 'Kentucky: Unbridled Spirit'; Kentucky is seeking to unify multiple campaigns for government departments (S)

headline: World Business Briefing | Asia: South Korea: Bank Executive Nominated
abstract: World Business Briefing: South Korea: Bank Executive N¬ê

headline: Ethnic Clashes Are Confirmed by Beijing; Toll Is Unclear
abstract: New China News Agency offers first official bulletin on unrest in Henan Province; says riots there resulted in 7 deaths and 42 injuries and were quelled after authorities imposed martial law; does not describe reasons for riots; local residents blame sustained clashes between Hui Muslims and Han Chinese (M)

headline: 3 major U.S. airlines report losses
As Nuclear Secrets Emerge in Khan Inquiry, More Are Suspected
abstract: When experts from the United States and the International Atomic Energy Agency came upon blueprints for a 10-kiloton atomic bomb in the files of the Libyan weapons program earlier this year, they found themselves caught between gravity and pettiness.     The discovery gave the experts a new appreciation of the audacity of the rogue nuclear network led by A.Q. Khan, a chief architect of Pakistan's bomb. Intelligence officials had watched Dr. Khan for years and suspected that he was trafficking in machinery for enriching uranium to make fuel for warheads. But the detailed design represented a new level of danger, particularly since the Libyans said he had thrown it in as a deal-sweetener when he sold them $100 million in nuclear gear.

headline: King Tut Treasures Will Return to U.S., but Won't Stop at the Met
abstract: Treasures of legendary Egyptian boy king Tutankhamen will tour US for first time since 1979, but will bypass Metropolitan Museum of Art because director Philippe de Montebello was not able to persuade trustees to permit separate charge; Egyptian official Zahi Hawass says Egypt needs to raise money for crumbling antiquities (M)

headline: Wary of Regulators' Scrutiny, Reinsurer Ends Berkshire Deal
abstract: Platinum Underwriters Holdings, responding to heightened scrutiny of once-common insurance industry practice, says it is scrapping insurance contract it had bought from Berkshire Hathaway because of deal might not meet regulatory standards; transaction unwound by Platinum is type of insurance known broadly as finite or financial reinsurance, which is intended to limit companies' exposure to unknown liabilities (M)

headline: Jury Convicts 5 Involved in Enron Deal With Merrill
abstract: First criminal trial stemming from financial dealings at Enron Corp ends when federal jury in Houston finds five defendants, including four former executives of Merrill Lynch, conspired to help Enron report bogus profits; convicted defendants are Daniel Bayly, former head of global investment banking at Merrill, and James A Brown, former head of firm's project and lease group; former Merrill executives convicted include Robert S Furst, banker in Houston office responsible for managing Enron relationship, and William Fuhs, banker who did some work on alleged bogus sale of interest in barges by Enron to Merrill; Dan Boyle, former executive in Enron's finance division, is also convicted; accountant Sheila Kahanek is acquitted (M)

headline: Even at Charity Used to Aiding, It's a Scramble
abstract: Even seasoned executives of Catholic Relief Services, which has responded to natural disasters around world for last 61 years, find misfortune in southern Asia almost overwhelming; Catholic Relief is one of America's largest aid organizations, with staff of 4,400 in nearly 100 countries; because devastation from earthquake and tsunami is spread across 3,000 miles, agency is sending teams of emergency relief managers simultaneously to multiple countries, on remote islands, in war zones and on unfamiliar turf; it is kicking off ambitious fund-raising campaign because it committed to spending $25 million in private funds, even though so far it has collected only $5 million in donations; photos (M)

headline: How economies, and societies, might adjust to their evolving populations : As the world comes of (older) age
Have Homes, Will Travel
abstract: John B McCoy, who retired as head of Bank One in 1999 at age 56, says his semiretirement includes living in different homes for each season and playing golf; photo (S)

headline: Neighbors Urge Iraq to Keep Working for Stability
abstract: But there was no firm agreement at the two-day gathering on whether elections scheduled for January could proceed.

headline: Technology Briefing | Internet: More Music Swapping Lawsuits
abstract: Technology Briefing: More Music Swapping Lawsuits

headline: Fort Worth Emerges From the Shadows
abstract: Decision by Pier 1 Imports and RadioShack to build headquarters in downtown Fort Worth, Tex, ignites stronger interest for offices there; office buildings are filling up; over past four years, occupancy has grown almost 10 percentage points, to about 91 percent; boom is linked partly to March 2000 tornado that tore through heart of downtown, wiping out several buildings and forcing companies to rebuild, relocate or shut down; photo (M)

headline: Maker of OxyContin Reaches Settlement With West Virginia
abstract: Purdue Pharma reaches agreement with regulators in West Virginia over claims that it inappropriately marketed OxyContin, its controversial painkiller, to state residents; agreement, which averts a trial, involves $10 million sum paid over four-year period to drug abuse and education programs in state (S)

headline: Independence Air Makes Bid to Rejoin United
abstract: Six months after Independence Air stopped flying as a regional carrier for United Airlines and began flying on its own, it is seeking to return to the company it left.    Independence, struggling with heavy losses, disappointing ticket sales and high fuel prices, has submitted a bid to resume flying United Express routes, a person close to the situation said yesterday. News of Independence's bid was reported in USA Today yesterday. Officials at United and Independence said they had no comment.

headline: World Business Briefing | Americas: Brazil: Venture Plans Steel Mill
abstract: Companhia Vale do Rio Doce and ThyssenKrupp Stahl sign agreement to build steel slab plant in state of Rio de Janeiro, Brazil, with initial production capacity of 4.4 million tons a year (S)

headline: THE END USER A voice for the consumer : New bulbs brighten Net
Yushchenko Steps Out Presidentially; Rival Grumbles
abstract: Viktor A Yushchenko, Ukraine's presumptive president-elect, begins to draw up shape and early priorities of his government, even as his opponent in election Prime Min Viktor F Yanukovich continues to refuse to acknowledge his defeat; Yanukovich's prospects of having election results overturned seem remote; Yushchenko says he has commissioned working group to make recommendations for ministers who would succeed those of Pres Leonid D Kuchma, who is stepping down after 10 years in office; says he is creating new government body, Ministry of European Integration, which would include cabinet-level post; says he would replace all 10 regional governors in easteren Ukraine wwo had threatened last month to form autonomous region; expresses willingness to prosecute Kuchma, who has been accused of election-rigging, corruption and abuse of state power; photo (M)

headline: Digital Bread Crumbs for Your Photos
abstract: Interest in geocoding digital photos, attaching Global Positioning System coordinates to digital cameras, is growing; relating pictures to precise locations has obvious applications for mapmakers, but interest is growing in other applications as well; photos (M)

headline: Bertelli's smart, impossible style : Prada chief takes the long view
Musharraf Says He'll Continue as Army Chief
abstract: Pres Pervez Musharraf announces in nationwide television address that he would continue as Pakistan's army chief despite his pledge last year to give up post by end of 2004; says any change in internal or external policies can be 'extrememly dangerous' for country; holds democracy will continue unhampered; critics say his decision would further polarize already fractious political environment and would mean further weakening of democratic and civilian institutions (M)

headline: Directors of Fannie Mae to Discuss Executives' Fates
abstract: Fannie Mae board reportedly will meet to consider fate of chairman and chief executive Franklin Raines and chief financial officer J Timothy Howard, who signed off on financial statements that violate accounting rules governing treatment of derivatives and prepaid loans; photo (M)

headline: 2 Shipbuilders Get Big Breaks in New Corporate Tax Bill
abstract: Little-noticed provision in sweeping corporate tax bill that passed Congress last week will reduce taxes at military shipbuilding contractors General Dynamics and Northrop Grumman by nearly $500 million over next 10 years; provision would allow shipbuilders to postpone their taxes for years on profits from building ships and submarines for Navy; measure's primary sponsor is Sen Olympia J Snowe of Maine, who said she was determined to protect Bath Iron Works, one of her state's largest employers; photo (M)

headline: Kayak Is New Vehicle For Searching the Web
abstract: Kayak.com becomes latest Web search site to enter travel business; such sites display prices available for flights, hotel rooms or car rentals and refer customers to other sites to buy tickets or make reservations; drawing (M)

headline: Disobedient British Fathers Act to Reclaim Children
abstract: Fathers 4 Justice, organization of fathers committed to gaining equal child custody rights for men, is gaining supporters in Great Britain, where it was founded by Matthew O'Connor; non-violent, attention-grabbing stunts, which include wearing super-hero costumes, have brought cause to attention of general public and politicians; membership has grown from 200 to 12,000 in two years and is becoming global movement, soon to open offices in United States; group is critical of current proposed family court reforms and strives to gain presumptive 50-50 custody arrangement and policies that mandate mediation to solve disptues; photos (M)

headline: Arroyo vows aid on journalist cases
Balance Sheet: Derivative ambiguity
F.T.C. APPROVES MERGER OF MOLSON AND COORS
abstract: Molson, the Canadian beer maker, and the Adolph Coors Company yesterday won antitrust clearance in the United States for their proposed $3.4 billion merger. The combination appeared on a list of completed merger investigations published by the Federal Trade Commission. The merger proposal still needs the approval of Molson and Coors shareholders. Molson, based in Montreal, and Coors, of Golden, Colo., said in July that the combination would create the world's fifth-largest brewer. The merger would require approval of two-thirds of the Class A shares, and some investors have said that they will sue to prevent options holders from having the same voting rights as Class A shares.

headline: Tyco to Sell Ex-Chief's Apartment for $21 Million
abstract: James G Dinan, founder and senior managing director of York Capital Management, buys Fifth Avenue cooperative apartment of former Tyco International chief executive L Dennis Kozlowski from Tyco for $21 million; Dinan will get many of furnishings inside, but not infamous $6,000 shower curtain and several other items that were used in Kozlowski's fraud trial; Kozlowski and Tyco's former chief financial officer Mark H Swartz are expected to be retried early next year after first trial ended in mistrial; Tyco spokesman David Polk comments; photo (M)

headline: EXECUTIVE TURNOVER AT SUNTRUST BANKS
abstract: SunTrust Banks Inc, which restated results in November as result of accounting mistakes, names James Wells president and chief operating officer and chooses chief credit officer and controller; chief risk officer Theodore Hoepner and vice chairman John Clay will retire (S)

headline: Lawmakers in Cambodia Vote to Try Khmer Rouge
abstract: Cambodian Parliament's lower house finally ratifies agreement with United Nations to create international tribunal to try surviving leaders of Communist Khmer Rouge for atrocities during their four-year rule in late 1970's; no timetable is set for trial and some technical and political issues lie ahead, including need to raise estimated $57 million from international donors; none of aging Khmer Rouge leaders have been brought into court; during their reign, as many as one-fourth of Cambodian population died from execution, starvation, overwork and disease; seven major figures are main focus of possible proceedings, but only two are in custody; Khmer Rouge leader Pol Pot died in 1998 (M)

headline: Constellation Makes $970 Million Offer for Mondavi
abstract: Constellation Brands Inc makes unsolicited $970 million offer for Robert Mondavi Corp; Mondavi will consider proposal; photo (M)

headline: You'll Laugh. You'll Cry. ButThis Merger May Not Be a Hit.
abstract: Assessment of Blockbuster's $700 million unsolicited offer for its biggest rival, Hollywood Entertainment; there is some skepticism about Blockbuster chairman John F Antioco's rationale for merger; Blockbuster's worldwide rental revenue fell 6.3 percent in third quarter; combined entity will have access to even bigger shrinking audience that increasingly favors Netflix, online rental company, and on-demand services from cable, satellite and Internet; photo (M)

headline: G.M. Plans 10,000 Temporary Layoffs
abstract: General Motors will temporarily lay off more than 10,000 workers for one to four weeks early next year at five plants that mostly produce sport utility vehicles and pickup trucks; move is further sign that sales of largest SUV's are under pressure amid unusually high gas prices (M)

headline: COMPANY BRIEFS
abstract: General Electric Co., Fairfield, Conn., which makes aircraft engines, said it would buy the Aircraft Parts Corp., Holtsville, N.Y. Terms were not disclosed.    U.S. Bancorp, Minneapolis, a regional bank, said it would increase its quarterly dividend by 25 percent and would authorize the repurchase of 150 million shares in the open market.    Peninsular & Oriental Steam Navigation Co., a British ports operator, said it had sold 14 buildings in Boston for $97 million to Berkley Investments, Boston, a real estate investment company, and to an unnamed private investor in Germany.    Tarragon Corp., New York, a home builder and real estate investment company, said it would buy four apartment and town house complexes in Florida for about $190 million.

headline: Tension Grows Between Arafat's Wife and Political Heirs
abstract: Palestinian leaders cancel trip to France after Suha, wife of ailing leader Yasir Arafat who, according to French law, has control over information regarding husband's condition, accuses them of burying Arafat alive; Palestinian leaders are stymied by lack of concrete information about Arafat's condition; coalition hoping to visit with Arafat consists of Mahmoud Abbas, secretary general of Palestine Liberation Organization and second in command, Palestinian Authority Prime Min Ahmed Qurei, Foreign Min Nabil Shaath and Parliament Speaker Rawhi Fattouh; some officials question motive of Suha, who has not seen husband in over three years; couple's relationship discussed; photo (M)

headline: Offices With Space, Sex Appeal and Great Acoustics
abstract: Real estate services firm Newmark says media and entertainment companies accounted for 8 percent of all commercial real estate deals that were closed during first three quarters of year, compared with 7 percent in 2003 and 3 percent in 2000; some specific projects in Manhattan and Brooklyn discussed (M)

headline: The Ad Store Hires A Managing Partner
abstract: Ad Store in New York makes first significant management change since it opened in 1993 by hiring Tim Arnold as a managing partner (S)

headline: Women leave traditional Bolivian dress in closet
Tiptoeing Leftward: Uruguayan Victor's Moment of Truth
abstract: Analysis of election results in Uruguay; says despite fact that left has finally gained power there after 33-year struggle, Tabare Vazquez and his party are more likely to tinker around edges of country's problems than carry out profound social transformation they have been promising; photo (M)

headline: SPOTLIGHT: The non-conformist who made good
Technology Briefing | Internet: Consumer Groups Complain About Site
abstract: Representatives of six national consumer groups have written to Federal Trade Commission to complain that Web site introduced Dec 1 to give people free copies of their credit reports is deliberately difficult to find and use; groups, which include Electronic Privacy Information Center and US Public Interest Research Group, say credit agencies Equifax, Experian and TransUnion that set up site have blocked Web links from reputable consumer sites such as Privacy Rights Clearinghouse and Consumers Union from mainstream news Web sites; groups also tell FTC that site's language prevents people from finding it through standard search engines (S)

headline: Trouble Comes in All Sizes and Is Available Everywhere
abstract: Viking River Cruises president Jeff Dash, in Frequent Flier column, on some of his airline travel experiences; photo (M)

headline: World Business Briefing | Americas: Brazil: Bank To Offer Services In Japan
abstract: Banco Bradesco of Brazil signs deal with UFJ holdings of Japan to offer financial services in Portuguese to Brazilian immigrants in Japan (S)

headline: China Detains 3 Leading Critics
abstract: The detentions were the latest in a string of arrests and official harassment of journalists, writers and scholars.

headline: Sharon Strikes Deal With Opposition Labor Party
abstract: The deal is likely to insure the prime minister can carry out his plan to dismantle Israeli settlements in Gaza.

headline: World Business Briefing | Americas: Canada: Jobless Rate Rises
abstract: Canadian jobless rate reportedly rises to five-month high of 7.3 percent in November from 7.1 percent in October; economy loses 25,300 full-time jobs as factories lay off workers for fourth consecutive month (S)

headline: Egyptian Leader Urges Palestinians to Work With Israel for Peace
abstract: Pres Hosni Mubarak of Egypt makes remarkably conciliatory remarks toward Israel, advising Palestinians to work with Prime Min Ariel Sharon as their best hope to achieve peace and also urging them to curb violence that has marked struggle to end occupation; he criticizes decision of Marwan Barghouti, jailed Palestinian leader, to declare his candidacy for president of Palestinian Authority; Mubarak's comments seen as attempt to help Sharon during his domestic crisis because Egypt wants Israel to complete its withdrawal from Gaza Strip (M)

headline: World Briefing | Europe: Russia: Apology Demanded For Latvian Insult
abstract: The chairman of Parliament's international affairs committee said he may refuse to attend a regional forum of North European and Baltic Sea legislators next month because of insulting comments about Russia made by his Latvian counterpart, who is scheduled to be there, according to Itar-Tass. The Russian, Konstantin Kosachyov, said he would attend the meeting only on condition of a public apology by Aleksandr Kirsteins, who said on Latvian television this week that ''there are only two ways to develop relations with Russia -- either to hit it in the face or to lick its boots.'' Mr. Kosachyov said the statement ''goes beyond any permissible insult of our country.''   Sophia Kishkovsky (NYT)

headline: That Line at the Ferrari Dealer? It's Bonus Season on Wall Street
abstract: Wall Street's traditional year-end bonuses are up significantly for second consecutive year; Goldman Sachs, Lehman Brothers and Bear Stearns have reported record profits for year and all are said to have given out handsome bonuses; investment bankers are expected to see gains in bonuses of 10 to 15 percent, amid year-end flurry of mergers; fixed-income traders will also be amply rewarded, but their percentage gains may be smaller than those of bankers; bonuses vary by bank, by division and by individual; they reflect firm's profitability and group's performance, as well as individual's contribution; this year's bonuses are rich enough to persuade many of Wall Street's elite to rediscover conspicuous consumption; but many Wall Street professionals urge caution, given that bonus typically constitutes majority of their compensation; say they are all too aware that good times could end as quickly as they did after 2000, when $2.5 million income could turn to $800,000 overnight; photo; graph (M)

headline: MARVEL, COMICS PUBLISHER, NAMES CHIEF EXECUTIVE
abstract: Marvel Enterprises' vice chairman Isaac Perlmutter will become chief executive in January (S)

headline: Texas Instruments Reviews for Agency
abstract: Texas Instruments begins review for agency to handle its worldwide account, which has been handled by TM Advertising (S)

headline: Temperatures Dip in Europe, Sending Price of Oil Up 4.8%
abstract: Price of crude oil surges 4.8 percent in New York on concern that cold weather in Europe will draw heating oil from United States (S)

headline: Sleepy Results for Financial Companies
abstract: Market Week column notes that financial-company results were drag on earnings performance in third quarter; graph (M)

headline: WHAT A CARD
abstract: Latest christmas card by venture capital firm Onset Ventures described; for years, firm's cards have been gauge of Silicon Valley's mood (S)

headline: 4 years after Milosevic, unity's gone in Belgrade
The Keystone Cops as Locksmiths - It's Show Time
abstract: Avista Inc software engineer E Aimee Concepcion, in Frequen

headline: 78 Arrested in Thai Protests Suffocate in Crowded Trucks
abstract: At least 78 people suffocate while being transported in overcrowded military trucks after violent demonstration in Thailand's largely Muslim south; six others were shot to death and about 20 wounded earlier when police fired live rounds into wild, rock-throwing crowds; photo; map; government is using strong-arm measures to quell rising anger and militancy in volatile region; protest was touched off by arrest of six men charged with selling weapons to Muslim fighters in Narathiwat Province (M)

headline: Flawed Device Places F.D.A. Under Scrutiny
abstract: Flawed defibrillator made by Access Cardiosystems and now recalled illustrates questions about FDA's oversight of critical medical devices; Access has ceased operating; founder Randall Fincke, who was forced out, accused company of shipping potentially defective units, prompting FDA inspection that uncovered no major defects and cleared company of serious problems even as complaints mounted; agency approves hundreds of such devices each year; only manufacturers and health care facilities, not individuals or emergency responders, are required to report problems; photo of Steve Bane, Wisconsin fire official with defective defibrillators; FDA official Dr Daniel G Schultz defends oversight while acknowledging problems with growing use of defibrillators in public places and homes (M)

headline: Treasury Bills Set for This Week
abstract: The Treasury's schedule of financing this week includes today's regular weekly auction of new three- and six-month bills and both an auction of four-week bills and a two-year note tomorrow.    At the close of the New York cash market on Friday, the rate on the outstanding three-month bill was 2.14 percent. The rate on the six-month issue was 2.35 percent, and the four-week issue's was 1.90 percent. In when-issued trading, the two-year note was offered at a price to yield 2.96 percent.

headline: S.E.C. Steps Up Inquiry on Krispy Kreme
abstract: Krispy Kreme Doughnuts says SEC has upgraded its inquiry of company's financial reporting practices into formal investigation; photo (M)

headline: Merck Offering Top Executives Rich Way Out
abstract: Merck, which has been reeling since it withdrew its arthritis treatment Vioxx from market Sept 30, adopts plan that could give its top executives big bonuses if company is taken over; says in federal securities filing that its board decided to give top 230 managers opportunity for one-time payment of up to three years of salary and bonus if another company buys Merck or over 20 percent of its shares; says any executive who is fired or resigns for good cause would receive payment; plan is seen as formal acknowledgment that Merck is now so weakened that it may be vulnerable to takeover; experts on corporate governance consider plan to be particularly ill timed; say board is rewarding executives for company's problems with Vioxx and its inability to bring new drugs to market; analysts say plan's probable cost of hundreds of millions of dollars would not discourage other drug companies from considering takeover; say most likely suiters are GlaxoSmithKline and Novartis; even though Merck's share prices declined 40 percent since Vioxx withdrawal, company has market value of $61 billion, figure that dwarfs potential payments to executives; photo (M)

headline: BRIEFLY:ASIA/PACIFIC:SEOUL : Strikers fail to close government services
SBC in Deal With Microsoft to Provide TV on High-Speed Lines
abstract: SBC Communications, as part of its efforts to compete head-on with the cable industry for television subscribers, plans to announce on Wednesday that it will pay $400 million to Microsoft for software used to deliver TV programming over high-speed data lines.

headline: Ford and G.M. Sales Slide Despite Generous Rebates
abstract: Ford Motor Co and General Motors, despite crop of new models and generous rebates, report decline in sales in November; both plan to cut production in first quarter 2005, troubling sign for job growth in Michigan and elsewhere; GM accelerates plan to stop production at plant in Linden, NJ, and lay off nearly 1,000 workers in early 2005; Ward's AutoInfoBank reports overall auto sales have been robust this year, but declined by 4.9 percent in November; graph; charts (M)

headline: Drive for Global Markets Strains Brazil's Infrastructure
abstract: Many economists and business leaders warn that economic recovery in Brazil could start losing steam as early as 2005 if government does not find ways to attract billions of dollars in investment to remedy Brazil's infrastructure; economy is expanding at its fastest clip since 1996 and is on course to grow more than 4 percent this year thanks to boom in exports; trucks carrying soybeans and grain have faced a wait of as much as 20 days to reach port of Paranagua in southern portion of country; similar bottlenecks and weak infrastructure can be found across country; photo (M)

headline: Technology Briefing | Telecommunications: Vodafone's Chief Expands Control
abstract: Vodafone Group says chief executive Arun Sarin will have more directors of its biggest markets reporting directly to him as company names Andrew Halford new finance director, succeeding Ken Hydon, who retires in July (S)

headline: Iran Gives Pledge on Uranium, but Europeans Are Cautious
abstract: Governments of France, Germany and Britain are studying letter delivered by Iran in which it pledges to suspend uranium enrichment activities temporarily in exchange for economic and political incentives; European officials say it is unclear whether Iran has agreed to all conditions set out in recent talks, or has inserted new and unacceptable conditions; in spite of cautious approach of three European governments, International Atomic Energy Agency is prepared to include Iran's new pledge in its comprehensive special report on Iran's nuclear activities; photo (M)

headline: Turkey Insists on Equal Terms in European Union
abstract: Prime Min Recep Tayyip Erdogan says Turkey will accept no affiliation with European Union short of full membership; rejects idea of conditional membership; says Turkey has rewritten its laws and amended its constitution to conform to requirements set by European Union; Turkey became candidate for full membership in 1999; Cyprus remains problem, although Greece has endorsed Turkish membership; union members will vote in December on whether Turkey may begin formal entrance talks; photo (M)

headline: Consumer Inflation in China Is Up, but the Pace Slowed

Moving Ideas Off Campus
abstract: Universities have enjoyed ownership of research breakthroughs that were developed on their campuses with help of federal financing and have been scrambling to turn them into commercial ventures since Congress passed Bayh-Dole technology-transfer law of 1980; transfer of technology from campus to capitalist marketplace has been financial windfall for many schools; revenue for all universities generated from their researchers' inventions has nearly doubled, to $1.3 billion in 2002 from $699 million five years ago; business plan developed by now former University of Arizona students Sara Conrad and Daniel Berger for device to detect shaken-baby syndrome invented by two professors at university's medical school discussed; photo (M)

headline: House Moves to Protect G.I.'s on Finances
abstract: On a broadly bipartisan vote, the House of Representatives approved a measure yesterday aimed at preventing marketing practices that have exposed military personnel, especially young recruits and junior officers, to high-pressure or misleading sales pitches for financial products that may not fit their financial needs.    The bill, which easily passed the House, would abolish an archaic form of mutual funds sold almost exclusively to military personnel. The funds, known as contractual plans, impose sales fees that eat up half of an investor's contributions in the first year.

headline: Thousands march, citing a climate of 'political repression' : Protesters accuse Manila of abuses
BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: Rough Days for Travelers, Possibly Glimpse at Future  A horrible weekend might finally be over for thousands of air travelers, but the worst may still be to come for the industry. The combination of a winter storm, labor unrest and computer glitches, which snarled airports from Philadelphia to Atlanta, may only be a prologue to what could be the most difficult year yet for an industry that since 2000 has lost $30 billion and eliminated over 100,000 jobs.

headline: World Business Briefing | Global Trade: Brazil: Central Bank Buys Dollars
abstract: Brazil's central bank, apparently responding to calls from government officials and business leaders to halt rally by Brazilian real that threatens to curb exports, buys dollars on foreign exchange market for first time since February (S)

headline: Europe's Frustration Grows as Dollar Hits Another Low
abstract: Europe's financial policy makers issue their strongest warnings yet about dangers of swooning dollar, and dollar promptly sinks to new low against euro; after falling to $1.339 in trading in New York on Dec 6, euro bounces back to $1.346--a record--on Dec 7; European Central Bank has been mum about possible intervention (M)

headline: Argentina's Economic Rally Defies Forecasts
abstract: When the Argentine economy collapsed in December 2001, doomsday predictions abounded. Unless it adopted orthodox economic policies and quickly cut a deal with its foreign creditors, hyperinflation would surely follow, the peso would become worthless, investment and foreign reserves would vanish and any prospect of growth would be strangled.    But three years after Argentina declared a record debt default of more than $100 billion, the largest in history, the apocalypse has not arrived. Instead, the economy has grown by 8 percent for two consecutive years, exports have zoomed, the currency is stable, investors are gradually returning and unemployment has eased from record highs -- all without a debt settlement or the standard measures required by the International Monetary Fund for its approval.

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: U.S. Trade Deficit Increased in 3rd Quarter  The broadest measure of the country's trade and investment flows showed a record deficit of $164.7 billion in the third quarter.

headline: Top Army Official Calls fora Halliburton Inquiry

headline: F.D.A. Releases Memo on Vioxx
abstract: Providing details from a report it had described broadly in August, the Food and Drug Administration published a memorandum yesterday that indicated Merck's Vioxx painkiller might have contributed to 27,785 heart attacks and deaths from 1999 through 2003.     The memo, based on a sample of patient records, concluded that people taking Vioxx were more likely to have heart attacks or die from sudden cardiac arrest than people taking a competing painkiller, Celebrex from Pfizer.

headline: World Briefing | Europe: Belgium: Politician Critical Of Radicals Threatened

headline: Terminating Spyware With Extreme Prejudice
abstract: THE end of the year is a time when people sit down, rethink their priorities and sometimes change their ways. Some quit smoking. Others join a gym. I chose to erase my hard drive and reinstall my operating system.     Sure, it was a drastic move, but my two-year-old I.B.M. ThinkPad -- equipped with a 1,000-megahertz Pentium III processor, a high-speed Internet connection and 256 megabytes of memory -- was running about as fast as the Apple IIE I used in the mid-80's.

abstract: Mutual Funds Report for third quarter of 2004; graphs summarize financial market results in stocks, bonds and commodities

headline: Drawing From Its Past Wars, Britain Takes a Tempered Approach to Iraqi Insurgency
abstract: They came with their regimental colors, embroidered flags recording battles in 18th-century India, in the Napoleonic wars, against Ottoman legions in Iraq in World War I, on the Normandy beaches, and in Malaya, Kenya and other colonial outposts after World War II.    For 8,900 British soldiers serving in Iraq, second largest among 31 foreign military contingents to the 140,000 American troops, the banners hanging at their bases are emblems of a collective memory -- of how to prevail in foreign wars, and, just as surely, British officers say sardonically, of how to lose them.

headline: Senate Investigators Interview Lawyer Who Has Sued Merck
abstract: Senate investigators examining Merck's recall of its Vioxx painkiller interview Andrew Birchfield, lawyer whose firm has filed 58 suits against company on behalf of people claiming injuries; Sen Charles E Grassley has been probing if Food and Drug Administration was slow to respond to concerns about drug; Merck shares fall on report of evidence that company knew about safety concerns much earlier than it acknowledged (M)

headline: World Business Briefing | Europe: Russia: Stake In Steel Maker Sold
abstract: Russia sold its stake in a steel maker, Magnitogorsky Metallurgichesky Kombinat, for $790.2 million to investors allied with management in the government's last auction in the industry. A venture of the United Financial Group, a Moscow brokerage firm, bought the 23.8 percent stake at the starting price. Four other prospective buyers showed up at the sale but did not bid. Another United Financial venture bought a 17 percent stake in the steel maker on Tuesday from Mechel Steel. The management group, which held a 32 percent stake in the company, will now have a majority stake.

headline: U.S. agrees to Iran deal proposed by its allies

headline: China's Bank, in Transition, Raises Rates
abstract: China's central bank raises official interest rate for first time in nine years, embracing free-market tool of economic management despite possible internal political repercussions; step is aimed at slowing breakneck economic growth and inflation, but it could lead to social unrest if heavily indebted state companies respond by laying off more workers; Beijing also removes ceiling on what banks could charge for loans, measure that paradoxically could make more loans available to risky private enterprises and ultimately enhance China's long-term growth prospect and give its economy much greater stability; two moves shift China further toward Western-style financial system in which markets determine allocation of credit, not government officials; interest rate increase, although only quarter of percentage point, is widely expected by economists to be first in series of increases that could lift rates by as much as two percentage points in coming year; photo; graph (M)

headline: Costs of Recall Hurt Merck's Results; Lilly's Profit Is Up

headline: Intifada's Legacy at Year 4: A Morass of Faded Hopes
abstract: The Palestinians refer to the Israeli victory over the Arab nations in 1948 as al nakba, or the catastrophe, when many of them became refugees. Some Palestinians, who thought they were on the brink of statehood four years ago, now say that the second intifada has been a second nakba.    ''We have suffered gravely since the eruption of the second intifada, far more than the Israelis have suffered,'' said Mkhaimar Abu Sada, a political scientist at Al Azhar University in Gaza.

World Business Briefing | Europe: Economic Forum Executive Quits
abstract: The World Economic Forum said its chief executive, Jos√© Mar√≠a Figueres, below, quit after admitting that he broke the organization's rules covering disclosure of outside interests. Mr. Figueres, who was president of Costa Rica from 1994 to 1998, failed to inform the forum that he received consulting fees of $906,355 from November 1999 to October 2003, the organization said.. A spokesman for the forum, which is the host of an annual meeting of business and government leaders in the Swiss Alps, said Mr. Figueres's resignation was not linked to bribery-related allegations made in Costa Rica.   Alan Cowell (NYT)

headline: Chirac Offers Cooperation and Criticism to U.S. and Britain
abstract: Conciliation was coupled with unrepentant criticism of the British-American war in Iraq and, more generally, of America's global posture.

headline: On-Demand Movies at 30,000 Feet
abstract: AS a general rule, I do not watch the movies they project on those cheap little overhead screens that drop down from the ceiling like broken shingles on domestic long-haul flights.     But I'd forgotten my reading glasses one day last week on a flight from Los Angeles to Newark. So there I sat, gaping like an idiot at a postage-stamp-size overhead screen that performed visual violence upon ''The Terminal,'' a Tom Hanks movie that, it seemed to me, had already been slapped around quite a bit by its screenwriters.

headline: Ukraine Vote for President in Virtual Tie; Runoff Is Due

abstract: Attendance is sparse at churches in Baghdad day before Christmas and all Christmas Eve services are canceled because of martial law curfew; photos (M)

headline: Pension Fund of New York Files Suit Against Merck
abstract: New York State Common Retirement Fund files lawsuit against Merck & Co, accusing it of misleading shareholders about safety of its arthritis pain drug Vioxx, which has since been withdrawn; suit says pension fund lost about $171 million in Sept 30, when company withdrew drug from market; New York State Comptroller Alan G Hevesi, who is also pension fund's trustee, says Merck knew but failed to disclose that growing evidence indicated that Vioxx users were at increased risk of heart attacks, strokes and death; suit also names several individuals, including Merck's chief executive Raymond V Gilmartin (M)

headline: Mortgage Indexes Decline
abstract: Mortgage Bankers Assn reports 5.8 percent decline in applications index, to 673.3, from 715 in previous week; reports 0.6 percent decline in home purchases, bringing index to 460.3 (S)

headline: World Business Briefing | Asia: Thailand: Consumer Confidence Down Again
abstract: University of Thai Chamber of

headline: Let big-caps bloom as small-caps and value stocks wilt : A year-end trim list
U.S. ELECTIONS / Wanting to get it right: Tight U.S. contest left Europeans dangling
Confidence stagnates at German companies
BRIGGS & STRATTON MAY BUY ASSETS OF MURRAY
abstract: Briggs & Stratton Corp may buy some assets of Murray, lawn mower maker that filed for bankruptcy protection in November; Briggs has not been paid for about $40 million worth of engines it sold to Murray last spring (S)

headline: Oops. You Told a Secret. What to Do Next?
abstract: Career Couch column answers questions about what to do after making inadvertent disclosure about your company to competitor; says telling employer about your lapse may ultimately save your job; drawing (M)

headline: Macedonia's Ethnic Peace Faces a Test in a Referendum
abstract: Macedonians will vote Sunday in a referendum that is likely to determine whether a three-year peace agreement to end ethnic violence will remain in place.

headline: Correction:For the record
Trouble in paradise
Justices to Hear Case on Sharing of Music Files
abstract: Supreme Court, responding to pleas from recording and film industries, agrees to hear case, Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer Studios vs Grokster Ltd, and decide whether online services that enable copyrighted songs and movies to be shared freely over Internet can be held liable for aiding copyright infringement; more than 85 million copyrighted songs and smaller but growing number of movies are downloaded from Internet every day by people using file-sharing services (M)

headline: Technology Briefing | Deals: Microcell Investors Accept Rogers Bid
abstract: Microcell Telecommunications shareholders approve takeover bid by Rogers Wireless Communications Inc; merger creates largest wireless company in Canada (S)

headline: Israel Feuds With Agency Set Up to Aid Palestinians
abstract: Israel and United Nations Relief and Works Agency have had running battle; Israel claims agency's Palestinian workers help Palestinian militants, and that militants have often gained access to UN ambulances, schools and other facilities; agency's director Peter Hansen says Israel has frequently raised false or inflated accusations against it and has consistently hampered aid efforts by imposing stringent travel restrictions against its personnel in West Bank and Gaza Strip; since 2001, Israel has arrested and indicted 17 of agency's workers, accusing them of assisting militants; seven have been convicted by military courts; in incident in Gaza City in May, four Palestinian gunmen climbed into UN ambulance after placing wounded comrade inside; incident was captured by television cameraman, and Israeli military contends Palestinians used ambulance to escape; photo (M)

headline: Leading Chinese TV Exporter Has Huge Loss
abstract: China's biggest television exporter Sichuan Changhong Electric Co announces major losses stemming in part from declining sales in US and unfolding financial scandal involving its biggest American customer Apex Digital Inc; Changhong says Apex Digital owes it $468 million; estimates it might be able to recover $150 million and says it is making provisions to take losses on $310 million; also says that Apex has suffered large losses to royalty payments, US antidumping measures 'and adverse business factors and is experiencing considerable hardship making full payments'; announcement of losses follows report in Chinese newspaper of detention in China of Apex Digital president David Ji on charges of financial fraud; photo (M)

headline: World Business Briefing | Asia: Japan: Retailer's Profit Falls
abstract: Japanese retailer Daiei reports 48.6 percent decline in net profit for first half of its fiscal year amid declining sales; Daiei's net profit sinks to 1.18 billion yen ($10.8 million) (S)

headline: Ukraine's Face Is Mirrored in a Candidate
abstract: Ukrainian opposition presidential candidate Viktor A Yushchenko uses his own disfigured face to underscore message that things are so fundamentally ugly in Ukraine that they must fundamentally change; contends cysts marring his once-handsome face are result of poisoning by political enemies; offers hope for modern civil society in place of Pres Leonid Kuchma's what Yushenko and his supporters see as shadowy, thuggish and corrupt government, but it is unclear if he can deliver; critics say that Yushchenko has no issues that unify his coalition aside from opposition to current government; photo (M)

headline: 169 Fox Stations Fined in Indecency Case
abstract: Federal Communications Commission will fine 169 Fox television stations $7,000 each, or total of $1.18 million, for violating indecency rules when it showed particularly grapic episode in April of show Married by America; Fox broadcasting network, which owns 25 of stations, issues statement suggesting that it will appeal action (M)

headline: Consumers Less Confident; Output Higher
abstract: Conference Board's confidence index dropped to 90.5 in November from 92.9 in October; Commerce Department reports gross domestic increased in third quarter at faster-than-expected 3.9 percent annual pace, up from 3.7 percent third-quarter pace initially estimated; National Association of Purchasing Management report shows business in Chicago area grew at slower pace in November, falling to 65.2 from 68.5; graph (M(

headline: 'Dysfunctional' economy is Yushchenko's first challenge
World Briefing | Europe: Turkey: Security Tightened At Patriarchate
abstract: Turkish officials vow to increase security around 400-year-old home of Greek Orthodox patriarchate in Istanbul after homemade bomb explodes in courtyard; complex is home of Bartholomew, who is worldwide spiritual leader of Orthodox Christians; Prime Min Recip Tayyip Erdogan's office condemns attack (S)

headline: Technology Briefing | Software: LeapFrog Predicts Lower Profit
abstract: LeapFrog Enterprises says 2004 will be less profitable than expected and custs its earnings forecast for year (S)

headline: Technology Briefing | Hardware: Chip Maker Plans Layoffs
abstract: LSI Logic Corp will cut 510 jobs, or about 11 percent of work force, after reporting wider third-quarter loss and falling sales; loss increased to $282.4 million from $31.7 million year earlier; sales declined 16 percent, to $380.2 million, from $450.2 million (S)

headline: G.M. vs. Toyota: This Time, the Hare May Win
abstract: GENERAL MOTORS is the world's largest carmaker, but it is not even close to being the most valuable. At current prices, you could buy all of the company's shares if you had a spare $22 billion; Toyota Motor, by contrast, which makes about 30 percent fewer vehicles, would set you back about $140 billion.    In a choice between Toyota and General Motors shares, many investors have bid up Toyota's sticker price out of faith in its ability to operate more efficiently and profitably than its American rival. Analysts say that this results from financial burdens facing G.M., as well as from better production methods and better cars that Toyota has developed over the years.

headline: Schwab Expected to Name Euro RSCG to Direct Overhaul
abstract: Charles Schwab & Co, seeking to reverse series of financial setbacks, turmoil in executive suit, branch closings and layoffs, reportedly will name New York office of Euro RSCB Worldwide, division of Havas, to handle brand and retail advertising; billings are estimated at more than $100 million; photo (M)

headline: Treasury Bills Set for This Week
abstract: The Treasury's schedule of financing this week included the regular weekly auction of new three- and six-month bills today and a four-week bill and a five-year Treasury-inflation pegged security, both tomorrow.    At the close of the New York cash market on Friday, the rate on the outstanding three-month bill was at 1.84 percent. The rate on the six-month issue was 2.05 percent, and the four-week issue was 1.62 percent.

headline: Administration Officials Split Over Stalled Military Tribunals
abstract: Myriad problems that have held up trials of terrorism suspects held at naval base at Guantanamo Bay, Cuba, before special military tribunals have ignited often fierce behind-the-scenes struggle that sets Pentagon and its allies in White House against adversaries at National Security Council, State Department and Justice Department; friction among officials like Defense Sec Donald H Rumsfeld, national security adviser, Condoleezza Rice, and Atty Gen John Ashcroft sheds new light on internal dynamics of administration that has shown remarkably united public front; photos (L)

headline: DELPHI ACQUIRES PEAK INDUSTRIES, A MEDICAL DEVICE MAKER
abstract: Delphi Corp acquires Peak Industries, maker of medical devices, for $44 million (S)

headline: Unauthorized Campaigns Used by Unauthorized Creators Become a Trend
abstract: NOT long after the chief executive at Coca-Cola, E. Neville Isdell, began saying that the company needed to improve its marketing, a group of experienced hands in the ad industry decided they might be able to help.    Soon a collective of creative types from many industries delivered their response, including a new campaign, brand promise and commercial for Coca-Cola using the theme, ''A Cool American.''

headline: Legal Affairs, a Magazine of Ideas, Severs Its Ties to Yale Law School
abstract: Staff of Legal Affairs, two-year-old magazine of law and ideas, sever magazine's ties to Yale Law School as of Jan/Feb issue; chairman Seth P Waxman and editor and president Lincoln Caplan comment; photo (M)

headline: Where Only the Antelope Roam
abstract: Cellphone service competition is heating up in nation's exurbs and rural markets, long dominated by smaller second-tier companies; these regional providers have had good business serving small companies with little competition while collecting fees from major carriers when their customers roam to rural areas; are now coming under intense pressure as saturation of urban markets forces national carriers to enter rural territories in search of subscribers; some of regional providers are United States Cellular, Dobson Communications, Leap Wireless International and Western Wireless; photo; charts (L)

headline: Stock Offering This Week
abstract: The following equity and convertible debt offering is expected this week:      Ninetowns Digital World Trade Holdings, 9.6 million shares. J.P. Morgan Securities; Citigroup Global Markets; Lehman Brothers.

headline: After 'The Incredibles,' Pixar Can Afford to Play Hard-to-Get
abstract: Pixar Animation Studios, whose joint venture with Walt Disney Co is set to expire in 2005, has yet to begin serious talks to determine its next distribution partner; chief executive Steven P Jobs cites outlook for shifts in top executives at studios; planned retirement of Michael D Eisner as Disney chief executive seen key factor; Jobs has always favored deal with Disney, but blamed Eisner for souring two companies' lucrative ties; photo (M)
