headline: Almost Here: Cellphones at 37,000 Feet
abstract: Joe Sharkey column notes kinks barring use of personal cellphones on airplanes are being worked out; cites decline in use of costly seat-back phones; discusses need for noise control; drawing (M)

headline: ROY DISNEY WILL NOT PROPOSE RIVAL BOARD CANDIDATES
abstract: Former Disney directors Roy Disney and Stanley Gold, following board's promise that successor for chief executive Michael Eisner would be found by June and that Eisner would step down when process is complete, say they will not propose alternate slate of candidates for board next year (S)

headline: Asian states see open source as window of opportunity
Technology Briefing | Telecommunications: Sprint To Enhance High-Speed Internet Access
abstract: Sprint Corp will spend up to $3 billion over next three years to enhance its network to provide high-speed Internet access (S)

headline: ON ADVERTISING : Can a beer from Brazil go global?
Technology Briefing | Telecommunications: Sprint Reports 3rd-Quarter Loss
abstract: Sprint Corp reports third-quarter loss; net loss widened to $1.91 billion from $497 million year ago; sales rose 3.1 percent, to $6.92 billion (S)

headline: World Briefing | Americas: Canada: Banishing The Pit Bull's Bite
abstract: The government of Ontario introduced legislation proposing a ban on all breeds of dogs commonly known as pit bulls, after a number of highly publicized pit bull attacks in Toronto in recent months. Under the legislation, owners of dangerous dogs that attack a person would face an $8,000 (U.S.) fine or up to six months in prison. Current owners would be allowed to keep their dogs, provided the animals were muzzled and leashed in public.   Colin Campbell (NYT)

headline: Aviation Fight Mirrors Larger French-German Rivalry
abstract: French shareholders of European Aeronautic Defense and Space Co, parent of Airbus, confirm that they will name Airbus chief executive Noel Forgeard to become co-chief executive of EADS in summer of 2005; Germans put forward Thomas Enders, head of military unit of EADS, as his counterpart; Forgeard favors scrapping dual management structure of EADS, saying it is inefficient; Forgeard photo (M)

headline: Typhoon Kills 412 in Philippines; President Blames Illegal Logging
abstract: Philippines is hit by second, even stronger typhoon after first sets off flooding and landslides that cause death toll to rise over 400; Pres Gloria Macapagal Arroyo blames illegal logging for high number of casualties and orders crackdown on practice; most of deaths are in Quezon Province, where illegal logging is rampant (M)

headline: Berlusconi delays lowering taxes
Business Blossoming in Las Vegas
abstract: American entrepreneurship is flourishing in Las Vegas largely because of low taxes and rapidly growing population; some examples cited, including Mary Basta's Chocolate Swan shops she opened in Mandalay Bay Resort and Casino; photo (M)

headline: U.S. and Europe Fail to Resolve Dispute on Aircraft Subsidies
abstract: Top trade officials for United States and European Union fail to resolve their dispute over government subsidies to aircraft manufacturers, especially Airbus and Boeing, inching closer to clash before World Trade Organization (M)

headline: Security Policy Modified
abstract: Transportation Security Administration, reacting to complaints from women who say they were groped by airport screeners under new policy to search for nonmetallic explosives; modifies procedures for pat-down security searches; Norman Siegel, representing some women seeking legal redress for what they claim was unnecessarily invasive pat-down searches, says modifications are inadequate; Travel Industry Association of America says Americans in record numbers are planning winter travel; says Americans will take 243 million individual trips through next February, 2.6 percent increase over period last winter; Los Angeles International Airport has set aside 'cellphone waiting lot,' where motorists can park free till they get call to pick up arriving passenger at curbside; photo (Memo Pad column) (M)

headline: DEL MONTE REDUCES PROFIT FORECAST FOR 2005
abstract: Del Monte Foods Co cuts 2005 profit forecast; earned $41.6 million in its second quarter, up from $40.2 million year ago; sales rose 6.9 percent, to $846.6 million (S)

headline: Technology Briefing | Biotechnology: Monsanto Wins Patent Dispute
abstract: The Monsanto Company, the world's biggest developer of genetically engineered crops, said yesterday that it had won a 12-year patent dispute over technology used to modify genes in plants like cotton. The Patent and Trademark Office ruled that Monsanto was the first to invent agrobacterium transformation in dicot plants. The decision ends a dispute with the Max Planck Institute and others, Monsanto said yesterday. The company, which is based in St. Louis, used the technology to create Bollgard cotton seeds, which are resistant to bollworms, a spokesman, Ben Kampelman, said. Shares of Monsanto rose 33 cents, to $36.74.

headline: In the Bay Area, TiVo Supplies DVR's at a Terrific Price: Nothing
abstract: TiVo gives away nearly 2,000 digital video recorders to Comcast subscribers who show up at its Silicon Valley headquarters between 11 am and 1 pm on Dec 17 (S)

headline: World Business Briefing | Africa: South Africa: Gold Miner Posts  A Loss
abstract: Harmony Gold Mining Co, which has bid to take over Gold Fields, posts loss of 340 million rand ($55 million) in its first quarter ended Sept 30, its fifth consecutive quarterly loss; Gold Fields says it will respond to Harmony's $8 billion takeover bid on Nov 3 (S)

headline: Profit Off 13% at J.P. Morgan; Trading Cited as Weak Spot
abstract: J P Morgan Chase & Co surprises Wall Street with sharp drop in third-quarter earnings; profits were $1.4 billion, down about 13 percent from earnings of $1.6 billion year earlier; revenue was $12.5 billion, up from $7.8 billion last year; chief executive William B Harrison Jr comments (M)

headline: World Business Briefing | Asia: India: Reliance Asks Directors To Stay
abstract: Reliance Energy, in latest move in power struggle between brothers Mukesh and Anil Ambani, asks six directors to reconsider their resignations (S)

headline: Asia very doubtful on the honesty of leaders, poll finds : Mistrust of leaders found high worldwide
Sony Also Tries to Give the TV a Life Outside the Living Room
abstract: Sony offers LocationFree TV, which retransmits home television signal wirelessly throughout house or over the Internet to remote locations; photo (M)

headline: Selling the Popcorn
abstract: I GREW up in Ogden, Utah, north of Salt Lake City. My dad was in the service station business back when they really were service stations.    I started going down to the station with him on weekends when I was 5 or 6. My job was to wipe down the cans, clean the shelves and stack the cans up again so they looked pretty. I'd earn a few pennies.

headline: Republicans Try to Dilute Provisions in Tax Bill
abstract: House Republicans are working in House-Senate conference committee to eliminate or dilute Senate-passed provisions in new corporate tax cut bill aimed at cracking down on illegal tax shelters that cost government billions of dollars a year; provisions, opposed by range of business lobbyists and tax lawyers, are part of larger battle in Congress over how to attack rapidly expanding use of complex transactions used to evade taxes; House Republicans oppose provisions to greatly increase penalties on people who spin complex transactions that serve no purpose other than tax avoidance and to let Internal Revenue Service demand customer lists from companies promoting tax shelters; particularly oppose provision to tighten definition of tax shelters; photo (M)

headline: UNITED HEALTHCARE TO SETTLE MEDICARE CHARGES
abstract: Justice Department says United Healthcare Insurance Co, unit of UnitedHealth Group, will pay $3.5 million to settle charges it defrauded federal Medicare program (S)

headline: Spitzer Accuses Insurance Industry of Rigging Bids
abstract: The New York attorney general filed a lawsuit today accusing the world's largest insurance broker of cheating its customers by rigging bids for the coverage they bought.

headline: Citing Cancer, Chief Resigns at McDonald's
abstract: McDonald's Corp says Charles H Bell is resigning as chief executive to focus on his battle with cancer, will be succeeded by vice chairman James Skinner; Bell took chief executive post in April after death of James R Cantalupo, who suffered heart attack on April 19; McDonald's USA chief executive Michael Roberts is named president and chief operating officer; will also join board (M)

headline: With Oil Prices Up, It Could Be a Long Winter
abstract: Americans face higher heating oil bills in coming winter, with crude oil touching $53 a barrel; some analysts say crude oil prices could reach $60 a barrel, double last year's prices if supplies are suddenly interrupted or winter is very cold; problem is not on demand side, but rather with supply, especially impact of hurricanes on production in Gulf of Mexico and labor strife in Nigeria, fifth-largest source of crude for US; photo (M)

headline: Chipmaker Has Profit (and a Glut)
abstract: Intel Corp reports its profit for third quarter rose 15 percent from year earlier, though it continued to struggle with inventory glut that has reduced its profit margins; net income for quarter was $1.9 billion compared with $1.66 billion for quarter year earlier; revenue reached $8.5 billion for quarter, compared with $7.8 billion in quater last year (M)

headline: World Business Briefing | Europe: France: Vivendi Rating Raised
abstract: Moody's Investors Service raises credit rating of Vivendi Universal one level, to investment grade; photo (S)

headline: COMMERCIAL REAL ESTATE
abstract: Several companies are hoping Westwood Village, a retail district with Spanish-colonial-style architecture bordering the University of California, Los Angeles, will make a comeback. [C6.]    Thylan Associates is acquiring the largest commercial site in Middlebury, Conn., for less than half the amount that had been sought. Plans call for filling the space with about 10 users taking spaces of 10,000 to 30,000 square feet each. [C4.]

headline: Terror links alleged in a power struggle : Dispute splits Bulgaria's Muslims
Brazil is driving a revival in sugar cane fuel : Ethanol's sweet success
A Good Season for Online Sales
abstract: Online sales growth surpasses high range of estimates thanks to heavy last-minute sales to holiday shoppers; on-line spending was on track to reach only low end of estimates in mid-Dec; experts say typical online holiday favorites of computers, consumer electronics and apparels were again dominant items; photo (M)

headline: For the Gamer Who Wants Some Extra Zip, a Mouse That Doesn't Crawl
abstract: Razer Diamondback from Alienware is ultra-sensitive mouse that tracks at 1,600 dots per inch; designed with gamers in mind, Razer Diamondback is house mouse for 2004 World Cyber Games (S)

headline: Turks welcome the EU's go-ahead
Joyful Dancing
abstract: The people of North Korea are not as submissive as they appear to be. Unnoticed by the outside world, strong opposition to the regime of dictator Kim Jong Il is beginning to appear.

headline: Israel Apologizes for Killing Egyptian Officers
abstract: The Israeli prime minister, Ariel Sharon, apologized to Egypt today after an Israeli army tank crew fired on an Egyptian patrol near the border with Gaza, killing three Egyptian police officers.

headline: CBS Forms a Unit to Oversee Marketing
abstract: CBS Forms a Unit.

headline: CAMPAIGN 2004: Rhetoric on the rise as Florida begins vote
ViewPoints:A DEFENSIVE STOCK:
The Real Consequences of Pension Projections
abstract: Securities and Exchange Commission is generally examining whether corporations alter projections for health care costs, pension plan returns and other factors as way of manipulating earnings; agency is looking at automakers like GM and Ford Motor because they have some of largest pension plans and offer medical benefits to huge number of retirees; Northwest Airlines appears to be under scrutiny because of unusual actuarial assumptions that it has factored into its pension calculations; graph; photo (Market Place column) (M)

headline: Software Firm to Name New Chief Executive
abstract: Computer Associates International is expected to announce its new chief executive will be John Swainson, IBM executive with strong technical and sales credentials but who is untested in leading business size of Computer Associates, which has 15,000 employees; Swainson assumes control over company that is emerging from accounting scandal, barely sidestepped criminal indictment and whose long-time leaders have been forced out (M)

headline: Rivals in Ukraine Agree to Negotiate Over Vote
abstract: The two candidates claiming to be president-elect of Ukraine met Friday in the presence of international mediators and agreed to begin immediate negotiations to try to end their bitter stalemate, the first sign of an easing of the political tensions that have risked leading the nation toward civil war.    The campaigns of Prime Minister Viktor F. Yanukovich, the official winner of the presidential election, and of Viktor A. Yushchenko, the opposition challenger who asserts that his victory was stolen by state-organized fraud, plan to start holding talks on Saturday.

headline: HEIDRICK & STRUGGLES CHOSEN TO FIND NEW DISNEY CHIEF
abstract: HA

headline: Once a Backwater, Slovakia Surges
abstract: Foreign investors are turning Slovakia into one of fastest-growing economies in Central Europe; Slovakia's state investment agency has signed 47 deals this year worth $2.26 billion, up from 22 deals for $1.55 billion in 2003; economic growth is up 5.3 percent, to $33.3 billion in last three quarters; businesses are lured by political stability, low labor costs and low taxes; biggest investments have been in automotive plants; Peugeot Citroen, Kia, and Ford Motor are set to join Volkswagen, which already makes 300,000 vehicles a year in Bratislava; Slovakia is expected to produce 850,000 cars a year by 2007, becoming world's largest car producer per capita; photo (M)

headline: Fannie Mae, After the Battle of Capitol Hill
abstract: Analysis of future of Fannie Mae in wake of ongoing regulatory investigations and ouster of chairman-chief executive Franklin D Raines; says Fannie Mae's struggles will be played out in halls of Congress as well as in corporate boardrooms; holds its fate, and any reorientation of way it conducts business, will have effects on homeowners and world financial markets; graph (M)

headline: Polls show Kerry victory in debate
Eisner Regrets Praising Ovitz on 'Larry King'
abstract: In an interview on CNN's ''Larry King Live'' in September 1996, Michael D. Eisner, chief executive of the Walt Disney Company, praised Michael S. Ovitz, then Disney's president. But at the same time, Mr. Eisner said in testimony here on Thursday, he was telling Disney's board about troubles with Mr. Ovitz.    In his fourth day of testimony in the shareholder lawsuit regarding the hiring and firing of Mr. Ovitz, Mr. Eisner said his television appearance was ''dumb'' and ''stupid.'' Mr. Ovitz joined Disney in October 1995 and was fired 14 months later, receiving a severance package valued at $140 million.

headline: DataBank; Investors Give Markets a Pre-Christmas Rally
abstract: The stock market rose in four days of trading last week, as both the Dow Jones industrial average and the Standard & Poor's 500-stock index closed on Thursday at their highest points in the last three years.    The Commerce Department reported Thursday that personal incomes rose 0.3 percent last month, more than anticipated by many economists, and the University of Michigan said that its index of consumer confidence jumped to an 11-month high in December.

headline: Rivals in Ukraine Report Violations in Presidential Vote
abstract: Voters in Ukraine cast ballots for president; charges by international election observers of pattern of harassment and electoral irregularities calls into question fairness of vote to elect successor to Pres Leonid D Kuchma; his decision to step down after two five-year terms has opened fierce fight over country's future, with Prime Min Viktor F Yanukovich promising to follow Kuchma's course and Viktor A Yushchenko promising to steer country toward more open and democratic path; country's only television network not controlled by Kuchma's government has its license to broadcast suspended; photo (M)

headline: Pro-West Leader Appears to Win Ukraine Election
abstract: Opposition leader Viktor A Yushchenko appears to win third round of voting in presidential race in Ukraine marked by intrigue, charges of poisoning, fervent street demonstrations and widespread abuses of state power; egregious election violations that discredited previous round of voting are not in evidence in this latest round; Yushchenko predicts end at last to extended and bitter election season and promises 'new great democracy'; leads Prime Min Viktor F Yanukovich, 55 percent to 40 percent, with three-quarters of votes counted; displays of fireworks light up Independence Square in Kiev as tens of thousands of Yushchenko's supporters turn out once more, as they did in late November and early December to protest government fraud that discredited last vote; Yushchenko's face is still disfigured from dioxin poisoning this fall for which he has blamed his adversaries in government; while Yanukovich seeks stronger ties with Russia, Yushchenko pledges to accelerate Ukraine's post-Soviet evolution by fashioning more open government and by nurturing relationships with Western nations; photos (M)

headline: Redeploying In Gaza Strip, Israel Finishes Its Pullback
abstract: Israeli troops and armor completed their pullback from built-up areas in the Gaza Strip early on Saturday, but many soldiers have remained in the territory, redeployed on the hills overlooking the Jabaliya and Beit Hanun refugee settlements.    The redeployment was the effective end to Israel's 17-day offensive to repress the firing of Qassam rockets into Israeli settlements and towns from the northern Gaza strip. Some 115 Palestinians died during the operation, Israeli Radio said Saturday morning. Western news agencies say at least a third of the dead have been civilians caught in the crossfire, including two schoolgirls killed by stray fire as they sat at their desks.

headline: U.S. Intensifying Bombing Attacks on Falluja Sites
abstract: American forces stepped up their pressure on the insurgent-controlled city of Falluja on Friday, unleashing an aerial and artillery bombardment of suspected guerrilla positions and encircling the city with hundreds of marines at checkpoints along its main roads.    Beginning Thursday, American jets began their most intense bombardment of the city yet, dropping 11 satellite- and laser-guided 500-pound bombs on suspected guerrilla safe houses and weapons depots, as 1,600 American marines moved forward under artillery fire to set up the checkpoints, designed to snare insurgents moving out of the city.

headline: In a Gesture of Conciliation, the Pope Returns Orthodox Relics
abstract: Pope John Paul II returns bones of St John Chrysostom and St Gregory of Nazianzus to Ecumenical Patriarch Bartholomew I of Orthodox Church in ceremony at St Peter's in Rome; returned an icon to Russian Orthodox Church in August; moves are conciliatory and political; John Paul II hopes to become first Pope to visit Russia, his health permitting; there is some dispute about when relics were removed from Constantinople; portion of relics will remain interred in St Peter's in Rome (M)

headline: Ex-Pentagon Official Gets 9 Months for Conspiring to Favor Boeing
abstract: Judge T S Ellis 3d sentences Darleen A Druyun, former top Air Force official, to nine months in prison after she acknowledges she favored Boeing Co in multibillion-dollar Defense contracts while seeking jobs at company for herself and family; Druyun pleaded guilty in April to one count of conspiracy for negotiating job with Boeing overseeing its business with Pentagon; offers details on extent of her favoritism toward Boeing as well as difficult negotiations during which she admitted to misleading government investigators; apologizes to court for her actions; photo (M)

headline: Plan to Shift New Jersey Pension Funds Approved
abstract: New Jersey state pension fund governing council approves plan to shift responsibility for portion of $66 billion fund to outside money managers; plan also allows much more aggressive investment strategy, using vehicles such as hedge funds, real estate and private equities; representatives of teachers and general public employees unions oppose plan and assert they will challenge it in court; New Jersey fund lost more than $20 billion following crash of technology stocks in 2000, and plan ad vocates argue that new alternative investments may help recover losses more quickly (M)

headline: Ukrainian Candidate Returns to Hospital for Testing
abstract: Viktor A Yushchenko, opposition candidate for president in Ukraine, returns to Vienna hospital for third time since Sept for futher testing to determine whether he had been poisoned and, if so, to identify toxic substance; photo (M)d

headline: No Jackpot for Domain-Name Speculators
abstract: Hundreds of candidate-related domain names have been staked out by those hoping to cash in, either by selling items to people who stumble on sites or by selling domain names to candidates' parties; one monitoring service reports 871 registered Web addresses evoking Pres Bush's name and 733 using Sen Kerry's (M)

headline: Airbus's Midsize Challenge to Boeing
abstract: European Aeronautic Defense and Space Co, or EADS, says its board supports plan by Airbus to build competitor to 7E7, Boeing's highly efficient 200-to-300-seat plane intended for huge market in midsize aircraft; Airbus plane, to be called A350, will be based on existing aircraft, A330, photos (M)

headline: Technology Briefing | Hardware: TiVo's 3rd-Quarter Loss Widens
abstract: TiVo Inc reports widening of third-quarter loss, to $26.4 million; reports 11 percent decline in revenue, to $38.3 million (S)

headline: THE WORKPLACE : In France, worker bias has a name
Canada, the Closer Country for Outsourcing Work
abstract: Kean and other software outsourcing companies, which often send work to employees in India, Philippines and Singapore, are sending more work to Canada; Canada, which lags India in number of people working in outsourcing businesses, offers stability, proximity and cultural similarity to US and tends to attract higher-value, more sophisticated work; photo (M)

headline: World Business Briefing | Asia: Thailand: Industrial Output Rises
abstract: Bank of Thailand reports Thailand's industrial production rose by 9.5 percent in November, fastest pace in nine months; reports 22 percent rise in exports on balance-of-payments basis, to $8.71 billion; reports 29.6 percent hike in imports, to $8.53 billion (S)

headline: COMPANY BRIEFS
abstract: NEIMAN MARCUS GROUP, Dallas, the retailer, said it had sold its Chef's Catalog business to Pikes Peak Direct Marketing, a company formed by JH Partners, San Francisco, a private equity firm, for less than $20 million.    ASA INTERNATIONAL LTD., Framingham, Mass., a software maker, said it had rejected a second bid to be purchased by Rippe & Kingston Systems, Cincinnati, a software company, for $6 a share. ASA International said it was not interested in being acquired and wanted to go private.    MURRAY INC., Brentwood, Tenn., a lawnmower manufacturer, filed for bankruptcy protection, citing reduced profits and inadequate cash resources.    KNIGHT RIDDER INC., San Jose, Calif., the newspaper publisher, named Steve Rossi, former president of its newspaper unit, its chief financial officer.

headline: Technology Briefing | Software: Panel Suspends Review Of ContentGuard Buyout
abstract: European Commission reportedly suspends review of plan by Microsoft and Time Warner to buy ContentGuard, maker of antipiracy software (M)

headline: World Business Briefing | Europe: Russia: Relief At Tax Bill
abstract: Russia's mobile phone operator VimpelCom receives tax claim of $21 million for 2002, less than company expected; shares rise 8 percent; graph (S)

headline: With F.C.C. Consent, Cingular Buys AT&T Wireless
abstract: Cingular Wireless completes its purchase of AT&T Wireless after Federal Communications Commission signs off on $41 billion deal that creates country's largest mobile phone provider (M)

headline: Globalist : Signs that the worst may be over in Africa
World Business Briefing | Asia: Japan: Top-Selling Car
abstract: Honda Motor's Fit compact beats Toyota Corolla as Japan's best-selling model for second straight month in Sept; Fit sales rose 7.4 percent from Sept 2003 level, to 15,482 units (S)

headline: World Business Briefing | Asia: Japan: Wholesale Prices Rise
abstract: Japanese wholesale prices rose 1.8 percent in September from year earlier, largest gain in more than 13 years (S)0

headline: Names of the Dead
abstract: The Department of Defense has identified 1,060 American service members who have died since the start of the Iraq war. It confirmed the death of the following American yesterday:    POTTS, Christopher S., 38, Sgt., Army National Guard; Tiverton, R.I., First Battalion, 103rd Field Artillery.

headline: JOINT VENTURE TO PRODUCE ONCE-A-DAY AIDS PILL
abstract: Bristol-Myers Squibb Co and Gilead Sciences form joint venture to develop and market HIV treatment that combines three AIDS drugs in a once-a-day pill; pill contains Bristol-Myers's Sustiva and Gilead's Viread and Emtriva drugs; companies plan to seek Food and Drug Administration approval for their new drug in second half of 2005 (S)

headline: PeopleSoft defends plan
Italians rally to keep Fiat 500 on the road
Investcorp Pays $350 Million for Thomson's Media Group
abstract: Investcorp

headline: World Briefing | Asia: Sri Lanka: Rebels Accused In Swiss Death
abstract: The police blamed Tamil Tiger rebels for the killing of a 61-year-old Swiss man, Hans Ulris Herpos, on Monday night in eastern Sri Lanka, Reuters reported. If true, it would be the first rebel killing of a foreigner since a 2002 cease-fire ended two decades of civil war in the country. The killing comes after the assassination of dozens of ethnic Tamils who opposed the separatist guerrilla group. Tamil Tiger officials could not be reached for comment.   David Rohde (NYT)

headline: Technology Briefing | Software: Illinois: Regulating Videos For Minors
abstract: Illinois Gov Rod R Blagojevich will propose bills to prohibit sales, rental and distribution of violent and sexually explicit video games to minors; similar bills in other states and cities have been held to be unconstitutional; Blagojevich says legislation will address court objections by narrowly defining games to be restricted (S)

headline: Germans Weigh Taking Stocks Off Wall Street
abstract: Add another entry to the list of how Americans and Europeans are parting ways. Several German companies, which rushed to have their shares traded on exchanges in the United States during the bull market of the late 1990's, are now seriously thinking about abandoning the market.    The Germans are disenchanted by the United States as a source of capital, and offended by what they view as oppressive new regulations adopted in the aftermath of Enron and other corporate scandals.

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: A New Study Finds Aleve Could Create Problems  A new study has found that Aleve, made by Bayer, could increase heart problems. It was the fourth pain medicine in recent months to be suspected of increasing heart risks.    The study, sponsored by the National Institutes of Health, was intended to measure whether Aleve and Celebrex might prevent Alzheimer's disease. [Page A1.]    Exelon Agrees to Buy Local Utility  Shares of Exelon rose after the owner of utilities in northern Illinois and eastern Pennsylvania said that it would buy the Public Service Enterprise Group of New Jersey in a deal valued at about $13.2 billion. For the deal to be complete, the new company will have to shed more than 1,400 jobs, or 5 percent of the combined work force of 28,000, and be approved by state and federal regulators. [C2.]    Yukos Auction Deepens Doubts  Little is known about the Baikal Finans Group, a company registered in a provincial Russian town that was the winning bidder for the largest subsidiary of Yukos. [C8.]    Bidders Vie for London Exchange  Both the pan-European exchange Euronext and Deutsche B√∂rse have expressed interest in acquiring the London Stock Exchange. [World Business, Section W.]    Liberty Media Accelerates Swap  Liberty Media is accelerating a planned swap of nonvoting shares in the News Corporation for voting shares in the company. [C4.]    2 Companies Plan to Go Public  The tale of two companies planning to go public: Lazard and √âlectricit√© de France. Floyd Norris: Market Place. [C9.]    Sprint Expects Growth to Continue  Sprint said that it expected sales and profit to continue growing in 2005, but Sprint did not take into account its proposed merger with Nextel, which the companies say will be completed by the second half of 2005. [C9.]    Disney Settles With the S.E.C.  The Securities and Exchange Commission reached a settlement with Walt Disney over the company's failure to disclose its relationships with various board members. For example, Thomas S. Murphy, left, who was chairman of Capital Cities/ABC and a former director, received secretarial services, a leased car and a driver. In addition, the children of three directors -- Reveta Bowers, Stanley P. Gold and Raymond L. Watson -- worked at Disney. [C4.]    Diageo Agrees to Acquire Chalone  Diageo agreed to buy the Chalone Wine Group for $200 million plus the assumption of $60 million in debt. The bid was $2.50 a share more than one from Domaines Barons de Rothschild. [World Business, Section W.]    Electronic Arts Buys Stake in Rival  Electronic Arts acquired a 19.9 percent of Ubisoft Entertainment, the maker of games based on Tom Clancy novels. [C9.]    Jones Settles Marketing Charge  Edward D. Jones said that it had agreed to pay $75 million to settle accusations by regulators that it did not disclose hidden marketing deals with mutual funds. [C7.]    Dow and S.&P. Up, but Nasdaq Dips  Stocks finished mixed. The Dow Jones industrial average rose 11.68 points, to 10,661.60, and the Standard & Poor's 500-stock index gained 0.45 of a point, to 1,194.65. The Nasdaq composite index fell 7.35 points, to 2,127.85. [C9.]    What's a Parent to Do?  Traveling with small children is common around the holidays, and so are parental anxieties. Joe Sharkey: On the Road. [C6.]

headline: Technology Briefing | Deals: SkyTerra Buys Stake In DirecTV Unit
abstract: DirecTV Group sells 50 percent stake in new unit that includes Hughes Network Systems business to SkyTerra Communications for about $251 million in cash; graph (S)

headline: Ovitz Fired for Management Style, Ex-Disney Director Testifies
abstract: Former Disney director Stanley P Gold testifies that Michael Ovitz was fired as president in 1996 because his management style differed sharply from chief executive Michael D Eisner's; Gold resigned last year along with Roy Disney to campaign for Eisner's ouster (S)

headline: Blueprint and BT join music fray
Finding legal information online
A Campaign Chat Turns to Anchors
abstract: Dan Rather's admission in Sept that he erred in broadcasting and defending flawed report on 60 Minutes about Pres Bush's National Guard Service is discussed at panel on presidential campaign sponsored by New Yorker magazine, New York City; rival broadcasters Peter Jennings and Tom Brokaw defend Rather, who declines to comment on probe; photo (M)

headline: Briefs: Euro-zone retail sales fall again
In a Clamshell, AT&T Delivers a Tool for Text
abstract: David Pogue State of the Art column on Ogo from AT&T, pocket-size clamshell gadget designed for sending and receiving text, e-mail and instant messaging using cellphone network; device, which is being marketed to young crowd that longs for these features, is not a cellphone; photo; drawing (M)

headline: Correction
Rebels in Ivory Coast Say They Have Not Been Invited to Talks
abstract: A spokesman for the rebel forces that control the northern half of Ivory Coast said that the rebels had not been invited to talks led by South Africa's president.

headline: Briefs: Ballot counting starts 5 days after election
STARBUCKS ANNOUNCES EXECUTIVE CHANGES
abstract: Starbucks Corp says Jim Donald will take over as president and chief executive on March 31 when Orin Smith retires; Jim Alling is promoted to new position of president of Starbucks Coffee US (S)

headline: I.R.S. Loses a Tax Shelter Ruling
abstract: A judge has ruled against the Internal Revenue Service in its effort to prove that it does not owe Coltec Inc. an $82 million refund in connection with what the agency contends is an abusive tax shelter.    The ruling is the second setback in two months for the I.R.S. in its fight against what it regards as questionable tax shelters. Coltec is an industrial concern formerly involved in mining.

headline: More Data Sought on Drug for Sex Drive
abstract: Federal advisory panel, citing lack of information about long-term safety, votes unanimously not to approve Intrinsa, testosterone patch developed by Procter & Gamble that would enhance sex drive of women; panel member Dr Steven Nissen, cardiologist at Cleveland Clinic, says he does not want to expose several million American women to risk of heart attack and stroke in order to have one more sexual experience per month; Food and Drug Administration, which convened meeting, will have final say on patch (M)

headline: Seven Ways to Save on Taxes (Just Don't Wait Until 2005)
abstract: Securities investors should consider seven tax strategies before end of year (M)

headline: HOW DO YOU MANAGE?: No secretary?You could, but...
World Briefing | Europe: Bosnia-Herzegovina: Bosnian Serbs Admit Massacre
abstract: Bosnia's Serb Republic conceded for the first time that its forces executed more than 7,000 Muslim men and boys in the town of Srebrenica during the 1992-1995 civil war in the country. The admission was made in an officially sanctioned report by a panel of judges and lawyers commissioned to look into the massacre. A previous report had admitted to the involvement of Bosnian Serb troops, but put the number of deaths at just over 600.   Nicholas Wood (NYT)

headline: UPS WORKERS STAGE A WALKOUT IN CANADA
abstract: 3,800 United Parcel Service drivers and sorters walk off job in Canada, shutting down most of its operations in country; strike affects about 1 percent of company's 360,000 employees (S)

headline: World Briefing | Europe: Iceland: Searching For Bobby Fischer?
abstract: Iceland grants temporary residency to former chess champion Bobby Fischer, under arrest since July for traveling on invalid US passport (S)

headline: Looking for a Phone Listing? Check Your Text Messages
abstract: Text-messaging company UpSnap has introduced free directory assistance service for users of short message service; glitches are still being worked out; photo (S)

headline: Spanish honor author, but remain aloof : Like tilting at a windmill:Cervantes lost on Madrid
INSURANCE REGULATORS SEEK DOCUMENTS FROM MUNICH RE
abstract: Munich Re says one of its North American units was subpoenaed by insurance regulators in North Carolina and Texas in connection with bid-rigging investigation (S)

headline: Fears of an Identity Crisis for Lands' End at Sears
abstract: Retail analysts agree that Lands' End clothing line has little to gain and much to lose with Kmart's acquisition of Sears, Roebuck; note that fit between Sears and Lands' End has been awkward; say that purchase may have watered down Lands' End image, and Kmart's takeover of Sears threatens to erode that further; Sears chief execuieve Alan J Lacy acknowledges that store made several missteps in handling of Lands' End; photo (M) photo (M)

headline: How I Got That Schwag: A Boldfaced Online Spree
abstract: Joyce Wadler humorous article about online shopping (Special section, Retail) (M)

headline: World Business Briefing | Europe: Britain: Do-It-Yourself Retailer Acquired
abstract: World Business Briefing: Britain: Do-It-r

headline: Maturing of childrenswear:no longer just miniature adults
COMPANY BRIEFS
abstract: VALLEY NATIONAL BANCORP, Wayne, N.J., said yesterday that it would buy Shrewsbury Bancorp, Shrewsbury, N.J., for $136 million, or $48 a share, in cash and stock, gaining 12 branches in Monmouth County, N.J.    BANK OF AMERICA CORP., Charlotte, N.C., said James H. Hance Jr., its vice chairman, would retire at the end of January.    GNC CORP., Pittsburgh, a maker and seller of nutrition supplements and health products, said that Louis Mancini, its chief executive and president, had resigned.    CATERPILLAR, Peoria, Ill., the maker of earth-moving equipment, said it would close a factory in Quebec and lay off about 85 workers.

headline: Cisco Expects to Hit Estimate for Revenue
abstract: Cisco

headline: World Briefing | Europe: Britain: Hunt Ban Challenged
abstract: Countryside Alliance, group of British pro-hunt activitists, begins legal action against Parliament's decision to ban hunting with dogs; holds use of Parliament Act, envoked to pass legislation, is invalid (S)

headline: Liberal Leader From Ukraine Was Poisoned
abstract: Viennese doctor says tests confirm that Viktor A Yushchenko, Ukrainian opposition candidate, was poisoned with dioxin, providing explantion for broad array of painful and disfiguring conditions that plagued him during last three months of presidential campaign; Dr Michael Zimpfer says Yushchenko's blood dioxin leve was 'more than 1,000 times' upper limits of normal and that his initial severe abdominal pain suggests he ate the poison; Yushchenko's opponents have in past ridiculed his claim of having been poisoned; he fell ill after Sept 5 dinner with Gen Ihor P Smeshko, head of Ukraine's successor to KGB; KGB and Eastern European intelligence services used poison against political enemies in earlier years of cold war; Smeshko dismisses notion that he was involved in poisoning of Yushchenko, and Yushchenko himself has been vague on topic of who tried to poison him; photos (M)

headline: New Leadership For a G.M. Account
abstract: Leo Burnett Worldwide in Chicago, part of the Publicis Groupe, has named James C. Moore as executive vice president for the General Motors international account, a new post. Mr. Moore, 49, had been president and chief executive at the AppleSeed Group in Birmingham, Mich., and previously worked at agencies like Foote Cone & Belding and McCann Erickson Worldwide.

headline: DO WELL, DO GOOD
abstract: Bright Horizons day care center chain co-founder Roger H Brown is inaugurated as president of Berklee College of Music in Boston (S)

headline: An Oklahoma Version of Guns vs. Butter
abstract: Federal Judge Sven Erik Holmes of leaves in force temporary restraining order preventing Oklahoma law that allows employees to keep firearms in locked vehicles on company property from taking effect, as challenges to it mount from companies including ConocoPhillips and Williams Companies; showdown between several of Oklahoma's largest companies and people who want to carry guns began in March, when rural legislators rushed through measures to prevent companies from infringing on what they viewed as employee's right to keep gun close at hand at work; photo (M)

headline: Libraries Reach Out, Online
abstract: Libraries are breaking free of physical limitations by making materials and services available online; New York Public Library offers 3,000 titles to cardholders, which can be borrowed for set periods by downloading on computer, hand-held organizer or other device using free reader software; when they are due, files are automatically locked out and returned to circulation; systems from other libraries described; photos (M)

headline: Parliament in Kiev Begins Re-examining Flawed Election Laws
abstract: Emergency session of Parliament, called after Ukrainian Supreme Court nullified recent contested election, fails to draft changes in election laws to prevent repetition of fraud in November 28 election; allies of opposition candidate Viktor Yushchenko have pressed for changes, but pro-government members have proposed shifting some presidential powers to Parliament; Yushchenko's allies say they support proposal but insist shift take effect only after next election; court has scheduled runoff election for December 26; photo (M)

headline: The Disco Ball of Failed Hopes and Other Tales From Inside Intel
abstract: Intel, giant computer chip maker, seems to have lost its way lately; has publicly canceled succession of high-profile projects, replaced managers in money-losing ventures and fallen behind Advanced Micro Devices in introducing technologies in markets it has long dominated; Paul S Otellini, who will become chief executive in May, plans strategy shift; Intel, previously obsessed with making ever-faster chips, now focuses on complete systems aimed at both computing and consumer electronics markets; Otellini says recent missteps are result of overoptimistic marketing, interview; stock price graph; drawing (M)

headline: Advertising Revenue Rises for Newspapers
abstract: Newspaper Association of America says advertising revenue for newspapers rose 3.8 percent in third quarter, to $11.3 billion, from year ago; revenue rose 3.8 percent, to $33 billion, for first nine months, compared with period pervious year (S)1

headline: Technology Briefing | Software: Pixar Profit Soars On Home Video Sales
abstract: Pixar Animation Studios says third-quarter profit jumped 70 percent; net income increased to $22.4 million, or 38 cents a share, from $13.2 million, or 23 cents a share, year earlier; revenue rises 47 percent, to $44.5 million from $30.2 million (S)

headline: World Business Briefing | Asia: Thailand: Refiner Sells Shares
abstract: Initial public offering of 60 million shares of Thai Oil, largest oil refiner in Thailand, sells out to individual investors in four hours; company plans to raise as much as $700 million by selling 900 million shares over next few days; most of shares belong to creditors that took them in lieu of $900 million in debt as part of restructuring deal in 2000 (S)

headline: SUPERMARKET OPERATOR TO SELL DISTRIBUTION CENTERS
abstract: The Penn Traffic Company, which operates 109 supermarkets in the Northeast, said yesterday that it planned to sell five distribution centers in New York and Pennsylvania for $37 million as part of a plan to emerge from bankruptcy. The Equity Industrial Partners Corporation will purchase the centers, then lease them back to Penn Traffic for an initial term of 15 years, according to papers filed with the United States Bankruptcy Court in New York. Penn Traffic, which is based in Syracuse, N.Y., filed for bankruptcy protection in May 2003.

headline: French Court Delays Decision on Hezbollah-Run TV Channel
abstract: France's highest administrative court delays decision on banning Al Manar Arabic-language channel, run by Hezbollah, from Lebanon; government asserts that Al Manar's broadcasts are anti-Semitic and racist and support violence, but effort to shut it down has been thwarted by legal loopholes; French broadcasting regulator last month renewed license for Al Manar to operate in France as long as it abides by law; government contends it broke law four days later with inflammatory story; Al Manar is available by satellite in United States, where there are no plans to close it down, although Hezbollah has been on State Dept list of terrorist organization since 1997 (M)

headline: World Briefing | Americas: Mexico: Fox Fires Police Chiefs After Lynchings
abstract: Mexican Pres Vicente Fox fires chiefs of federal and Mexico City police after authorities failed to stop lynchings of two police officers broadcast live on television (S)

headline: For Radio Programs When You Want Them, Plug In a Fin
abstract: Griffin Technology's RadioShark connects to USB port of PC and allows time-shifting and recording of radio broadcasts; photo (S)

headline: World Business Briefing | Asia: Singapore: Jet Fuel Concern Seeks Protection
abstract: China Aviation Oil (Singapore) Corp reportedly will ask Singapore High Court for protection from creditors after losing about $550 million in oil market; suspends its chief executive and is negotiating rescue by Chinese parent, China Aviation Oil Holding Co, and Temasek Holdings (S)

headline: Profit Rises 27% at Whole Foods
abstract: Whole Foods Market Inc says that fourth-quarter profit rose 27 percent as sales increased; company also raises its dividend 27 percent, to 19 cents a share; net income climbs to $30.2 million, or 42 cents a share, from $23.3 million, or 38 cents a share year earlier; sales in 12 weeks that ended Sept 26 rise 24 percent, to $927.3 million (S)

headline: An Upstart Goes Up Against an Established Product and Holds Its Own
abstract: Comparison of remote television viewing systems TV2Me and LocationFree TV from Sony (M)

headline: Treasury Schedules Auctions This Week
abstract: The Treasury's schedule of financing this week includes today's weekly auction of new three- and six-month bills and an auction of four-week bills tomorrow.    At the close of the New York cash market on Friday, the rate on the outstanding three-month bill was 1.69 percent. The rate on the six-month issue was 2 percent, and the rate on the four-week issue was 1.55 percent.

headline: Ikea Takes Its Business From Crispin Porter
abstract: Ikea North America moves billings estimated at $40 million from Crispin Porter & Bogusky to Secret Weapon Marketing in Santa Monica, Calif (S)

headline: ELI LILLY TO BUY AN EXPERIMENTAL DRUG FOR INSOMNIA
abstract: Eli Lilly & Co acquires experimental drug designed to fight insomnia from Merck KGaA of Germany for $29 million plus other fees and royalties (S)

headline: Consumer Borrowing Declines for First Time in Nine Months
abstract: Borrowing by American consumers falls 1.4 percent in August, measured on annual rate; initial claims for unemployment benefits fall by 37,000 for week, to one-month low of 335,000 (S)

headline: Europe Still Unhappy With U.S. Tax Subsidy
abstract: European Union objects to provisions for grandfathering in $137 billion US corporate tax bill enacted in October, which is intended to do away with tax cut for exporters that was declared illegal by World Trade Organization; new law gives some of biggest American corporations three-year grace period or transition before original tax cut is ended; photo (M)

headline: Trial in '85 Jet Blast Nears End in Canada
abstract: Canadian prosecutors open final arguments in long trial of two Canadian Sikhs accused of plotting bombing of Air India jet that exploded in midair off Ireland in 1985, killing all 329 people on board; more than 100 witnesses have testified in specially-built high-security courtroom in Vancouver, but outcome is far from certain because of years of bungled police work and unexplained killing of important suspect; photo of defendants Ripudaman Singh Malik, millionaire real estate entrepreneur, and Ajaib Snigh Bagri, sawmill worker and Sikh preacher; two are also charged in explosion that killed two baggage handlers at Narita Airport in Japan just before Air India flight went down; that bomb was intended for second plane; alleged motive was revenge for 1984 Indian army's storming of Golden Temple of Amritsar after shrine was taken over by Sikhs (M)

headline: Stung, Sharon movesto renew coalition talks
BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: Ace Dismisses 2 Executives In Response to Inquiry  Ace Ltd., a Bermuda insurer that is a subject of the New York attorney general's investigation into bid-rigging and price fixing in the insurance industry, dismissed two executives.    Ace said that it had dismissed Geoffrey G. Gregory, the president of its casualty risk unit, and Patricia Abrams, an assistant vice president who worked for Mr. Gregory, because of ''past improper actions'' in the unit. [Page C5.]    Altria May Split Into 2 or 3 Pieces  The chief executive of Altria, Louis C. Camilleri, left, said that the company might split into two or three independent entities. Altria, which includes Philip Morris USA, Philip Morris International, Philip Morris Capital and Kraft Foods, has been looking for a way to extract Kraft and Philip Morris International from the American tobacco unit, which has been mired in litigation. [C2.]    Medicare Altering Payment System  Medicare is offering to pay for a number of new treatments and diagnostic tests, ranging from $30,000-a-dose cancer drugs to brain scans to diagnose Alzheimer's -- but with a catch. Patients can only receive the payments if they enter into studies that evaluate how well they work. [A1.]    Energy Company May Appeal Ruling  The chief financial officer of Progress Energy said appealing an adverse Internal Revenue Service ruling regarding $1 billion in federal tax credits for the company could take as long as two years. [C2.]    Crude Oil Falls to a 6-Week Low  The price of crude oil for December delivery fell $2.06, to $48.82 a barrel, as increased OPEC production and slower economic growth eased pressure on supplies. [C6.]    Stocks Continue Post-Election Rally  Stocks continued their post-election rally. The Standard & Poor's 500-stock index gained 18.47 points, or 1.6 percent, to a high for the year of 1,161.67. The Nasdaq composite index climbed 19.30 points, or 1 percent, to 2.023.63, and the Dow Jones industrial average jumped 177.71 points, or 1.8 percent, to 10,314.76. [C6.]    Large Losses at MCI and Qwest  MCI and Qwest Communications reported large losses in the third quarter, driven by a continued decline in revenue and one-time write-offs. But the companies said that the long slide in phone prices might be slowing in some parts of their businesses and that they were making progress cutting costs. Shares of MCI rose 51 cents, to $17.76, and Qwest gained 17 cents, to $3.58. [C3.]    Garment Quota Move Riles China  China's Ministry of Commerce filed a protest over the possible imposition of quotas in the United States on five categories of garment imports, including polyester pants and shirts, cotton knit shirts and underwear. [C3.]    Movie Industry Preparing Lawsuits  Hollywood's major movie studios said that they would begin filing lawsuits against people who make copyrighted films available for downloading over the Internet. [C4.]    Retail Sales Rose 4% Last Month  Sales at retailers increased 4 percent in October, the Goldman, Sachs retail composite index indicated. [C3.]    Productivity Slowed in 3rd Quarter  The productivity of workers grew at a 1.9 percent annual rate in the third quarter. In a separate report, the Labor Department said that initial jobless claims fell by 19,000, to 332,000, last week. [C2.]

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: 337,000 Jobs Created; Jobless Rate Rises to 5.5%  The economy created 337,000 new jobs in October, snapping a prolonged jobs slump and renewing hopes that businesses may finally be starting to hire workers more aggressively.      Unemployment inched up 0.1 percent, to 5.5 percent. But that was seen as a generally positive development -- largely a result of discouraged workers returning to the labor force because of improving prospects. [Page A1.]    Verizon Adding NextWave Licenses  Verizon Wireless said that it would pay $3 billion in cash for the spectrum licenses owned by NextWave Telecom, a move that should help it expand coverage for new subscribers. [C2.]    Scrutiny for F.D.A. Safety System  The Food and Drug Administration announced that it would hire the government's top scientific review agency to figure out whether its drug-safety system is adequate. Also, after embarrassing disclosures that the views of its drug-safety officials have been suppressed, the agency said that it would set up an internal appeals process. [A11.]    Russia Leader Signs Kyoto Protocol  President Vladimir V. Putin signed Russia's ratification of the Kyoto Protocol on global warming, clearing the way for the international treaty aimed at reducing emissions of heat-trapping gases to take effect next year. [A10.]    Molson Sweetens Merger Offer  In a bid to gain support for its proposed merger with the Adolph Coors Company, the Canadian brewer Molson offered minority shareholders a $316 million special dividend, contingent on the merger's approval. [C3.]    Europe Unhappy With U.S. Tax Bill  The European Union raised objections to parts of the $137 billion corporate tax bill passed last month. The measure was three years in the making and was intended to do away with a tax cut for exporters that was declared illegal by the World Trade Organization. [C3.]    SBC Plans to Cut 10,000 Jobs  SBC Communications will eliminate 10,000 jobs by the end of 2005. The cuts amount to 6.1 percent of SBC's work force of 165,000 and will come through attrition and layoffs. They are in addition to 7,000 jobs SBC plans to eliminate this year. In general, SBC and the other Bell operating companies have been reducing the size of their local phone businesses because they have been losing customers. [C2.]    J.P. Morgan Forms British Venture  Cazenove and J.P. Morgan Chase have formed a joint venture in Britain that puts Cazenove in charge of all of J.P. Morgan's British investment banking business. [C3.]    Purdue Settles With West Virginia  Purdue Pharma reached a $10 million settlement with regulators in West Virginia over claims that it had inappropriately marketed OxyContin to state residents. [C2.]    An Editor for Washington Post  The Washington Post named Philip Bennett, the assistant managing editor for foreign news, as the next managing editor, replacing Steve Coll, who announced in August he would return to writing at the start of 2005. [C2.]    African Gold Miner Sues Suitor  Gold Fields filed a lawsuit against Harmony Gold Mining, a rival South African miner, in an attempt to stop Harmony's hostile $7.4 billion takeover bid. [C3.]    MBNA Adds American Express Card  MBNA introduced a line of credit cards under the American Express brand. [C4.]

headline: All Corruption Charges Against Berlusconi Are Dismissed
abstract: A three-judge panel absolved Silvio Berlusconi of corruption charges today, ending a more than decade-long legal battle.

headline: Strong Points at a Telecom May Also Be a Weakness
abstract: Strong Points At a Telecom May Also

headline: PROPERTIES : This desert is hot again
A Priority as Chechnya's President Takes Office: Staying Alive
abstract: Alu Alkhanov, the Kremlin's latest hope for stabilizing its foundering strategy in the Caucasus, was sworn into office here on Tuesday as president of Chechnya, taking control of the government of a republic with its infrastructure in ruins and its nights racked by lawlessness and terror.    The ceremony took place on the first day of what is supposed to be a four-year term. Of all the difficult tasks ahead -- and there are many -- Mr. Alkhanov's chief chore may be to stay alive.

headline: World Briefing | Americas: Colombia: Venezuela Says It Rejects Rebel Groups
abstract: Venezuelan Pres Hugo Chavez, during visit to Colombian Pres Alvaro Uribe in Cartagena, says that all armed groups who enter Venezuela are treated as national enemies; Venezuela has been accused of harboring Colombian rebels (S)

headline: World Briefing | Europe: Spain: Cost Of ETA Attacks Put At $11 Billion
abstract: Attacks by the Basque militant group ETA cost the Spanish government nearly $11 billion from 1994 to 2003, the newspaper El Pa√≠s reported. The report, citing a study commissioned by the investigative judge Baltasar Garz√≥n that has yet to be released, said nearly half the cost stemmed from the closing of a nuclear power plant after an attack. The other main costs included intelligence and police operations, the assigning of bodyguards to thousands of people and compensation for victims of the group's violence, the report said. ETA has killed more than 800 people since 1968 in its effort to establish an independent Basque state.   Renwick McLean (NYT)

headline: Europe Is Expected to Fine Members of Vitamin Cartel
abstract: European Commission will fine several chemical companies for operating cartel that fixed price of vitamin B4, animal growth stimulant; companies involved in price fixing include UCB of Belgium, BASF of Germany and Akzo Nobel of Netherlands; photo (M)

headline: World Briefing | Europe: Georgia: Towns Demand Electricity
abstract: Residents in the western towns of Kutaisi and Zestafoni gathered at government buildings to demand more electricity, the Itar-Tass news agency reported. About 200 people joined the protest in Zestafoni and 600 in Kutaisi, where the demonstrators stood outside Town Hall with placards reading ''Give Us Light!'' Electricity in the country has been sporadic since the collapse of the Soviet Union, with service available for just a few hours a day, if at all.   Sophia Kishkovsky (NYT)

headline: Taiwan Watches Its Economy Slip to China

headline: $500 Million Frozen in I.R.S. Crackdown in Doctors' Tax Case
abstract: Federal judge has temporarily frozen more than $500 million in assets owned by thousands of doctors and dentists who bought abusive tax shelters run by Xelan, San Diego investment company, according to Justice Department; action, one of largest of its kind, is rare and part of effort by Internal Revenue Service to clamp down on tax shelters it considers abusive; about 4,000 doctors and dentists across nation bought tax-reduction plans in recent years from Xelan, evading $420 million in taxes, not including interest and penalties; agents from FBI and IRS search Xelan's headquarters in San Diego; Xelan, founded and run by Dr L Donald Guess, San Diego dentist turned financial adviser, is subject of criminal investigation by federal grand jury in San Diego (M)

headline: The mobile medium is the new instant messaging tool
Farmers Being Moved Aside by China's Real Estate Boom
abstract: Fifth article in series The Great Divide, about widening gap between rural and urban Chinese, describes how world's fastest-growing economy is displacing farmers under two-tiered property system that favors city dwellers and development projects; photos; map; desperate farmers recently occupied Community Party compound in village of Sanchawan for five months, protesting seizure of land by officials of nearby city of Yulin; government sent police into village, firing tear gas and arresting farmers in fierce assault; typically one-sided negotiations allowed Yulin officials to cite obscure legal clause to offer only small sums to farmers, who are not allowed to own land because they still fall under collective system; urban dwellers by contrast may now buy or sell apartments or suburban villas as investments on way to fledgling middle class; as many as 70 million farmers have lost land in past decade as city officials push lucrative projects; arid landscape around Sanchawan, in Shaanxi Province, holds mythic place in Communist Party lore as refuge where Mao Zedong rebuilt Red Army in 1930's; it has long been fertile ground for peasant revolt; Sanchawan itself prospered along Yuxi River until gas, coal and oil discoveries made region hub of major pipeline project, and former Pres Jiang Zemin visited in 2002 to push faster development; village leaders, longtime firm Maoists, recall drafting petitions in vain effort to get redress (M)

headline: Rice University Computer Scientists Find a Flaw in Google's New Desktop Search Program
abstract: A Rice University computer scientist and two of his students have discovered a potentially serious security flaw in the desktop search tool for personal computers that was recently distributed by Google.    The glitch, which could permit an attacker to secretly search the contents of a personal computer via the Internet, is what computer scientists call a composition flaw -- a security weakness that emerges when separate components interact. ''When you put them together, out jumps a security flaw,'' said Dan Wallach, an assistant professor of computer science at Rice in Houston, who, with two graduate students, Seth Fogarty and Seth Nielson, discovered the flaw last month. ''These are subtle problems, and it takes a lot of experience to ferret out this kind of flaw,'' Professor Wallach said.

Still Deeply Divided, Nervous Kosovo Goes to Polls This Weekend
abstract: Five years after the United Nations took over the administration of Kosovo, the southern province of Serbia, the residents vote this weekend in an election that may be crucial in determining whether it becomes independent.    The vote for the 120-seat Parliament is the second since NATO troops forced Serbian security forces responsible for widespread atrocities out of the province in June 1999, making Kosovo an international protectorate. Half a decade later, Kosovo remains home to NATO's largest peacekeeping force, and the election has focused the minds of the ethnic Albanian majority, who make up over 90 percent of the 1.8 million people, most of whom are impatient for an end to the international control.

headline: The Stock? Whatever. Google Keeps On Innovating.
abstract: SIX months ago, Google was intriguing mainly as a financial phenomenon. Would its initial public offering come too early? Or too late? Would it succeed, signaling a broader tech revival? Or would it fail, deepening the gloom about Internet-based businesses?    Today, Google is still plenty interesting for financial reasons. In the weeks before its shares first went on sale in August, disparaging views about its prospects forced it to lower the target price to $85 a share from $135. By last week, its stock had more than doubled, to $190.64, giving it a market capitalization of $52 billion, more than Ford and General Motors combined.

headline: ALASKA AIRLINES REVISES 3RD-QUARTER NET INCOME DOWN
abstract: Alaska Airlines Inc. revised third-quarter net income lower by 7.9 percent because of a clerical error in accounting for a frequent-flier program. The revised third-quarter net income is $61 million, down from $66.2 million reported previously, the airline said in a Securities and Exchange Commission filing yesterday. The error reduced third-quarter net income for the parent company, Alaska Air Group of Seattle, to $74 million from $79.2 million. Alaska Airlines mistakenly recorded revenue from partners in its frequent-flier program who offer bonus miles as an incentive to use their products, said Caroline Boren, an Alaska Air spokeswoman.

headline: World Briefing | Europe: Turkey: 'Cologne Caliph' Denies Plot
abstract: Metin Kaplan, a militant cleric accused of trying to overthrow the secular system and create an Islamic state, told an Istanbul court he was not a terrorist. ''I am Muslim, and a Muslim cannot be a terrorist,'' he said in a courtroom discourse sprinkled with quotes from the Koran. Turkish authorities accused Mr. Kaplan, a Turk known as the Caliph of Cologne when he lived in that German city, of organizing a failed plot to crash an airplane into the Ataturk mausoleum during an independence day ceremony in 1998. Germany extradited him in October, after Turkey abolished the death penalty. After the one-day hearing, the court adjourned until April 2005.   Susan Sachs (NYT)

headline: Kerry and Bush Compete for the Role of Israel's Best Friend
abstract: Days before a tight presidential election focused on a handful of states with many Jewish voters, the campaigns of both President Bush and Senator John Kerry are trading charges over who would be the greater friend to Israel in the White House.    Interviews with aides to Mr. Kerry and Mr. Bush indicate, however, that their views on Israel and the difficulties of getting talks started with the Palestinians are starkly similar. Whoever is elected on Tuesday, American policy in the Middle East is unlikely to change markedly.

headline: S.E.C. MAY SUE TV AZTECA OVER DEBT TRANSACTION
abstract: TV Azteca, Mexico's second-largest broadcaster, said yesterday that the Securities and Exchange Commission had notified four executives, including the chairman, Ricardo Salinas Pliego, that it might sue the company over a debt transaction at its telephone unit, Unefon. The S.E.C. notified the executives on Aug. 27 of the investigation, which was started last February, Azteca Holdings, the company that controls TV Azteca, said in an S.E.C. filing. The S.E.C. began its investigation after Mr. Salinas and a business partner, Moises Saba, made a $218 million in profit when they purchased and sold Unefon debt, TV Azteca said in July. TV Azteca owns 46.5 percent of Unefon.

headline: Renovation:The challenge of changing the past
The End User: Letters to the technology editor
Hostage Takers Give Up After 18-Hour Standoff on Bus in Greece
abstract: Daylong hostage siege ends in Athens, Greece, after two gunmen who hijacked Athens-bound commuter bus surrender to authorities and release six remaining captives; police say men had no explosives, only rifle and pistol; they had earlier threatened to blow up bus; motives and backgrounds of gunmen remain unclear; police identify them as Albanians, but one who spoke on phone with authorities called himself Russian (M)

headline: To our readers
U.S. Oil Companies Face More Scrutiny
abstract: The role that American oil companies played in the United Nations' oil-for-food relief program is coming under greater scrutiny after a report by the chief arms inspector for the Central Intelligence Agency that disclosed how extensively Saddam Hussein abused oil profits.       The companies say their Iraqi oil purchases were not illegal or unknown in international oil markets.      Article, Page A11.

headline: With Interest : On rates, how much and how fast?
AMERICAN GREETINGS BUYS STAKE IN THE HATCHERY
abstract: American Greetings Corp buys major stake in Hatchery, which develops and produces family and children's entertainment, including films, videos and TV shows (S)

headline: As Suits End, Judge Says Deal Was Only Way to Resolve Fight
abstract: Vice Chancellor Leo Strine Jr, who is presiding judge in all lawsuits involving Oracle Corp's hostile takeover bid for PeopleSoft, says merger deal is only way to resolve disputes; photo (M)

headline: Correction
Retail in Review: More Bah Than Sis-Boom
abstract: Retail analysts say Christmas shopping season was good, but not great; analysts were assessing traditional bricks-and-mortar retail companies; Amazon.com says it set one-day record during holiday season of 2.8 mill1on orders; Wal-Mart Stores says sales rose 1 percent to 3 percent during seasons, smaller than originally predicted; Target says sales in December may have increased by as much as 5 percent; retail consultants NPD Group sticks to prediction of 3.4 percent increase; National Retail Federation maintains its prediction of 4.5 percent growth; MasterCard predicts 8.1 percent holiday sales growth for both online and gift card sales; Sharper Image says its gadgets did not produce expected windfall, and cuts its profit forecast significantly; photos (Market Place column) (M)

headline: DDI TO TRIM UP TO 175 JOBS AT ITS CALIFORNIA PLANT
abstract: DDI Corp, maker of electronic components for computer and telecommunications companies, will eliminate as many as 175 jobs, or about 7 percent of its workforce, at plant in Milpitas, Calif, to cut costs; is transferring work to lower-cost plants in Toronto and in Sterling, Va (S)

headline: Merck to Offer Big Bonuses to Executives if It Is Taken Over
abstract: Merck adopted the plan at a time when its stock is down sharply and its ability to thrive as an independent company is uncertain.

headline: COMPANY BRIEFS
abstract: Quality Dining, Mishawaka, Ind., an operator of Burger King restaurants, said that it had agreed to a buyout by five shareholders led by the chief executive, Daniel B. Fitzpatrick, who will take the company private. Shareholders will receive $3.20 for each share, the company said.    Whitney Holding Corp., New Orleans, a bank holding company, said that it had agreed to buy Destin Bancshares Inc., Destin, Fla. Terms were not disclosed.    Inamed Corp., Santa Barbara, Calif., a health care products company, and Genzyme Corp., Cambridge, Mass., a biotechnology company, said that the Food and Drug Administration had approved sales of Hylaform Plus, a treatment for facial wrinkles.    Xenogen Corp., Alameda, Calif., which develops pharmaceutical research technology, said that it had received a five-year global licensing deal to provide imaging technology to the drug maker Merck & Co., Whitehouse Station, N.J.

Flash flash
Embracing the index trackers

abstract: Maoist rebels in Nepal claim to have killed at least 10 soldiers and security officers in recent fighting (S)

headline: Briefs: Short strikes threatened at VW
China's 'Haves' Stir the 'Have Nots' to Violence
abstract: Article in series The Great Divide, on widening gap between China's rural poor and urban rich, examines full-scale riot in Wanzhou, one of many mass protests springing up around country; China is having more trouble maintaining social order than at any time since Tiananmen Square democracy movement in 1989; many protests are being touched off by government corruption, police abuse and inequality of riches accruing to powerful and well connected; protests are numerous, in part because they are small, local expressions of discontent over layoffs, land seizures, use of natural resources, ethnic tension, misspent state funds, forced immigration, unpaid wages or police killings; in Wanzhou, minor street quarrel between street porter and another man provoked thousands of people to demonstate in steets after second man boasted that he was ranking government official and beat porter with stick; such mass protests show how people with different causes can seize opportunity to press their grievances together; photos; map (L)

headline: World Business Briefing | Asia: Japan: Trade Surplus Rises
abstract: Japan's current account surplus grew 2.3 percent in August, to 1.45 trillion yen ($13.2 billion), in August from month year ago; imports rose 19.4 percent, to 3.76 trillion yen, while exports expanded 11.4 percent, to 4.57 billion yen (S)y

headline: Accounts
abstract: Advertising account changes noted (M)

headline: United's Pilots Are Offered 2 Ways to Cut Their Wages
abstract: United Airlines gives pilots' union two options to cut wages: accept 18 percent wage cuts or agree to smaller cuts but also accept significant changes in work rules; airline tells its pilots that it wants to be able to impose additional wage cuts after it leaves Chapter 11 bankruptcy, if it needs to do so; demands are part of United's bid for another round of $725 million in wage and benefit cuts from its unions (M)

headline: I.R.S. Audits More of the Wealthy and Fewer Small Companies
abstract: Internal Revenue Service is auditing significantly more wealthy individuals and large companies as it pursues crackdown on aggressive tax shelters, but it is increasingly shying away from scrutinizing smaller businesses; IRS releases new data showing number of high-income taxpayers audited in 2004 fiscal year rose 40 percent from previous year; about 195,200 individuals were audited by agency, up from nearly 139,400 in fiscal year 2003 (M)

headline: Israel Investigates Reports of Soldiers Abusing Corpses
abstract: The Israeli Army has ordered an investigation into allegations that soldiers in the West Bank photographed each other two years ago posing with the head of a suicide bomber.

headline: World Business Briefing | Europe: Sweden: Clothier's Profit Rises
abstract: Europe's largest clothing retailer, Hennes & Mauritz, says fiscal third-quarter profit rose 18 percent; net income rose to 1.59 billion kornor ($218 million); chief exec Rolf Eriksen comments; photo (S)

headline: Bangkok talks focus on endangered species
New Help for the Black Entrepreneur
abstract: At first blush, the figures are bleak. African-Americans account for 12 percent of the nation's population, but own only 4 percent of the small businesses. And the revenues of their businesses are on average less than one-tenth those of nonminority companies, according to the Census Bureau.    Other statistics, however, suggest that black Americans are more caught up in the entrepreneurial spirit than those numbers suggest, and even that they feel the entrepreneurial impulse more keenly than other ethnic groups.

headline: A Record Deal Now Looks Like a Good One, Too
abstract: Harry Macklowe's acquisition of General Motors Building in Manhattan for record-breaking $1.4 billion some 15 months ago is starting to look like a good investment; photo (M)

headline: Britain's Establishment Newspaper, Times of London, Goes Tabloid
abstract: Times of London, long voice of English establishment, is quietly going fully tabloid, dropping broadsheet version that has been published alongside new compact version for year; number of broadsheet papers across Europe have added tabloid-size editions or switched over entirely, seeking to bolster eroding circulations by appealing to new readers who prefer ease of smaller paper; photo (M)

headline: World Briefing | Asia: China: Taiwan Call For Talks Rejected
abstract: Zhang Mingqing, China's Taiwan Affairs Office spokesman, rejects efforts by Taiwan Pres Chen Shui-bian to revive talks between Chinese government and local Taiwan authorities; holds Chen is actively pursuing Taiwan independence; photo (S)

abstract: Jarvis' new chief executive Alan Lovell says company might raise money from new investor or be taken over; reports first-quarter loss of 288 million pounds (about $555 million (S)

headline: COMPANY BRIEFS
abstract: QUALCOMM INC., San Diego, the maker of mobile phone chips, said it had bought Trigenix Ltd., a British creator of graphics for handset screens, for $36 million in cash.    ALLIED WASTE INDUSTRIES, Scottsdale, Ariz., the trash hauler, said it planned to lay off 30 workers as part of a reorganization that will result in fourth-quarter expenses of as much as $10 million.    PILLOWTEX CORP., Kannapolis, N.C., the bankrupt maker of textile products, said it had reached a $3 million cash agreement to sell its Plant No. 1 complex to Manchester Real Estate and Construction, New York, a development firm. The deal is expected to be the starting point for an auction of the property.    LIBERTY MUTUAL GROUP, Boston, the insurer, said it had bought an office and retail building across the street from its headquarters for about $28 million.

headline: Starbucks Will Use Cups With 10% Recycled Paper
abstract: Starbucks will start stocking its stores with cups made with 10 percent recycled material starting in 2005 in hope of winning over customers who care about environment; is first time national food chain has incorporated recycled material into packaging that comes into direct contact with food or beverages (M)

headline: Another Loss at Interpublic
abstract: Interpublic Group of Companies reports seventh consecutive quarter of negative results, with third-quarter net loss of $578.4 million on revenue of $1.51 billion; results include $608.4 million in charges and other special items, bulk of which reflects writedown in value of some of more than 270 agencies acquired during acquisition spree of late 1990's (M)

headline: Dollar's Fall Tests Nerve of Asia's Central Bankers
abstract: Many investors are concerned that investors in Asia will pare their US holdings because of slumping dollar, causing currency to plunge much further and setting off round of interest rate increases in US that could send global economy into tailspin; Japan's total stockpile of foreign currency, at $817 billion, is largest in world, but China, which owns about $600 billion, is catching up fast; Asian investors want US to protect value of their investments by adopting policies that would slow or reverse dollar's decline; graph; photo (M)

headline: COMPANY BRIEFS
abstract: WENDY'S INTERNATIONAL INC., Dublin, Ohio, the restaurant chain, said it had named Ian Rowden to direct the company's advertising, replacing the chief marketing officer, Don Calhoon.    PATTERSON-UTI ENERGY INC., Snyder, Tex., an operator of oil and natural-gas drilling rigs, said that it would buy the United States onshore rigs of Key Energy Services, Midland, Tex., for about $62 million.    RCN CORP., Princeton, N.J., a cable television, phone and Internet service provider, said that it had won court approval of a plan to exit bankruptcy by trading $1.2 billion in unsecured debt for all its equity.

headline: Pressure Said to Be Building for Ouster of Marsh's Chief
abstract: Marsh & McLennan directors, under pressure from regulators, move to force resignation of Jeffrey W Greenberg, company's chief executive; some of company's 10 independent directors contact New York Atty Gen Eliot Spitzer in effort to settle civil lawsuit accusing Marsh of rigging bids and fixing prices for insurance; Spitzer indicates that negotiations may begin only with departure of Greenberg, whom he accuses of misleading him in early stages of investigation into corruption in insurance industry; Greenberg photo (M)

headline: Is Kaiser the Future of American Health Care?
abstract: Article on Kaiser Permanente, huge California-based health maintenance organization considered leader in efforts to increase quality of care and spend health dollars more wisely; management of care and $3-billion initiative to use information technology to improve clinical care and streamline operations explained; Dr Victor Silvestre, who gave up frustrations of sole practice to join Kaiser, comments, as do Dr Francis J Crosson, director of Kaiser physicians, and chief executive George Halvorson; photos (M)

headline: Tyco to Sell Undersea Cable Unit to an Indian Telecom Company
abstract: Tyco International will sell its undersea cable business, Tyco Global Network, to Indian telecommunications company Videsh Sanchar Nigam for $130 million; spent $2.5 billion laying over 37,000 miles of undersea cable; reports fourth-quarter net income of $454 million, compared with year-earlier loss of $297 million (M)
