World Briefing | Europe: Russia: Rail Link To Georgian Region Is Shut
abstract: Russia, making good on threat to suspend trade with separatist Abkhazia, Georgia, over disputed presidential election, closes rail line between Moscow and Abkhazia capital Sukhumi; impoverished region relies heavily on sale of food to Russia (S)

headline: World Business Briefing | Europe: Germany: Retail Sales Decline
abstract: German Federal Statistics Office reports 3.7 percent decline in retail sales in October, largest decline in five months (S)

headline: Martha Stewart Reports to Prison, Ducking Cameras
abstract: Martha Stewart beat the news media trailing her every move  at their own game today by announcing herself that she had checked into prison in West Virginia.

headline: Time Warner Said No Deal and Then Tried to Deal
abstract: LAST month, Richard D. Parsons, Time Warner's chairman and chief executive, appeared to accept defeat graciously after losing the battle for control of Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer to a Sony-led consortium of investors. He even issued a statement saying that he had withdrawn Time Warner's bid because he could not reach a deal with MGM ''at a price that would have represented a prudent use of our growing financial capacity'' and that the company approaches ''every potential acquisition with strict financial discipline.''    The real story behind Mr. Parsons' retreat, however, appears to be slightly more complicated, to put it mildly. In fact, it was hardly a retreat at all.

headline: Tributes for Arafat Focus on Efforts for Palestinian State
abstract: From the Vatican to the Palestinian refugee camps of Jordan, tributes poured in today for Yasir Arafat, a man regarded as an international leader by many and a terrorist by others.

headline: Fannie Mae's Regulator to Review Pay Packages of Ex-Officials
abstract: Fannie Mae says regulator Office of Federal Housing Enterprise Oversight will review benefits company plans to pay its former top officers Franklin D Raines and J Timothy Howard after their ouster last week; regulator could seek to block compensation; Ofheo is probing whether any changes were made to two executives' termination packages since they were originally agreed upon; Raines is eligible for monthly pension payments of $114,393 for life, or about $1.4 million per year; is also owed $8.7 million in deferred compensation; Howard would be eligible for $36,071 in monthly pension payments and deferred compensation of $4 million; Rep Barney Frank says payments are not appropriate; photo (M)

abstract: Joenia Batista de Carvalho, first Indian woman to become lawyer in Brazil, has emerged as one of most effective advocates of indigenous cause in Brazil; photo (M)

abstract: Cingular Wireless plans to cut about 10 percent of its work force, or 7,000 jobs, as result of its purchase of AT&T Wireless; says most of cuts will come in administrative and managerial positions that were duplicated as result of $41 billion buyout (M)

abstract: Colombia's manufacturing output rose 1.44 percent higher in October than year earlier; retail sales rose 7.8 percent in October from year earlier as economy grew at its fastest pace in about decade (S)

headline: Blast Kills 5 In Jeep Used By Vote Board
abstract: Roadside explosion in Paktia Province in Afghanistan kills five people traveling in election commission jeep; deaths serve as reminder that insurgents remain deadly threat to election and other government officials, especially in southern and southeastern parts of country; it is not clear if explosion was aimed at election vehicle, although gray jeeps have been targets before; spokesman for Taliban takes credit for latest blast; with 20 percent of votes counted, Pres Hamid Karzai is leading easily, with 61.3 percent of vote; photo (M)

headline: To Supply China, South African Mines Want More Trains
abstract: Growing demand from China promises lucrative future for South Africa's iron ore and manganese companies if they can find way to move metals more than 500 miles from inland mines on edge of Kalahari Desert to coastal ports; South Africa's government-run rail company does not have enough capacity and has been slow to do anything to improve situation; mining companies like Kumba Resources, Africa's largest iron ore producer, are so frustrated that they are even offering to buy their own trains; China imported 157 million tons of iron ore in 2003, and is expected to import 205 million tons this year; South Africa's share of Chinese market has fallen to 4 percent from about 12 percent 10 years ago; photo (M)

headline: Two Anchormen Down. One More to Go?
abstract: Peter Jennings will be last broadcast news anchorman now that Dan Rather has decided to leave in March and Tom Brokaw departs next week; if Jennings's ratings to do not rise after rookies replace his longtime rivals, he may find ABC executives pushing him out (M)

headline: Foes of Death Penalty Making Gradual Gains in Africa
abstract: Edmary Mpagi, who spent 18 years on Uganda's death row before being acquitted of crime, is part of growing movement to eliminate death penalty in Africa; 15 years ago, only Cape Verde Islands did not have death penalty; now 10 countries have outlawed practice and 10 more have abolished its use; proponents of death penalty include religious leaders, particularly Islamic courts, and citizens who fear violent criminal activity; Uganda, which has 417 people on death row, supports harsh penalties, but has not carried out execution since March 2003; Uganda Citizen's Rescue activist Godfrey Ssebuwufu supports abolishing capital punishment; investigates cases of those individuals on death row and seeks to have verdicts overturned; Edmary Mpagi was released as result of Ssebuwufu's diligence to save innocent lives; photo (M)

headline: In sound quality, price, not size, tells the story
COMPANY BRIEFS
abstract: PURETUNES.COM, a defunct online service that sold songs through the Internet, agreed to pay the recording industry $10.5 million to end a lawsuit accusing it of falsely claiming to be a legal file-sharing site.    THE CARNIVAL CORP., Miami, the cruise line, said yesterday that it would buy back as much as $1 billion in stock and increase its dividend 20 percent.    COUSINS PROPERTIES, Atlanta, and CarrAmerica Realty Corporation, Washington, sold a 10-story office building in Tysons Corner, Va., to an affiliate of ING Realty Partners, New York, for $59.3 million.    THE POTLATCH CORP., Spokane, Wash., a forest products company, said yesterday that its directors had approved the return of $150 million to shareholders after the company's successful tender offer for $250 million in senior subordinated notes.

headline: Fired Flight Attendant Finds Blogs Can Backfire
abstract: Until two weeks ago, Ellen Simonetti worked as a flight attendant for Delta Air Lines, doing her best to project the image of a stewardess from a bygone era. ''In the past people expected flight attendants to be young and attractive,'' Ms. Simonetti, a 29-year old blonde, said from her home in Austin, Tex. ''Maybe I represent the flight attendants of the past.''    But it is Ms. Simonetti's very 21st-century activities that she says prompted Delta management to ground her, suspending her from flying in September and then firing her a month later.

headline: Charge hits share price at Corning
Expert in Martha Stewart Case Acquitted on Perjury Charges
abstract: An ink expert who testified in the Martha Stewart case last spring, has been acquitted in federal court on perjury charges related to analyzing evidence in the case.

abstract: Saovapa Devahastin, winner of Thailand's first Miss Spinster beauty contest, and growing number of successful professional women are challenging not only traditional imperative of marriage and family but also what they see as delicate egos of Thai men; photo (M)

abstract: Iranian officials hint that they sped up their enrichment of uranium in past year to put Iran in better position to negotiate with West; rare admission is made by Sirous Nasseri, member of Iranian negotiating team with Germany, France and Britain over its nuclear program (M)

abstract: Michelle Slatalla Online Shopper column says growing number of Internet merchants are making it easy for gift givers to shop online without it looking as if they did; roundup of sites offering interesting gift ideas; photo; drawing (M)

headline: Nothing Ventured, Everything Gained
abstract: New trading tactic that gives a hedge fund voting stake while holding no economic interest has emerged in takeover fight for King Pharmaceuticals, generic drug maker, by its larger rival, Mylan Laboratories; Perry Corp, New York-based hedge fund, owns 7 million shares of King, hoping to profit from spread between price of Mylan offered for King shares, $16.49, and King's actual share price, $12.42 at close of trading on Dec 1; if deal is completed, Perry stands to make over $28 million; Perry appears to have set up sophisticated swap trade with Bear Stearns and Goldman Sachs so that it now controls about 10 percent of Mylan's votes, with limited or no exposure to fluctuations in Mylan's share price; move, which leaves Perry as largest, if indirect, shareholder of Mylan, could help ensure that Mylan receives enough shareholder votes to approve deal for King at time when next-biggest shareholder of Mylan, Carl C Icahn, is trying to block merger; chart; photo (M)

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: Congress May Try to Tackle Price of Health Coverage  Regardless of who wins the presidential election, Congress will soon take up the idea of lowering the cost of health insurance by shielding employers from the most expensive medical cases, lawmakers and lobbyists say.

headline: Haitian and U.N. Forces Arrest Militant Suspects and Seek Arms
abstract: Haitian police officers and United Nations soldiers fan out in determined effort to quell week of violence, arresting people suspected of being militants and searching for weapons; marches that began on Sept 30 to commemorate anniversary of coup that first forced Pres Jean-Bertrand Aristide from power in 1991 have turned increasingly violent (M)

headline: A Tea Party, and All Boomers Are Invited
abstract: Soaring tea sales in US discussed; photos; American consumers last year spent $5 billion on tea, five times as much as decade ago, though still far below $20 billion spent on coffee; companies like Starbucks, with its Tazo brand, and Republic of Tea market specialty teas to huge potential market of baby boomers; photos (M)

headline: Japan Exports Hit Record, Easing Concerns of Slowdown
abstract: Japanese exports hit record high in October, helping to ease concerns about slowdown in important sector of economy (M)

abstract: United Parcel Service is buying direct control of services it has jointly run with Chinese delivery service Sinotrans Group; deal is valued at $100 million (S)

headline: Online Award to Times Writer
abstract: New York Times on Web wins award from Online News Association for commentary by Nicholas D Kristof, Op-Ed columnist for New York Times; association cites Kristof's columns last year in Times about Arctic National Wildlife Refuge and his multimedia presentations on NYTimes.com from Arctic as well as China, Cambodia and Iran; Dan Gillmor, who writes his 'e-Journal' for SiliconValley.com, is given commentary award for Web sites with fewer than 500,000 monthly visitors; awards for general excellence go to BBCNews.com and VenturaCountyStar.com in California; other winners noted (M)

headline: World Business Briefing | Europe: Britain: Shell To Postpone Meeting
abstract: Royal Dutch/Shell Group postpones annual meeting, and vote on corporate restructuring, from April to June 2005 because possible reserves revision may affect previous earnings statements; would be fifth revision this year (S)

Disney Is Tailoring New Park to Fit Hong Kong Sensitivities
abstract: Walt Disney Co is taking series of steps to address local cultural sensitivities as it prepares to open Hong Kong Disneyland in late 2005; new theme park will include local food and music and provide services not only in English but in two Chinese languages; Disney's president-chief operating officer Robert A Iger comments; photo (M)

headline: Witness at Fraud Trial Says He Was a Conduit for Data
abstract: A former associate of Anthony Elgindy told jurors yesterday that he passed confidential information from an F.B.I. agent to the online stock adviser, who was ''pretty excited'' to get the illegal tips.    Derrick Cleveland, 38, who pleaded guilty in the case and is a key government witness, testified that he was a conduit for information from a former F.B.I. agent, Jeffrey Royer, to Mr. Elgindy. Mr. Cleveland said he referred to Mr. Royer in conversations with Mr. Elgindy as ''Jeff, my F.B.I. friend.''

headline: World Briefing | Middle East: Israel: Troops To Pull Back For Palestinian Vote
abstract: Israel's Defense Min Shaul Mofaz announces troop withdrawal from Palestinian towns for 72 hours around Palestinian election (S)

headline: Oracle Fires Top PeopleSoft Executives
abstract: The Oracle Corporation fired PeopleSoft's co-president and chief financial officer, Kevin T. Parker, and three other top executives, a day after assuming control of the rival software maker in a $10.3 billion takeover.     Oracle terminated W. Phillip Wilmington, co-president; Nanci Caldwell, chief marketing officer; and James Shaughnessy, general counsel, effective yesterday, according to a regulatory filing. Oracle, which is based in Redwood City, Calif., named its co-presidents, Charles E. Phillips Jr. and Safra A. Catz, and its chief financial officer, Harry L. You, to the PeopleSoft posts.

headline: Wide Format or Standard, Shutterbugs Get a Choice
abstract: Digital cameras display your pictures on any TV or video monitor that has video inputs (which means nearly all of them). The near-square (4:3) proportions of standard digital-camera images nicely fill most conventional video screens, which have the same proportions. But if you view those images on a wide (16:9) screen, the image fills only three-quarters of the screen, leaving unwanted black bars on either side.     Fujifilm's Finepix F810 solves that problem by giving you a choice of shooting your pictures in either 4:3 or 16:9 format. The wide format also offers possibilities for composing pictures, even to photographers without wide-screen televisions.

headline: Frequent-Flier Miles Can Vanish Into the Air
abstract: Article on secret audits conducted by airlines that can result in frequent fliers losing their elite status, flight coupons and all their accumulated mileage; focuses on Michael Sommer, technology consultant from Jacksonville, Fla, who lost all his frequent-flier miles when United Airlines conducted secret audit; photo (M)

The Dollar Falls, but the Pain and the Gains Vary
abstract: The dollar hit another record low against the euro on Thursday, and sank against other major currencies, in what analysts said was a growing unease about the ballooning trade and budget deficits in the United States.    The euro briefly traded at $1.35 against the dollar, with traders around the world betting that the dollar would fall further next year.

headline: Briefs: War crimes suspect issues call to surrender
A Widely Used Arthritis Drug Is Withdrawn
abstract: Merck drug company says it will stop selling its widely popular arthritis pain medication Vioxx because new study found it doubled patients' risk of heart attack and strokes; this is largest drug recall in history as measured by sales, which were $2.5 billion last year; new study was examining whether Vioxx prevented colon polyps, but Merck quickly ended trial after results of study showed that drug led to heart attacks and strokes; risk is small--15 cases of heart attack, stroke or blood clots per thousand patients over three years compared with 7.5 such events per thousand taking placebo; Merck tells federal regulators it halted trial because data was so unambiguous; previous studies linking Vioxx with heart attacks and strokes were not definitive; Vioxx represents 11 percent of Merck's revenue last year; its stock plunges 27 percent on news; photo; chart (L)

headline: Militants' Bomb Misfires, Hitting School Bus; Pupil Dies
abstract: One Iraqi eighth grader was killed and six others wounded Saturday morning in Mosul when insurgents trying to detonate a roadside bomb in the path of a routine American patrol misfired and hit a school bus full of children, the military said.    American troops identified and fired at insurgents nearby, killing one, military officials said, following the 7:45 a.m. attack in Mosul, in northern Iraq.

headline: COMMERCIAL REAL ESTATE
abstract: Jamestown, a private real estate company, has agreed to invest $300 million in the General Motors Building in Manhattan, which was acquired by Harry Macklowe 15 months ago. [C5.]    Sales totaling $750 million have revived hopes in the Mission Bay area of San Francisco. [C5.]

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: Importing Canadian Drugs Might Not Lower Prices  Many economists and health care experts say that importing drugs from countries like Canada that control their prices would do little to solve the problem of expensive drugs in the United States.     The nonpartisan Congressional Budget Office has said that allowing Canadian drug imports would have a negligible effect on costs. And drug makers say they would simply reduce their shipments to distributors in the countries supplying the drugs. [Page A1.]    No Deal on Russia-China Pipeline  Russia and China failed to seal an agreement on a proposed gas pipeline from eastern Siberia to northern China. President Vladimir V. Putin, left, of Russia visited China this week amid hopes that a deal was near. Instead, the two countries signed a loose agreement that left the door open to future talks. Many said the two countries remain wary neighbors. [C3.]    Layoffs and Write-Down at Sprint  Sprint plans to lay off 700 sales representatives and write down the value of its network to reflect the eroding market for traditional phone services. The company has already eliminated 7,500 positions this year. [C2.]    Delta Expects a Large Loss  Delta Air Lines said that it expected to lose as much as $675 million for the third quarter, renewing speculation that it could seek bankruptcy protection later this month. [C12.]    Greenspan Eases Fears on Oil  Alan Greenspan said higher oil costs had hurt the gross domestic product this year, but he said the long-term outlook for global oil supplies was reassuring. Crude oil prices climbed 17 cents, to $54.93 a barrel. [C4.]    British Bankers Face Extradition  A judge ruled that three British bankers can be extradited to the United States to face charges of wire fraud related to off-balance-sheet dealings with Enron. [C3.]    Retail Sales Surged in September  A large increase in September retail sales and gains in producer prices indicated stronger economic growth. But a surprisingly soft reading on consumer confidence showed that high oil prices were a threat. [C3.]    Economic Reports Lift Stocks  Stocks rebounded as a retail sales report showed that higher oil prices were not keeping consumers from spending. The Standard & Poor's 500-stock index rose 4.91 points, to 1,108.20, and the Dow Jones industrial average rose 38.93 points, to 9,933.38. [C4.]    Judge to Decide Fate of Oracle Bid  The two-week trial to decide the fate of Oracle's $7.7 billion hostile tender offer for PeopleSoft moved to the judge, who said the parties had moved closer together. [C2.]    Warning Labels on Antidepressants  The Food and Drug Administration ordered pharmaceutical companies to add strong warnings to antidepressants, saying the drugs can cause suicidal thoughts and actions in children and teenagers. [A9.]    Inquiry on Bonds at Bear Stearns  Bear Stearns said it had received subpoenas from federal investigators looking into its municipal bond business. [C12.]    Bitumen Price-Fixing Charges  The European Commission plans to file charges against several companies for fixing the price of bitumen, an oil-based product used in making houses and road surfaces. [C3.]    Flu Vaccine Not Salvageable  None of the flu vaccine made by Chiron that was quarantined in Britain is safe for Americans to use, federal health officials said. [A14]

headline: US Airways' Deal Requires Bankruptcy Exit by June 30
abstract: US Airways outlines $140 million aircraft leasing and financing deal with GE Capital Aviation Services that would require airline to meet swift set of deadlines and emerge from bankruptcy protection by June 30; at same time, Association of Flight Attendants says it has sent out strike ballots to its membership; union is threatening walkouts at US Airways and other airlines to protest their efforts to set aside contracts and seek court-ordered wage and benefit cuts (M)

abstract: A suicide bomber killed himself, an American woman and a 12-year-old girl and wounded five people on a busy tourist street here on Saturday afternoon, apparently in an attempt to attack international peacekeepers.     Three soldiers and two children were wounded, police and military officials said.

headline: World Briefing | Asia: China: Officials Caught In Crackdown
abstract: A crackdown on misuse of government funds had led to arrests or reprimands of more than 750 officials in recent months, state news media reported this week. Prime Minister Wen Jiabao has led an effort to toughen government accounting standards and recover missing revenue, estimated at $3.5 billion in 2003. The auditing program, which has received heavy publicity in state-run media, is expected to expand in scope next year.   Joseph Kahn (NYT)

abstract: Dividing up revenues generated by soaring sales of DVD's becomes contentious issue in negotiations over new three-year film and television contract between producers, represented by Alliance of Motion Picture and Television Producers, and combined bargaining teams of Screen Actors Guild and American Federation of Radio and Television Artists; dispute has raised possibility of actors' strike; consumers, who in 1996 spent $6 billion buying VHS tapes and $9.2 billion renting them, will spend $24.5 billion buying and renting DVD's and VHS tapes in 2004, and nearly 80 percent of that will go to studios through their home entertainment division; studios have refused to change home video residual formula for creative talent guilds, which puts only fraction of pennies of each DVD sale into hands of most actors, writers and directors; infighting arises in Screen Actors Guild over Robert Pisano, its chief negotiator and national executive director, because he also sits on board and is shareholder of online DVD rental company Netflix; photo; graph (M)

headline: World Briefing | Americas: Colombia: Rebels Reject Hostages Deal
abstract: Marxist rebels rejected President √Ålvaro Uribe's offer to call off the extradition of Ricardo Palmera, the most senior guerrilla commander in government custody, to the United States on cocaine-trafficking charges if the rebels released 63 kidnapping victims, including 3 American Defense Department contractors. Raul Reyes, a spokesman for the rebel group, the Revolutionary Armed Forces of Colombia, told a local television station that Mr. Uribe's offer amounted to blackmail. Instead, the group has proposed exchanging the hostages for thousands of jailed guerrillas.   Juan Forero (NYT)

headline: Bird Flu Spread Tied to Ducks, Not Humans
abstract: Tests on the family of a Thai girl who died of avian influenza last month suggest that it was unlikely that the virus had mutated there into a form that spread easily among humans, the World Health Organization said yesterday.    The organization also issued a separate warning that it appeared that healthy ducks could become heavily infected with the A(H5N1) strain of the virus, which has killed about two-thirds of the 40 people infected in Thailand and Vietnam this year and has led to the slaughter of millions of chickens in Asia. It warned residents of Asian countries where the disease exists not to keep ducks as pets, let them into houses or drink from ponds they use.

headline: Greenspan Sees No Rise Soon for the Dollar

headline: Dutch Police Seize 2 in Raid on Terror Cell After a Siege
abstract: Daylong seige of Hague apartment by police ends with arrest of two North African men suspected of involvement in Islamist terrorist activities; arrests and recent killing of Dutch filmmaker Theo van Gogh, who was outspoken critic of conservative Islam, add to concerns that Netherlands has become home to international terrorist network; alleged evidence of international terrorists working in Netherlands described; Syrian man is discussed as possible link between van Gogh's slaying, foiled plot to attack government installations and threats to behead Dutch Parliament member Geert Wilders (M)

headline: Russian Cellphone Carrier Faces Tax Claim
abstract: VimpelCom, second-largest cellphone company in Russia, receives first notice for $157 million in back taxes, sending its stock plunging; company confirms it received preliminary audit from Russian tax ministry stating it owes 4.4 billion rubles ($157.8 million) in taxes for 2001; company says it will fight claim; analysts and investors say tax claim is probably latest installment in bitter dispute between Mikhail M Fridman, high-profile VimpelCom shareholder, and Leonid D Reiman, leader of Russia's newly renamed Information Technology Ministry; fight is over 25 percent stake that Fridman's holding company, Alfa Group, bought last year in MegaFon, another rapidly growing Russian company and nation's third-largest mobile phone operator; MegaFon is majority owned by Telecominvest; Reiman is widely believed to own stake in Telecominvest and to be waging harassment campaign against Fridman seeking to get him to relinquish his stake in MegaFon--all of which Reiman vehemently denies; photos (M)

headline: Zambia Apologizes for Founder's '97 Arrest
abstract: Zambia's government publicly apologized Saturday to its founding father, Kenneth Kaunda, for arresting and jailing him on trumped-up charges in 1997.

headline: Prospects Brighten for Maker of Nasal Flu Vaccine
abstract: It would seem a drug executive's dream come true. A week ago Thursday, the secretary of health and human services summoned the top officials of MedImmune to his office in Washington to ask their help in dealing with the nation's flu vaccine shortage.       David M. Mott, MedImmune's chief executive, said that if the company scrambled it could triple its planned production and turn out more than three million doses of its vaccine, the nasal anti-flu spray FluMist. The spray sells for as much as $23.50 for a once-a-season dose, compared with about $10 for a flu shot.

headline: Europe Rejects Microsoft's Bid to Preserve Bundling Plan
abstract: Europe's Court of First Instance rejects Microsoft's objections and orders it to offer version of its Windows operating system without its software for playing digital music and movies on personal computers; ruling only applies to Europe, but it represents first time since antitrust challenges to Microsoft began in 1990's that company will be forced to alter its software products and features with Windows; basic operations of more than 90 percent of world's personal computers are controlled by Microsoft's Windows program; ruling by Judge Bo Vesterdorf means that sanctions imposed by European Commission in March will now take effect RealNetworks, leading maker of media player software, describes ruling as step toward greater competition in software market (M)

abstract: Spanish-language media company Televisa says its third-quarter profit doubled to $126 million on 29 percent increase in sales (S)

headline: Despite Wal-Mart's Edict, Radio Tags Will Take Time
abstract: New radio tagging technology Wal-Mart had demanded that its top suppliers adopt by start of 2005 is not yet ready to meet needs of either Wal-Mart or its suppliers; most suppliers have yet to figure out inexpensive ways to automate printing and application of tags, which broadcast snippet of code identifying goods to which they are attached in response to query signals from scanning devices called readers; read rates are improving, but no one who uses technology has systems that can reliably read data 100 percent of time; Wal-Mart says rate is about 60 percent in its stores; data currently is not integrated well enough with other technology to initiate changes in manufacturing or shipping schedules that could offer enough savings to justify investment; analysts say suppliers are cooperating with Wal-Mart, while, as much as possible, delaying investment; photos (M)

headline: Jens and Vita, but Molli? Danes Favor Common Names
abstract: Denmark's Law on Personal Names is designed to protect children from being burdened by preposterous or silly names; under law, choosing first and last name for child is subject to approval by Ministry of Ecclesiastical Affairs and Ministry of Family and Consumer Affairs; people expecting children can choose pre-approved name from government list of mostly Western European and English names; some ethnic names have recently been added; photos (M)

headline: Putin Says He Will Accept the Will of the Ukrainian People
abstract: President Vladimir V. Putin on Monday adjusted his hard-line position on the presidential election in Ukraine, saying that he would accept the choice of the Ukrainian people and would work with whichever candidate wins the second runoff election, now scheduled for Dec. 26.    Mr. Putin effectively conceded that his unequivocal choice for the Ukrainian presidency, Prime Minister Viktor F. Yanukovich, might not prevail in the repeat vote, leaving him few options but to accept a victory by the opposition candidate, Viktor A. Yushchenko.

headline: Honda and Regulators Meet on Engine Fires in S.U.V.'s

headline: Hiring Spurt Helps Sustain U.S. Growth
abstract: Latest Federal Reserve regional survey shows that consumer spending accelerated in October as hiring led to 0.6 percent rise in incomes, biggest in five months; Commerce Department reports 0.7 percent hike in consumer purchases; spending on durable goods, adjusted for inflation, rose 0.1 percent and spending on nondurable goods rose 0.3 percent; spending on services rose 0.4 percent for second month; construction spending held steady at $1.1 trillion; Institute for Supply Management reports factory index rose to 57.8 percent in November from 56.8 percent; orders index rose to 61.5 percent from October's 58.3 percent; Federal Reserve policy makers reportedly are expected to raise overnight bank lending rate by 0.25 percent, to 2.25 percent at next meeting on December 14; chart; photo (M)

headline: Chinese Automaker Plans Assembly Line in Malaysia
abstract: China's Chery Automobile Co plans to assemble cars in Malaysia; move is likely to generate new controversy about Chinese protection of intellectual property; Chery has been at center of disputes with General Motors and Volkswagen over whether it has copied their vehicle designs, accusations that Chery has repeatedly denied; GM responds within hours to news of Chery's Malaysian plans by saying it will fight to prevent violations of its intellectual property rights wherever they might occur; Alado Corp, with links to BSA International, says it will import and later assemble Chery QQ subcompact car and Chery B14 minivan in partnership with Chery; vehicles are to be sold in Malaysia and distributed across Southeast Asia; photo (M)

headline: Support for U.S. in Food Dispute
abstract: World Trade Organization rules that European Union's system of registering and protecting regional food names is exclusionary, backing complaints by US and Australia and opening door for growers of Idaho potatoes and Florida oranges to register products in European Union; ruling means Anheuser-Busch Budweiser or Bud beer names, registered in 20 of 25 European Union nations, cannot be challenged by Budejovicky Budvar, Czech brewer that claims name as translation of Budvar; will also allow US food companies like Kraft Foods and General Mills to market trademarked foods that have names identical to European Union's geographical indications (M)

headline: Taiwan Leader Proposes Talks With China's New Chief
abstract: President Chen Shui-bian of Taiwan called today for the opening of peace talks with mainland China in a conciliatory overture following President Hu Jintao's consolidation of power last month in Beijing.

Peace Effort in Northern Ireland Falls Short
abstract: British Prime Min Tony Blair and Irish leader Bertie Ahern, meeting in Belfast, admit they have so far failed to restore power-sharing government in Northern Ireland; report two sides cannot agree on verifiable means to destroy last IRA arms caches; Blair says he is weary but not downhearted about snag over photographing weapons destruction (M)

headline: New Scrutiny of Drugs in Vioxx's Family
abstract: Removal of Merck's arthritis painkiller Vioxx from market because of studies showing it increased risk of heart attacks and strokes leads to more scrutiny of other drugs in widely prescribed group known as COX-2 inhibitors; Pfizer, in surprising stance, says it its looking into whether its somewhat similar drug, Celebrex, may actually help prevent heart attacks; admits evidence so far is scant and inconclusive; safety concerns could delay approval of two other drugs in advanced stages of development, Merck's Arcoxia and Novartis's Prexige, and others further behind; many experts say Celebrex is somewhat different chemically from Vioxx and has not shown signs of increasing cardiovascular risk; graphs of COX-2 inhibitors on market and in pipeline; photo (M)

headline: A.I.G. Will Accept Monitor and Pay $80 Million to Close Inquiries
abstract: American International Group agrees to accept independent monitor and pay about $80 million to settle probes into sale of insurance that was used by companies to manipulate their earnings; imposition of monitor is unusual and represents remarkable concession by company that until recently had reputation for standing up to regulators; makes settlement offer to Securities and Exchange Commission and reaches agreement in principle with Justice Department (M)

headline: Afghan vote counting begins, but with delays
Sale of I.B.M. PC Unit Isa Bridge Between Cultures
abstract: sale of i.b.m. pc unit is a bridge between companies and cultures** IBM sale of personal computer business to Lenovo of China reflects both rising global aspirations of corporate China, and recognition by prototypical American multinational that its own future lies further up economic ladder, in technology services, software and large computers that power corporate networks and Internet; $1.75-billion deal calls for IBM personal computer business to continue to be based in US, with IBM taking 18.9 percent stake in Lenovo, which is based in Beijing but plans headquarters in New York; IBM is acknowledging that its future in China may be best served by close partnership with local market leader, particularly one partly owned by Chinese government; Lenovo chief executive will be Stephen M Ward Jr, now IBM senior vice president; Lenova president Yang Yuanqing to become chairman; Ward and other IBM senior management in PC division, including Fran O'Sullivan, will join Lenovo; photo; IBM PC business has development headquarters in Raleigh and employs about 10,000 people worldwide, about forty percent in China; company moved personal computers from hobbyist market into mainstream in 1981 but lost leadership to nimbler players; hasty entry into business led to strategic error of using outside suppliers for crucial microprocessing and software, which helped Intel and Microsoft to great success (M)

abstract: Two international election officials appointed by United Nations complete first review of 43 complaints of voting irregularities from 15 Afghan presidential candidates, clearing way for millions of ballots from Oct 9 election to be counted (S)

headline: Internet Access, Delivered From Above
abstract: Jeff Thompson, chief operating officer of TowerStream, says company will challenge phone companies for high-speed Internet business customers in New York metropolitan area by delivering fast, cheap wireless service; many experts say this kind of aerial system could uncork bottleneck phone companies pose through their control of wire from switching stations to homes and offices; TowerStream, with 700 customers in five cities, is most active player in emerging industry that sells technology known as WiMax, or worldwide interoperability for microwave access; WiMax delivers broadband Internet links through fixed antennas that send and get signals across entire cities; photos (M)

headline: Big Hong Kong Real Estate Offering Must Be Postponed
abstract: 67-year-old public housing tenant forces Hong Kong government and three of world's largest financial institutions to postpone indefinitely a $2.73 billion real estate offering; Hong Kong officials, after five days of nearly constant meetings, announce that they will withdraw offering for giant real-estate investment trust because of lawsuit filed by Lo Siu-lan, tenant, who lives on $427 a month in government welfare assistance and says she never learned to write; HSBC, UBS and Goldman Sachs were underwriters for deal; it would have been world's largest initial public offering for a property trust; offering attracted bids from 503,000 of city's 6.8 million people (M)

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: Lobbying Frenzy Generates A Grab Bag of Tax Breaks  It was the biggest free-for-all in corporate lobbying that Congress has seen in nearly 20 years, and its final product was a tax bill, passed by the Senate on Monday, that offers giveaways to corporate titans like General Electric, shopping mall developers, wine distributors and even restaurants.    In Washington, the political logic of the process was in many ways predictable. What was not predictable was how brazen the frenzy would become. [Page A1.]    F.C.C. Fines Fox for Indecency  The Federal Communications Commission said it would fine 169 Fox television stations a total of $1.18 million for breaking indecency rules by showing an episode of ''Married by America.'' [C9.]    Federal Crackdown on Spyware  The Federal Trade Commission is going after spyware, bits of computer code that install themselves on the computers of Internet users to track or disrupt their online activities. Lydia Parnes of the commission's Bureau of Consumer Protection, left, announced a suit against one spyware distributor. [C10.]    Chiron Faces Government Inquiry  The Justice Department has started an investigation of Chiron, the company whose flu vaccine factory was shut down last week. [A14.]    Stocks Close Little Changed  The market opened lower but rebounded as oil prices eased. The Dow Jones industrial average fell 4.79 points, to 10,077.18, while the Standard & Poor's 500-stock index dropped 2.55 points, to 1,121.84. [C11.]    Medtronic to Pay $400 Million  A jury in Memphis said Medtronic's spinal products subsidiary should pay $400 million in punitive damages for violating agreements covering its use of surgical products invented by a doctor. [C10.]    Oracle Defends Motives in Court  The co-president of Oracle testified that its offer for PeopleSoft was more than a way to scare off a competitor's customers. [C10.]    Protest Over Boeing Contract  Lockheed Martin and BAE Systems filed protests over a contract to upgrade a transport plane that a former Air Force official has said was improperly awarded to Boeing. [C5.]    Court Upholds Phone Ruling  The Supreme Court upheld a decision that threw out federal regulations requiring regional Bell phone companies to lease access to their networks at discounted prices. [C11.]    Yahoo's Profit Nearly Triples  The $253 million profit by Yahoo met analysts' expectations and included $129 million related to its sale of shares in Google. Advertising, Yahoo's largest and fastest growing business segment, had a 212 percent increase in revenue from a year ago, defying worries that the market for Web ads had peaked. [C10.]    Lucrative Work in Tax Shelters  A tax partner in the Chicago office of a Dallas law firm earned about $19 million a year from 1999 through 2003 while designing and selling tax shelters, according to people who have seen related court documents. [C5.]

headline: Italy's Church and State: A Mostly Happy Union
abstract: Italy, European nation where religion and state have mingled most, manages issue without much of bitter, absolute argument seen in US; Italy is not exempt from counterpoint argued angrily in Europe, about whether Continent has become so secular as to be hostile to religion, but 1,700 years of debate and hard experience seem to have allowed church and state to settle into almost indistinct whole; result is that while only 32 percent of Italians believe religion should have secular influence, crucifixes hang in public schools without much comment, and abortion is legal and not much debated; photos (M)

abstract: German Economics Ministry reports 1.1 percent rise in industrial orders in October from September; reports 3.3 percent rise in domestic orders, seasonally adjusted (S)

headline: United Airlines to Cut 68 Planes and Add to Foreign Flights
abstract: United Airlines said today that it would cut 68 airplanes from its fleet, shift more responsibility for domestic routes to its regional carrier, and expand international flying.

headline: World Briefing | Americas: Peru: Corruption Fighters To Lose Jobs
abstract: The government of President Alejandro Toledo has chosen not to renew the contract of the chief of a team of special prosecutors empowered to investigate corruption, said the head of the unit, Luis Vargas. Once embraced by the government, the Ad Hoc Prosecutors unit has become a thorn for Mr. Toledo since it began investigating charges of malfeasance by the president, his wife, a presidential aide, other relatives and the government party, Peru Possible. Mr. Vargas, whose team's main focus has been on prosecuting officials in former President Alberto Fujimori's government, will finish his job on Dec. 31. A replacement has not been appointed.   Juan Forero (NYT)

headline: Eskimos Seek to Recast Global Warming as a Rights Issue
abstract: Eskimos, or Inuit, about 155,000 seal-hunting peoples scattered around Arctic, will seek ruling from Inter-American Commission on Human Rights that US is threatening their existence by contributing substantially to global warming; people of poor areas from Arctic to tropical atolls and flanks of Himalayas, represented at talks in Buenos Aires, say they are imperiled by rising temperatures and seas caused by others, and are casting issue as one of basic human rights; commission has no enforcement powers but finding of US violation could lead to legal action (M)

headline: Haiti's Political Vacuum Stokes Flames of Gang Violence

headline: World Business Briefing | Africa: South Africa: Insurer Eases AIDS Restriction

As many as 60 percent of African Life's 550,000 policies are burial policies that pay out up to 15,000 rand ($2,460) to cover funeral costs. Previously, beneficiaries of a principal policyholder who died of AIDS within six months of opening a policy would not have been paid.

abstract: Mainland Chinese stock markets dropped less than 2 percent on Friday, while most Asian financial markets reacted with surprising calm to the Chinese central bank's announcement late Thursday of its first increase in interest rates in nine years.    The People's Bank of China acted on Thursday to slow economic growth and try to curtail inflation, and its slight increase in rates, and the possibility of further moves, are likely to start trimming growth in China's imports.

headline: Warming to Brazil, Powell Says Its Nuclear Program Isn't a Concern
abstract: Secretary of State Colin L. Powell, stepping up the American courtship of President Luiz In√°cio Lula da Silva, said Tuesday that the United States had no concerns that Brazil was planning to develop nuclear weapons despite the country's resistance to allowing international inspectors greater access to one of its nuclear reactors.    After meeting with President da Silva and other Brazilian leaders, Mr. Powell also offered another gesture to Brazilian aspirations, saying that Brazil's contributions to peacekeeping in Haiti and other actions made it was worthy of consideration for permanent membership on the United Nations Security Council.

headline: The Next Hit Song? Ask P.&G.
abstract: Record companies have grown increasingly frustrated in the last few years at the difficulty of promoting new talent, particularly as more fans seem to prefer discovering new music on their own through swapping music files online. Now the EMI Group, the British music corporation, is turning to an unlikely merchant to promote its acts: Procter & Gamble.    EMI, which releases recordings by artists like Lenny Kravitz and Coldplay, is close to a deal to hire Procter & Gamble to test and distribute new music through a special division that uses a network of teenagers to promote products, executives involved in the talks say.

abstract: European Commission formally adopts emasculated accounting standard for derivatives, leaving it up to banks to decide whether they will fully comply with international rules aimed at preventing financial institutions from hiding losses; many companies are expected to report significant changes in profits under rule, which are similar to, but less restrictive than, American rule that has been in force for several years; banks argued that rule would lead to lower or more volatile valuations that could alarm investors (M)

abstract: Vaccination programs in Europe are progressing smoothly with a good supply of medicine, health authorities say.

Greenberg, the chief executive of the American International Group, was facing problems with the brokers who sold commercial insurance policies for his company. At the same time, A.I.G. was being sued in California over these incentives, widely referred to as contingency commissions.

abstract: The holding company of the Brazilian media concern Organiza√ß√µes Globo said yesterday that it had reached an agreement in principle with creditors to restructure $1.34 billion in debt. headline: Hunting Somber Relics of the Cold War in Antarctic Ice
abstract: Untied States Navy, piggybacking on scientific explorations of western Antarctica, has begun effort to locate Navy patrol plane that crashed on Dec 30, 1946, and recover remains of three crew members who died; six other crew members survived and spent two weeks in frigid weather before being rescued; crew members and their plane were part of what remains largest expedition over Antarctica, led by renowned polar explorer Rear Adm Richard E Byrd; mission's stated goal was to consolidate and extend US sovereignty over Antarctic areas and extend scientific knowledge; photos; map (M)

headline: BIG IRAQI PARTIES ARE URGING DELAY IN JAN. 30 VOTING
abstract: Some of Iraq's most powerful political groups, including the party led by the interim prime minister, called Friday for a six-month delay in elections scheduled for Jan. 30, citing concerns over security.    The list of groups includes some that have been among the strongest backers of American policy in Iraq, and their call gives sudden momentum to those arguing for a postponement. The two main Kurdish parties supported the delay request, marking the first time the Kurds, closely allied with the Americans, have taken a clear stand on the issue.

headline: Member of S.E.C. Criticizes Inaction

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: Lawsuit Over Tax Shelter May Derail a Settlement  A former director of America Online and a former senior AOL executive have sued the law firm of Jenkens & Gilchrist and two other entities, saying that they were sold illegitimate tax shelters in 1999 and 2000 intended to help them evade taxes on $200 million in income.    The lawsuit, filed by William N. Melton, a venture capitalist who was on AOL's board from 1992 to 1999, and Myer Berlow, a former marketing executive for AOL, appears to be the single largest lawsuit in which individual investors assert they were sold a tax shelter that the seller knew would not pass muster with the Internal Revenue Service. [Page C2.]    Camp and Culture on a Gay Channel  Pink TV, a new channel based in Paris with programming aimed at gay people, bills itself as a ''giant leap for television, a small step in high heels.'' The station, backed by major French media companies, examines the gay lifestyle without the politics. [C6.]    One Internet, Many Copyright Laws  In Australia, the copyright protection on the 1936 novel ''Gone With the Wind'' expired in 1999. Under United States law, the book will not enter the public domain until 2031. What happens when an Australian puts the book online for free downloading? Lawyers get involved. New Economy. [C4.]    Shopping With My Friendsters  Social networking features are popping up on auction and shopping sites, allowing visitors to compare notes and turn e-commerce into a social experience. Overstock.com hopes the service will help build trust among users. E-Commerce Report: Bob Tedeschi. [C7.]    Paramount Chief Is Sued Over Deal  Sherry Lansing, the chairwoman of Paramount Pictures, has been named in a lawsuit that accuses her of favoritism toward her husband, the director William Friedkin. Paramount says the accusations are false. [C6.]    Marketing for the Third Screen  Motorola hired a noted cinematographer to show off the video capabilities of its new cellphones. Marketers are interested in using the features of advanced phones, like video playback, to beam their messages to tiny screens. On the low-technology side of things, some companies are using text messages to build a relationship with consumers. Advertising. [C8.]    The Next Hit Song? Ask P.&G.  EMI, the British music company, is close to a deal to hire Procter & Gamble to help promote its acts through a division that uses a network of teenagers to spread the word, executives involved in the talks say. [C6.]    Superheroes Triumph at Box Office  ''The Incredibles,'' the latest joint effort from Pixar and the Walt Disney Company, topped the weekend box office, bringing in an estimated $70.7 million. ''Alfie,'' a Paramount release starring Jude Law, opened to a dismal $6.5 million, far less than expected. [E3.]    Voter Surveys Pump Up Web Traffic  On Election Day, Web sites that posted the results of early voter surveys were rewarded with tremendous gains in their hit counts. Slate, Microsoft's online news magazine, crawled into the list of top election news sites by publishing the results. [C7.]

abstract: Statistics Canada reports that Canada's unemployment rate remained steady at 7.1 percent in October despite creation of 34,300 jobs, as number of people entering work force offset gains from new jobs (S)

headline: South African Miner in Hostile Bid for Gold Fields
abstract: Harmony Gold Mining, largest miner of South African gold, makes hostile bid to acquire Gold Fields Ltd, another South African miner, for 52.9 billion rand ($8.2 billion) in stock; unsolicited bid could derail $2.1 billion merger deal reached in summer to combine Gold Fields and Imagold of Canada; photo (M)

headline: World Briefing | Asia: Pakistan: Explosion At A Hotel
abstract: Five people, including two foreign guests, were injured by an explosion at the entrance of a Marriott hotel in Islamabad, the capital. Officials said that the blast was caused by an electrical short circuit and that it was not related to terrorism. But the damage to the entrance of the building was extensive, with three 15-foot-high glass windows shattered and molding inside the hotel ripped off the wall. Officials said explosive experts would continue investigating the cause.   David Rohde (NYT)

headline: Nokia to introduce PDA-like phone
Samsung Electronics shows why markets sometimes discount top performers : When a strong company is a weak stock
Scanner's Compatibility Depends on Its Driver
abstract: Q. My new computer is running Windows XP. When I purchased it, the salesman told me not to hook up my Acer 3300U scanner, as it could ''screw up the new system.'' Acer and Microsoft have not responded to my questions. Do you foresee any problem with using this scanner?    A. As long as you can find and install a compatible Window XP driver for your Acer scanner, you should be able to use the old scanner with the new computer. Drivers are little bits of code that allow software like the Windows operating system to communicate with hardware devices like scanners and printers.

headline: General Electric Sells 60% of Indian Back-Office Unit
abstract: General Electric Co announces it has sold 60 percent stake in its Indian back-office unit GE Capital International Services to private equity firms General Atlantic Partners and Oak Hill Capital Partners; price is $500 million (M)

headline: World Business Briefing | Australia: Miner Plans Share Buyback
abstract: The world's largest mining company, BHP Billiton, said it would buy back shares worth as much as 1.5 billion Australian dollars ($1.1 billion) held by investors in Australia as it seeks to pay out some of the windfall it has earned from supplying China with raw materials. The announcement provided the first details of a plan announced in August when BHP reported record net profit and said it would distribute $2 billion in earnings to shareholders.   Wayne Arnold (NYT)

headline: Officials Fear Iraq's Lure for Muslims in Europe
abstract: France's antiterrorist police on Friday identified a young Frenchman killed fighting the United States in Iraq, the first confirmed case of what is believed to be a growing stream of Muslims heading from Europe to fight what they regard as a new holy war.    Redouane el-Hakim, 19, the son of Tunisian immigrants, died during an American bombardment of insurgents in Falluja on July 17, according to an intelligence official close to the case.

headline: Globalist : South Africa's ghosts haunt thinking on HIV

Treasury Bill Sales Set for This Week
abstract: The Treasury's schedule of financing this week includes the regular weekly auction of new three- and six-month bills today and an auction of four-week bills tomorrow.    At the close of the New York cash market on Friday, the rate on the outstanding three-month bill was 1.75 percent. The rate on the six-month issue was 2 percent, and the rate on the four-week issue was 1.57 percent.

headline: Austrians toast art of fine wine glasses
Connecticut Issues Subpoenas to Insurers
abstract: New efforts to investigate insurance industry emeges as Connecticut Atty Gen Richard Blumenthal issues subpoenas to big health insurers and providers of employee benefits and auto insurance; Blumenthal says he is seeking details on price-rigging and price-fixing, particularly among brokers, agents and health care and auto insurers; Connecticut is home of Aetna and base for Cigna and Anthem; California Insurance Comr John Garamendi plans to propose regulation to require brokers to disclose fully fees they receive; state regulation would be first official measure to change way indusry operates since New York State Atty Gen Eliot Spitzer asserted last week that incentive fees to brokers were causing 'widespread corruption' in industry; photo (M)

headline: Greenspan Warns That U.S. Deficits Pose Risk to Dollar
abstract: The persistently high current-account deficit of the U.S. in world trade threatens to further devalue the dollar, Alan Greenspan, the Federal Reserve chairman, said today.

headline: Rumsfeld Sees an Iraq Pullout Within 4 Years
abstract: Defense Secretary Donald H. Rumsfeld indicated Monday that he expected American troops to withdraw from Iraq within four years, but he cautioned that any final decision hinged on the progress that Iraq's civilian government and security forces made by then.     Asked by reporters traveling with him whether United States forces would be out of Iraq by the end of his second four-year term, Mr. Rumsfeld said, ''I would certainly expect that to be the case and hope that to be the case.''

headline: World Briefing | Europe: Italy: Zero-Tolerance Drug Plan
abstract: Italy plans tougher drug laws for possession of marijuana despite trend throughout Europe to decriminalize drug; marijuana possession in Italy, if drug is deemed for personal use, is rarely penalized under current laws (S)

headline: Bush Health Savings Accounts Slow to Gain Acceptance
abstract: Pres Bush has made health savings accounts one of his central campaign remedies for nation's health care problems, but so far employers and workers have been slow to accept accounts as alternative to conventional health insurance; few employers are offering new plans; UnitedHealth Group, which provides health insurance to more than 18 million workers, expects only 150,000 of those employees to choose health savings accounts for 2005; Aetna says only 38 of hundreds of employers it covers are offering savings plans for 2005; Pres Bush is expected to discuss plans again in domestic policy debate with Sen John Kerry; nonpartisan health policy experts say plans are apparently too new and untested to appeal to many employers and may simply not be financially feasible for middle-income familites; graph; photo (M)

headline: Federal Reserve Statement on Rate Increase
abstract: Text of statement released by Federal Reserve afer its Federal Open Market Committee decides to raise federal funds rate by 25 basis points, to 2.25 percent (M)

headline: Polls show passions about election reflect wide dislike of Bush : Vote in U.S. inflames Europeans
Pennsylvania Limits Cities In Offering Net Access
abstract: Pennsylvania Gov Edward Rendell, despite his objection to municipal Internet provision, signs new telecommunications law; law, considered victory for Verizon Communications, prohibits cities from building their own high-speed broadband data networks without first giving main local phone company right to build network within 14 months; dominant telecommunications provider in a region is required to provide high-speed Internet access across its territories over next decade; photo (M)

headline: Fear of Flying? Think Again. It's Gotten Safer.
abstract: Article explores question of whether air travel has become safer; National Transportation Safety Board study reports no fatalities in 2002 and only one death in 32.6 million passenger departures in 2003; Air Transport Assn spokesman Doug Wills says number of commercial airline accidents worldwide declined from 1.19 to 0.8 per million departures in last five years; increase in crew member training in moving passengers efficiently out of downed plane is cited as one reason for improved safety record; photos (M)

CAMPAIGN 2004: Military and families support Bush and war
Block Intruders by Rewinding Your Hard Drive
abstract: Suppose that in the middle of a bad day you could just click a button and start over. That is the idea behind DriveShield Plus, software from Centurion Technologies.    DriveShield (www.centuriontech.com; $60; Windows only) can help home users guard against unauthorized changes.

headline: Ahold Reaches a Settlement With the S.E.C.
abstract: Royal Ahold and former top executives Cees van der Hoeven and Michiel Meurs reach settlement with Securities and Exchange Commission in connection with multi-billion-dollar accounting scandal; sidesteps SEC fine because of what agency calls extensive cooperation; company agrees not to violate US securities laws in future; Ahold, which is still subject of Justice Department probe and investor class-action lawsuit in US, neither admits nor denies SEC allegations, which accused it of using fraudulent documents to pump up its sales and profit figures; SEC contended Ahold overstated is sales by $30 billion over three years (M)

headline: On Mindanao, jihad looms if peace talks fail
Political Power of Turkish Army Seems to Fade
abstract: Civilian, Yigit Alpogan, presides over Turkey's National Security Council for first time since 1980 military coup, reflecting quiet but major shift toward limiting military's political power; his appointment as secretary general followed constitutional amendments that cut number of posts reserved for military in council and several other government institutions; council has been army's vehicle for communicating its views on variety of issues (M)

headline: Chechen Rebel Leader Is Reported to Be Close to Surrendering
abstract: The senior law enforcement official in Chechnya announced Friday that the authorities had nearly captured Aslan Maskhadov, one of the best-known leaders of the Chechen resistance, and that Mr. Maskhadov was planning to surrender soon.     The announcement, made by the first deputy prime minister, Ramzan Kadyrov, in Grozny, the Chechen capital, underscored the sense of urgency driving the hunts for senior separatists. It also exposed the tension among the Russian security agencies conducting them.

headline: Balance Sheet : No more Marsh?Fine.
U.S. hints at reward to a disarmed North Korea
Rarely at a Tee, but Still a Player
abstract: Interview with George Fisher, former chief executive of Motorola and Eastman Kodak and now chairman of PanAmSat Corp; photo (S)

headline: World Briefing | Europe: Britain: Inquiry Finds No Wrongdoing By Blunkett
abstract: David Blunkett, who quit as home secretary last week after a series of humiliating disclosures about his personal life, was linked to a ''chain of events'' that hastened the approval of a visa for his former lover's nanny, a report concluded. But its author, Sir Alan Budd, cleared him of any direct wrongdoing, saying there was no evidence that he had abused his position. Mr. Blunkett, above, was accused of helping his former lover, Kimberly Quinn, by speeding visa approval for a Filipino nanny she had employed to care for her young son. Mr. Blunkett says he is the father of the boy and is embroiled in a custody dispute. ''I believe there are two broad possibilities,'' Sir Alan said. ''Mr. Blunkett was seeking special help for Mrs. Quinn's nanny or he was raising the case as an example of the poor performance of the Immigration and Nationality Directorate. I do not have direct evidence that allows me to choose between the two possibilities.''   Lizette Alvarez (NYT)

headline: Marketing With Double Entendres
abstract: Virgin Atlantic Airways commercial for its Upper Class Suite service on flights between New York and London uses bawdy British humor to spoof soft-core pornography, and it is running on sex-oriented pay-per-view channel on hotel TV networks run by LodgeNet Entertainment; spoof, almost 10 minutes long, is part of wry campaign that also includes droll seat-pocket safety cards and in-flight magazine; photo (M)

headline: 'Retired' Rapper Finds a Job Atop Def Jam
abstract: Rap star Jay-Z, whose real name is Shawn Carter, agrees to become president of Universal Music Group's Def Jam Recordings label; Universal will give Jay-Z, who has little corporate experience, vacant top job at one of its biggest divisions, granting him authority over everything from album production to marketing strategies; deal is also big win for Universal and Antonio Reid, chairman of corporation's Island Def Jam Music Group, who has been working to secure Carter as executive and prevent him from lining up with rival Warner Music Group; three-year deal allows Carter to sign limited number of artists to his own Def Jam-distributed venture, likely under Roc-A-Fella imprint; photo (M)

headline: The Sport That Has Everything: Water, Wind and Politics
abstract: Windsurfers are angry about political ads that seek to deride Sen John Kerry by showing him windsurfing; discuss sport's appeal and Kerry's skill; sport reportedly is booming nationwide after several years of contraction; table of costs of getting started; photos (M)

headline: Court Allows Ex-Banker to Remain Free for Now
abstract: US Appeals Court gives Credit Suisse First Boston's former investment banker Frank P Quattrone, who was found guilty of obstruction of justice, permission to remain free pending his appeal, just weeks before he was scheduled to begin 18-month prison sentence (M)

headline: Comments are rebuff to EU neutrality : Dutch aide casts vote for Kiev opposition
At Warning Center, Alert for the Quake, None for a Tsunami
abstract: Experts at Pacific Tsunami Warning Center in Honolulu had no way of knowing that earthquake that struck off Indonesia had generated devastating tsunami and no way to warn people most likely to suffer; sequence of events as knowledge of earthquake, tsunami and destruction unfolded suggest speed and precision of science and modern communication, as well as their limits; scientists do not have tools to tell when earthquake has created one; for Pacific Ocean, there are computer models to analyze consequences of earthquake, based on years of observations of previous quakes and tsunamis; for Indian Ocean, where tsunamis are rare, there are no such models (M)

headline: As Gaza Pullout Vote Nears, Tension Among Israelis Rises
abstract: Tension is high in Israel as Parliament prepares for Oct 26 vote on Prime Min Ariel Sharon's plan to remove all 8,000 Jewish settlers from Gaza Strip; Sharon is widely expected to prevail by winning at least 67 votes of 120-member Parliament, but debate remains raw; opinion poll says third of Israelis believe chances of political assassination in coming year have increased; sharpest sign of anguish caused by withdrawal debate has been response of military leaders to rabbis who are telling religious soldiers to follow their conscience and disobey orders; Defense Min Shaul Mofaz and army chief of staff Lt Gen Moshe Yaalon give wrenching speeces demanding that country consolidate around armed forces as unifying symbol of nation; Yaalon claims army disobedience would be dangerous to Israel as army, as society and as state; photo (M)

headline: Rebel near surrender, Chechen official says
Nuclear Talks With Iranians Said to Progress
abstract: French spokesman says French, German and British talks with Iran concerning Iran's suspected nuclear weapons program have made progress toward agreement that would provide economic, technological and political incentives for Iran to halt enrichment of uranium; talks ended without formal agreement but will continue (S)

headline: U.S. Board Close to Backing a Bidder for ATA Airlines
abstract: Air Transportation Stabilization Board is preparing to endorse its choice to purchase some or all of assets of ATA Airlines, nation's 10th-largest airline and unit of ATA Holdings, which sought bankruptcy protection this fall; Southwest Airlines, AirTran, America West and several investment firms are expected to bid; photo (M)

headline: Europeans Offer Plan to Ease Dispute on Iran Nuclear Issue
abstract: Britain, France and Germany are working to give Iran a last chance to avoid confrontation with the West over its nuclear program by offering incentives to curtail its most disputed activities.    But Iran's government, which the United States believes is using its nuclear program as a cover to develop nuclear weapons, has given no indication that it would accept the plan.

headline: British Bankers Can Be Extradited to U.S., Judge Rules
abstract: A judge ruled that three bankers can be extradited to face wire fraud charges related to dealings with the Enron energy group.

Flu Vaccine Maker Won't Assure U.S. Sales in '05
abstract: Chiron Corp executives hedge about whether company will be able to return to selling flu vaccine in US next year; chief executive Howard Pien says company must still design plan to fix sterility and quality control problems at its plant in Liverpool, Eng, which was stripped of its license by British regulators on Oct 5; company must still get input from British and American regulators; wrote off its Fluvirin vaccine inventory at cost of $91 million for third quarter; earned $24 million in quarter compared with loss of $20 million year ago; photo (M)

headline: L-3 PAID $42 MILLION FOR CAMERA DIVISION OF RAYTHEON
abstract: L-3 Communications, maker of bomb detectors and military electronics, says it had paid $42 million to buy a Raytheon Company unit that makes infrared camera systems for use in public safety, fire, security and transportation markets (S)

headline: World Business Briefing | Europe: The Netherlands: Bank To Cut Jobs
abstract: Dutch bank ABN Amro Holding will cut 2,850 jobs, or about 3 percent of its work force; graph (S)

headline: Eggs and Charges Fly in Ukraine's Ever-Nastier Election
abstract: Pres Leonid D Kuchma's decision not to seek third five-year term opens fierce and increasingly nasty presidentical campaign in Ukraine; polls suggest fierce race between two most prominent candidates: former prime minister Viktor A Yushchenko, leader of anti-Kuchma opposition, and current prime minister Viktor Yanukovich, who promises to carry out Kuchma's legacy; neither front-runner is expected to win outright majority in elections Oct 31; runoff is scheduled for Nov 21; photos (M)

headline: With Russia's Nod, Treaty on Emissions Clears Last Hurdle
abstract: Kyoto Protocol on global warming overcomes its last critical hurdle when Russia's cabinet endorses it and sends it to Parliament, which is widely expected to approve it; treaty will take effect 90 days after that; it is first treaty to require cuts in emissions linked to global warming; it has been ratified by 120 countries; United States, which accounted for 36.1 percent of emissions from industrialized countries in 1990, has rejected treaty and will not be bound by its restrictions; although treaty is seen as milestone of international environmental diplomacy, many specialists say that it is just tiniest initial step toward limiting human influence on climate, given that its targets are small and that US will not be bound by its terms, and because China, major polluter that did sign treaty, is not bound by its restrictions because it is considered developing country; chart (M)

headline: A Hint of a Nuclear Compromise by Iran
abstract: Iran's chief nuclear negotiator Hassan Rowhani hints that Iran might maintain its freeze on enriching uranium to end standoff with European countries over its nuclear program; his remarks come day after Iran's Foreign Ministry spokesman rejects request by Germany, France and Britain to suspend uranium enrichment in return for technical and economic aide (S)

headline: Does Grandma Need a Hug? A Robotic Pillow Can Help
abstract: Robotics researchers at Carnegie Mellon have designed soft, huggable pillow that uses sensors and wireless telephone technology to provide physical touch and thus better social and emotional support for distant family members; photo (M)

abstract: Pepsi-Cola North America Co shifts Diet Pepsi soft drink line for at least next year from BBDO Worldwide to DDB Worldwide in New York (S)

abstract: Sprint Near $34 Billion Deal For Nextel Communications  Sprint is near a deal to acquire Nextel Communications for more than $34 billion. A merger would create a powerful competitor in the field with some 39 million cellphone customers.

abstract: Fifteen candidates in Afghanistan's presidential election said today that officials had committed serious irregularities.

abstract: Lazard files for initial public offering, becoming last of old-line Wall Street partnerships to do so; seeks to raise $850 million from offering, which is subject to approval by Securities and Exchange Commission; Lazard, expected to command valuation of around $3 billion, will spin off its capital markets and merchant banking businesses in private company owned by current and former managing directors (M)

abstract: Citigroup acquires transaction services businesses that ABN Amro Holding operates in eight European and Asian nations; financial terms undisclosed (S)

abstract: Commerzbank will shut bulk of its investment banking operations outside Germany; decision will result in nearly 900 layoffs in New York, Tokyo and London; photo (M)

abstract: Somalia Pres Abdullah Yusuf Ahmed, in rare appearance before UN Security Council in Nairobi, Kenya, says he needs financial support and as many as 22,000 foreign troops to disarm gunmen who have ruled his country since 1991 (M)

headline: Thompson New York Names a Co-President
abstract: Ty Montague resigned yesterday as co-executive creative director at the New York office of Wieden & Kennedy to become co-president and chief creative officer at the flagship New York office of J. Walter Thompson, part of the WPP Group, effective on Jan. 1.    As co-president of Thompson New York, Mr. Montague, 41, will share leadership with Rosemarie Ryan, who joined as the sole president in January. As chief creative officer, Mr. Montague will succeed Michael J. Campbell, who left in January. Mr. Montague had been at the Wieden New York office since 2000 and earlier helped open the New York office of Bartle Bogle Hegarty.

headline: For Palestinians, a Sense That Arafat's Era Left Them Empty-Handed
abstract: Palestinians in Qalqilya say Israelis, not their late leader Yasir Arafat, created obstacles to peace, pointing to barrier wall that Israel has built all around town to curb terrorist attacks; photo; Mayor Maarouf Zahran is one of few who still has hopeful contact with Israelis, through calls with Israeli counterparts and as part of group of Palestinian and Israeli mayors who meet periodically overseas; he points out that Palestinian bombers did favor for Prime Min Ariel Sharon, increasing support for hard-line policies; Qalqilya zoo boasts new playground given by Bill and Melinda Gates Foundation, and several animals sent by Israeli zoo (M)

headline: Giving Overstuffed Cameras Some Offloading Options
abstract: Basics Basics column on hand-held devices that can take on burden of overstuffed memory cards in digital cameras; photos (M)

headline: Consumer Advice for Advertisers
abstract: Speakers at Association of National Advertisers annual meeting, Naples, Fla, say executives who oversee some $300 billion a year spent on consumer marketing in United States must become more accountable, innovative and creative; Procter & Gamble official James R Stengel holds traditional marketing model is obsolete; study by Booz Allen Hamilton consulting company finds corporate marketing has become more critical success factor, even in fields where it has not traditionally been valued, but is seen as disconnected from chief executive's agenda and typically lacks adequate resources (M)

headline: Brokers Are Jittery; Spitzer Seeks Data
abstract: New York State Atty Gen Eliot Spitzer is turing his attention to whether American corporations and their employees are paying more for life, disability and accident insurance than they should be; Spitzer's probe is on bid-rigging and price-fixing among commercial insurance brokers and insurance companies, but he is also pursuing reports of payoffs that may increase coverage costs for tens of thousands of individuals; California Insurance Comr John Garamendi says he is concerned about extra costs to individuals for life, disability and accident insurance and that he is considering legal action against at least one broker and several insurance companies that sell what are known as employee benefits (M)

headline: Mars consolidates advertising with Omnicom
$400 Million Judgment Against Medtronic
abstract: Memphis jury says Medtronic's spinal products subsidiary should pay $400 million in punitive damages for violating agreements covering its use of surgical products invented by Dr Gary K Michelson; punitive award follows verdict reached by jury last month that Medtronic owed $159 million in compensatory damages and unpaid royalties to Michelson and his company Karlin Technology; Michelson contends he spent $62 million on case; photo (M)

headline: Make the 5-Day Weather Forecast as Local as Your Own Backyard
abstract: Vantage Pro2 weather station from Davis Instruments uses outdoor sensors that relay information to indoor console, allowing backyard meteorologists to keep track of world around them; photo (S)
