abstract: Palmone names Andrew J Brown is new chief financial officer, succeeding Philippe Morali, who assumed post on acting basis after Judy Bruner left (S)

headline: World Business Briefing | Europe: New Zealand: Plane Order For Bombardier
abstract: World Business Briefing: New Zealand:

headline: Politicus : French ship of hope?It's a bit early to say
BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: Supreme Court Set to Hear Cable Access Arguments  The Supreme Court has agreed to decide whether competing high-speed Internet service providers are entitled to use the networks of cable companies to reach their subscribers.     The justices accepted appeals filed by the Bush administration and the cable industry from an appeals court decision that struck down portions of an order by the Federal Communications Commission. [Page C4.]    More of the Same for McDonald's  James A. Skinner, left, the chief executive of McDonald's, said he would continue with the strategies of his predecessors. Mr. Skinner was named to the top job after the resignation of Charles H. Bell, who has colorectal cancer. Last April, Mr. Bell's predecessor, James Cantalupo, died of a heart attack. Mr. Skinner must find a way to maintain the right balance between the cheap food for which McDonald's is known and new premium items. [C12.]    Dollar Drop Causes Soul-Searching  Japan, China and some other Asian nations have been aggressively buying dollars. But with these huge stakes in the dollar losing value, the question is: What will they do next? [A1.]    Treasury Report on Exchange Rates  The Bush administration once again declared that China is not manipulating its exchange rate, dismissing loud complaints from some manufacturers and members of Congress that the country's undervalued currency is badly aggravating the trade deficit of the United States. [C2.]    A Bet on Oil Prices Turns Sour  China Aviation Oil of Singapore filed for bankruptcy protection after its bet that oil prices would fall proved to be very wrong. A criminal investigation has begun. [C3.]    BBC Acknowledges Bhopal Hoax  The BBC acknowledged it had been tricked into broadcasting an interview with a man pretending to be a Dow Chemical spokesman who claimed that the company had taken the blame for the 1984 disaster in Bhopal, India. [A6.]    Nasdaq Up 7.22% for the Year  The Nasdaq composite index rose 4.39 points, to 2,147.96, and was up 2.2 percent for the week. It has climbed 7.22 percent so far this year. The Dow Jones industrial average rose 7.09 points, to 10,592.21, and the Standard & Poor's 500-stock index inched up 0.84 point, to 1,191.17. The dollar tumbled, while bonds rallied after the government reported that fewer jobs than expected were created last month. The price of crude oil dropped to $42.54 a barrel. [C4.]    Court Approves Halliburton Deal  A federal court approved Halliburton's $4.2 billion settlement of asbestos claims, but another court delayed the asbestos settlement plan for ABB's Combustion Engineering unit. [C4.]    No Alternate Slate for Disney Board  Roy E. Disney and Stanley P. Gold, former directors of Walt Disney, said that they would not propose alternate candidates for the board at its shareholder meeting next year. [C4.]    Intelsat Regains Control of Satellite  Intelsat said that it had regained control of the Americas-7 communications satellite whose failure on Sunday had threatened the planned $3.1 billion sale of the company. [C4.]    Aon Sells Endurance Specialty Stake  Aon said that it received $320.5 million by selling almost all of its shares in Endurance Specialty Holdings, a Bermuda-based insurer that it helped found after the Sept. 11 terrorist attacks. [C4.]    Offices of Yukos Unit Raided  A Siberian unit of Yukos was searched by law enforcement officers. Yukos offices in Moscow and at other subsidiaries have been raided in the last year in connection with an investigation into government claims for more than $24 billion in back taxes owed by the oil company. [C3.]

headline: Viacom Earnings Climbed 11.6% in Third Quarter
abstract: Viacom Inc says profits grew 11.6 percent in third quarter; also says it will buy back $8 billion, or almost 13 percent, of its stock; company earned $723 million compared with $648 million year earlier; sales grew 4 percent, to $5.5 billion (S)2

headline: China Praises Powell for Warning Taiwan on Independence
abstract: Taiwanese leaders sharply criticized Mr. Powell for changing a longstanding policy in managing the diplomatically nuanced cross-Strait rivalry.

headline: Young Bulgarians Know Their Nation's History, Sort Of
abstract: Amid recent years of economic changes and moves toward prosperity, young Bulgarians seem to be increasingly unaware of Communist era that began in their country just after World War II and ended after Berlin Wall fell; country's prewar history has been glossed over in high schools, as country concentrates on future; photo; map (M)

headline: Worst Violence in 2 Years Kills 28 Arabs and 3 Israelis
abstract: Israeli military offensive targeted to quell rocket fire from Jabaliya, northern Gaza refugee camp, results in highest single-day death toll since spring of 2002; at least 28 Palestinians, among them civilians and teenagers, are killed along with 3 Israelis, including kindergarten teacher Shula Batito; Israeli officials have been reticent to dispatch troops to congested urban areas and refugee camps, but stress need to control regions that have become hotbed for militant activities; current offensive was approved by Prime Min Ariel Sharon's cabinet and sanctions open-ended presence in regions of northern Gaza; photo; map (M)

headline: GOODRICH REACHES SETTLEMENT WITH NORTHROP
abstract: Goodrich Corp says Northrop Grumman Corp will pay it $99 million to settle claims related to its 2002 purchase of Northrop's aeronautical-systems business (S)

headline: Sprint Near Deal to Buy Nextel for $34 Billion
abstract: Sprint is near deal to acquire Nextel Communications for over $34 billion in transaction that would further consolidate rapidly changing telecommunications industry; merger would create powerful new cellular company, with some 39 million customers; it would also mean that 74 percent of cellphone market would be controlled by Cingular, Verizon Wireless and Sprint; executives say several details still need to be worked out and deal could fall apart; Sprint chairman Gary D Forsee would be company's chief executive and Nextel chief Timothy Donahue would be executive chairman (M)

headline: Mubarak Urges Palestinians to Do Business With Sharon
abstract: CAIRO, Dec. 2 - In remarkably conciliatory remarks toward Israel, President Hosni Mubarak of Egypt today urged Palestinians to work with Prime Minister Ariel Sharon of Israel as their best hope to achieve peace and appealed to them to curb the violence that has marked the struggle to end the occupation.

headline: Artists Bridge the Taiwan Strait With Paint and Bamboo
abstract: New York-based Chinese artist Cai Guo-Qiang is displaying his art installations on ruined bunkers on island of Quemoy for show that ponders legacy of war; exhibition also seeks to build bridge between artists from Taiwan and mainland China; Quemoy, mile off mainland coast but controlled by Taiwan, was often shelled during cold war; photos; map (M)

headline: Rebuilding Mitsubishi¬ís Image
abstract: Mitsubishi Motors to unveil series of TV commercials that stress its warranties; campaign was developed by Los Angeles office of Deutsch; photo (M)

headline: Afghans Studying The Art of Voting
abstract: After 23 years of conflict, many Afghans appear to be enthusiastically supporting the concept of resolving political differences through peaceful elections. Western experts and Afghans say the Oct. 9 presidential election is a positive first step in a long process.

headline: Judge Gives US Airways Authority to Cut Union Pay
abstract: Judge Stephen L Mitchell grants US Airways most of emergency pay cuts for is union members that it said are critical to avoid liquidation; industry's other bankrupt company, United Airlines, says it will ask bankruptcy judge to revise its labor contracts in November to cut its costs; actions will affect more than 90,000 employees in the industry and underscore crisis facing nation's airlines (M)

headline: Pedestrians and Drivers Beware! Motoboys Are in a Hurry
abstract: In Sao Paulo, Brazil, motorcycle messengers known as 'motoboys' zigzag among stopped cars, ignore lane markers, red lights and stop signs, and regularly menace pedestrians and infuriate motorists as they zoom their way down gridlocked streets and highways of city, armed with knowledge that without them business would grind to halt; photo (M)

Yudhoyono promises reforms for Indonesia

headline: Trying to Make the Pen as Mighty as the Keyboard

headline: Corrections
abstract: An article last Sunday about current parallels to the economy of 1985 misstated the year in which the Group of Seven industrial nations -- or G-7 -- was formed. The first annual summit meeting of the full G-7 was held in 1976, not in the 1980's. From 1986, the finance ministers of the G-7 nations began meeting separately and more often to discuss economic performance and coordination.

headline: CODELCO EXPECTS DECLINE IN PRICE OF COPPER
abstract: Codelco, world's biggest copper mining company, expects price of copper to fall to $1.10 to $1.20 a pound in 2005 after having risen 58 percent in last 12 months, to $1.4315 a pound (S)

headline: Names of the Dead
abstract: The Department of Defense has identified 1,106 American service members who have died since the start of the Iraq war. It confirmed the death of the following American yesterday:    LEMON, Jerome, 42, Staff Sgt., Army National Guard; North Charleston, S.C.; 1052nd Transportation Company.

headline: Man Who Toppled Chief of Fannie Mae Is Seen as a David Who Beat Goliath
abstract: They sat across from each other in a mahogany and velvet booth at one of those power-lunch restaurants near the White House: the top executive of the nation's fourth-largest financial institution and the little-known director of an obscure and historically ineffective federal regulatory agency.    The regulator, Armando Falcon Jr., had just narrowly avoided being ousted from his job, after being ridiculed for running an agency that did little more than rubber-stamp reports from corporate auditors.

Program Coaxes Hospitals to See Treatments Under Their Noses
abstract: Federal government is telling patients whether their local hospitals are doing what they should; effort involves three common and deadly afflictions of elderly--heart attacks, heart failure and pneumonia--and asks about lifesaving treatments that everyone agrees should be given but that hospitals and doctors often forget to give; it is bold effort by federal government, along with organizations of hospitals, doctors, nurses and health researchers, to push providers to use proven remedies for common ailments; hospital ratings are done by Medicare and posted on Internet (M)

abstract: Survey by Nancy L Salz Consulting finds that relationships between advertisers and their agencies have improved over last year in several areas but remain at or near historic low points in other important respects (M)

abstract: Sanyo Electric warns that it expects net loss of 71 billion yen ($682 million) of year ending March 31, 2005, compared with earlier forecast for profit of 14 billion yen; cites damage caused to one of its factories in northern Japan by earthquake in October (S)

headline: For the record
A.I.G. and U.S. Complete Big Settlement Agreement
abstract: American International Group and federal regulators complete settlement that calls for company to pay $126 million in penalties and restitution and to allow independent monitor to go through company's books; settlement covers some sales of insurance and services that were used by companies to inflate appearance of their financial strength; AIG says it is setting up internal review unit to prevent those kinds of transactions in future; Justice Department agrees not to pursue criminal charges against unit of AIG for 13 months, and will dismiss complaint at that time if AIG lives up to terms of settlement; AIG will pay Justice Department penalty of $80 million; will also pay Securities and Exchange Commission $46.3 million in earnings and interest that it had made on transactions it arranged for PNC Financial Services Group; that money will be added to $115 million restitution fund for PNC investors that was started last year as part of agreement between PNC and regulators (M)

headline: WIRELESS : Cellphone makers get call for cheaper models
Leader Offers Fresh Election for Ukrainians
abstract: Pres Leonid D Kuchma proposes holding new presidential election to end political crisis threatening to tear Ukraine apart, even as country's Supreme Court hears complaints of electoral fraud; it is unclear whether Kuchma intends to hold new runoff between Prime Min Viktor F Yanukovich and his challenger, Viktor A Yushchenko, which law does not permit, or whole new election; Kuchma's remarks represent collapse of what had been united government position that Yanukovich won election, despite evidence of fraud and falsification involving perhaps millions of ballots; Yushchenko himself does not immediately respond to Kuchma's proposal; tells thousands of protesters massed on Independence Square that struggle over election would be decided by Supreme Court and Parliament; Parliament, which voted in nonbinding resolution to declare election results invalid, will meet again; photo; map (M)

People

headline: World Business Briefing | Europe: Germany: Interest In Retailer
abstract: The buyout company Blackstone Group of New York is interested in buying KarstadtQuelle, the European retailer, a Blackstone official said, setting off a 15 percent gain in KarstadtQuelle's share price. Blackstone would consider buying all or parts of KarstadtQuelle, the official, Chad Pike, said in an interview in Munich. Blackstone is not currently in talks with KarstadtQuelle, said Mr. Pike, who is managing director of Blackstone's European real estate business. KarstadtQuelle's chief executive, Christoph Achenbach, said last week that the company was planning to sell stores and shares to raise 1.6 billion euros and help turn around the struggling company. Before yesterday's gain, stock in KarstadtQuelle had fallen 25 percent since early August.

headline: Bank deal hits snag in Germany
Maker of Flu Vaccine Says S.E.C. Has Called
abstract: Securities and Exchange Commission begins informal probe into disclosure issues surrounding Chiron Corp, maker of flu vaccine; Chiron's British manufacturing plant was shut down last week, halting production and delivery of nearly half of flu vaccine for Americans this winter; Chiron says it is cooperating with securities regulators; informal inquiry comes on same day that Congress requests documents and other information from Food and Drug Administration, as committees in House and Senate begin probes into what agency knew about problems at Chiron plant and how it responded; Justice Department and FDA are pursuing their own investigations; photo (M)

headline: Earnings Drop at Big Bank in Australia
abstract: National Australia Bank reports that net profit in year ended Sept 30 dropped 20 percent, to 3.18 billion Australian dollars ($2.42 billion); John Stewart, who took over as bank's chief executive in wake of foreign-exchange trading scandal in February, calls bank's performance 'totally unacceptable'; photo (M)

abstract: ABB plans to increase its work force by 5,000 people, or 71 percent, to help meet surge in demand for power networks; will add new employees by 2008; plans to invest at least $100 million in new product lines and plants in China by 2008 (S)0

headline: UBS's Quarterly Profit Falls Less Than Its Rivals'
abstract: UBS, Europe's biggest bank, said Tuesday that its third-quarter profit fell 1 percent as fees from managing finances for millionaires cushioned a drop in investment banking earnings.    Net income slid to 1.67 billion Swiss francs ($1.39 billion), or 1.55 francs a share, from 1.69 billion francs, or 1.48 francs a share, a year earlier, the bank said. Earnings per share rose after UBS spent 3.54 billion francs to buy back shares this year.

headline: From Afghanistan to Saudi Arabia, via Guant√°namo
abstract: YASER E. HAMDI, a high school honor student from a privileged Saudi background, was a sophomore in college, majoring in marketing, when he took off for Afghanistan during the summer of 2001.     His father, who spells his name Himdy, says it was just one of those things young men do, to find themselves or to satisfy a yearning for adventure. ''Boys like to try things new,'' Mr. Himdy said. ''He had never traveled outside Saudi Arabia before. He decided to show, 'I am a man.'''

SMUCKER CO., Orrville, Ohio, the maker of jellies and jams, said that it would sell its industrial bakery ingredients business to Baldwin Richardson Foods Co., Chicago, and that it would sell its dairy ingredients business to Sabroso Co., Medford, Ore., a distributor of fruit products. abstract: Harry Winston has put more jewelry on display at its Fifth Avenue store since being acquired by Aber in April, but it is definitely not going downmarket (S)

headline: Japan's Recovery Hinges on Oil Prices
abstract: Like a Japanese compact car, the nation's economy is built to go a long way on a little gas. And so, Japan should be one of the best-prepared countries in the world to deal with rising oil prices. But as oil prices linger around $50 a barrel, economists now say Japan may be among the hardest hit.     The Japanese economy depends less on oil than almost any nation, requiring only about half as much oil to generate $1 worth of economic growth as the United States. But while the surge in oil prices has had relatively little impact so far on corporate profits or consumer spending, the increase is beginning to take a toll on the economy by contributing to a decline in Japanese exports, the main engine of the recovery that began last year.

abstract: The Web can help you find the best price among 50,000 online merchants. But what if you just want to go to the store?

headline: A. SCHULMAN SAYS PROFIT FOR QUARTER IS BELOW FORECASTS
abstract: A Schulman Inc, plastics maker, says profit for fourth quarter ended Aug 31 was lower than forecast (S)

headline: At Citigroup, a Shifting in Strategy at a Core Unit
abstract: Charles O Prince, chief executive of Citigroup, and senior Citigroup executives have detailed discussions about strategic options for asset management-business, including internal revamping, sale to another institution or, least likely possibility, a spinoff; discussions are continuing, and bankers and executives say no final decision has been reached (M)

headline: New Guerrilla Factions Arise in Sudan Ahead of Peace Talks
abstract: Two new guerrilla factions emerge in western Sudan, potentially complicating peace talks that are set to begin between Sudanese government and its two established rebel foes; one is based near northwestern border with Chad and other in southern Darfur; rebel and government delegates to peace talks accuse one another of bad faith (M)

headline: Equity Firm to Take Over Shoe Retailer
abstract: Hicks, Tate & Furst will buy 51 percent of Jimmy Choo shoe company from Phoenix Equity Partners and Robert Bensoussan, its chief executive, valuing it at 101 million pounds ($188 million); deal will help finance ambitious expansion plan that includes opening Jimmy Choo stores in North America, as well as in big cities in Asia, Europe and Middle East (S)

headline: Figuring the Cost of Being Mobile
abstract: Roundup of services available from cellular phone providers other than voice service (M)

headline: Sports fans worldwide flock to online games : Leagues may be fantasy, but revenue isn't
Suits Over Offerings Made Class Actions
abstract: Morgan Stanley, Credit Suisse First Boston and other investment banks will face at least six class-action suits over claims they rigged initial public stock offerings in 1990's; Federal Judge Shira A Scheindlin certifies as class actions 6 of 310 cases arising from accusations that initial public offering market was manipulated by banks and Internet start-ups they took public during technology stock boom; cases certified involve offerings for Engage Inc, Firepond Inc, Corvis Corp, now known as Broadwing Corp, iXL Enterprises Inc, Sycamore Networks Inc and VA Software Corp (S)

headline: Digital Goes Mainstream
abstract: Amazon.com says its sales of consumer electronics surpassed book sales for first time during Thanksgiving weekend to become top sales category on site; analysts say shift is one indicator that digital products have become mainstream consumer products, even if their prices remain out of reach for some consumers; final sales figures for holiday shopping season are not yet available, but industry analysts expect electronics to be among best-selling categories; photos (M)

headline: Milosevic's Lawyers Ask to Be Taken Off War Crimes Case
abstract: The lawyers who are defending Slobodan Milosevic have asked to be relieved of their duties, creating new hurdles for the troubled and drawn-out war crimes trial in The Hague.

headline: World Briefing | Middle East: Israel: Property Rights For Gay Couples
abstract: Jacob Galanti, Israel's Justice Min spokesman, says that Attorney General Menachem Mazuz will not challenge court decision to recognize same-sex couples in financial and property decisions (S)

headline: In Shift, Putin Says He Will Back Whomever Ukraine Elects
abstract: The Russian president made the comments only days after mocking a call for a new presidential runoff vote.

abstract: Dow Jones industrial average rises 69.98 for week, or 0.7 percent, to 10,592.21; Standard & Poor's 500-stock index gains 8.52 points, or 0.7 percent, to 1,191.17; Nasdaq composite index climbs 45.99 points on week, or 2.2 percent, to 2,147.96; yield on 10-year Treasury note rises slightly, to 4.25 percent, from 4.24 percent previous week; graphs; charts (M)

headline: Bryant Case Is New Quandary for Press
abstract: News organizations are grappling with whether to use name of woman accusing Kobe Bryant of sexual assault in light of Judge Richard Matsch's ruling that she must include her name in suit against him; several editors and news executives comment, interviews (M)

headline: Return That Ill-Fitting Gift? Maybe Not
abstract: Several top retailers, including Express, division of Limited Brands, KB Toys, Sports Authority, Staples and Guess, are using services of Return Exchange, company that uses its database to monitor returns and also flag some for denial; service has been criticized by consumer advocates who say it is form of blacklisting; Sen Charles E Schumer has asked Federal Trade Commission to investigate practice and has proposed legislation to require stores that limit returns to clearly warn shoppers before they make purchase; photo (M)

headline: F.D.A. Failing in Drug Safety, Official Asserts
abstract: FDA drug safety reviewer Dr David Graham tells Senate Finance Committee that regulators are 'virtually incapable of protecting America' from unsafe drugs and names five drugs now on market that should be 'seriously looked at'; Graham, twenty-year FDA veteran, denounces FDA as feckless and apt to surrender to drug makers, and fears 'drug safety catastrophe'; FDA drug evaluator Dr Steven Galson calls Graham's data irresponsible and deputy dir Dr Sandra Kweder says five drugs he cites are not 'more concerning than any others'; Graham questions cholesterol drug Crestor, pain pill Bextra, obesity pill Meridia, asthma drug Serevent and acne drug Accutane; all are defended by manufacturers; photo; chart on five drugs; panel chairman Charles Grassley is focusing on Merck's withdrawal of arthritis drug Vioxx after study found that heart attack risk doubles after 18 months of use; FDA critics say drug should have pulled much earlier, after 1999 and 2000 studies showed risk (M)

headline: Moves toward a more federal Europe may be out of step with voters' wishes : Despite EU victories, forces of disunity
Cable's Rivals Lure Customers With Packages
abstract: Telephone companies enter alliances with satellite providers to lure customers away from cable companies by bundling television with high-speed Internet service and telephone service; BellSouth and Verizon sell DirecTV service to their customers, and SBC Communications works with Dish Network and has even invested $500 million in its parent, EchoStar; three Bells have signed up 325,000 subscribers for satellite TV so far this year, most of them former cable companies; eight largest cable companies have lost 552,000 subscribers for basic cable service during first three quarters of year; cable companies are responding by promoting cable-only features like free video-on-demand, faster Internet connection speeds and cheap Web phone service; graphs (M)

headline: Technology Briefing | Software: Microsoft Announces Windows Licensing Plan
abstract: Microsoft announces licensing plan for Windows that could mean cost savings for coporate customers that upgrade to multicore computers when they become available starting in 2005 (S)

headline: Jailed in Israel, Palestinian Symbol Eyes Top Post
abstract: Most popular Palestinian candidate for new leadership is Marwan Barghouti, who is considering run for presidency of Palestinian Authority from Israeli jail cell where he is serving five life terms on terrorism conviction; photos; Barghouti, 45, speaks Hebrew and English and has sophisticated understanding of Israelis, both from stints in prison and from formerly close ties to Israeli politicians; Israeli remember him for support of two-state solution and speculation abounds that he could be released now, but that is considered unlikely because court found he has blood on his hands from attacks of recent years; Barghouti is leader in rising generation of Palestinians who grew up under Israeli occupation and came to admire aspects of Israeli democracy; his wife Fadwa, 40-year-old lawyer, voices commonplace complaints about corruption under Yasir Arafat (M)

headline: SBC in Deal With Microsoft to Provide TV on High-Speed Lines
abstract: SBC Communications plans to announce that it will pay $400 million to Microsoft for software used to deliver TV programming over high-speed data lines.

headline: World Business Briefing | Americas: Mexico: Concrete Maker's Profit Rises
abstract: Cemex, Mexican concrete maker, says it earned $361 million in third quarter, up from $140 million in period year earlier, on 12 percent increase in sales; graph (S)

headline: Killer of Journalists Sentenced to Death
abstract: Former Taliban fighter Reza Khan is sentenced to death in Kabul for his role in killing of foreign journalists Harry Burton, Maria Grazia Cutuli and Julio Fuentes and Afghan photographer Azizullah Haidari in November 2001; also was convicted of raping Cutuli before she was killed; Taliban members ambushed party on road between Kabul and Jalalabad shortly after Kabul fell (S)

abstract: John C Malone says his Liberty Media Corp might increase its stake in News Corp through complex stock swap (M)

abstract: The two leading Palestinian presidential candidates, Mahmoud Abbas and Marwan Barghouti, are in a statistical dead heat ahead of next month's election.

headline: Filthy Lucre in Luxor, or Why King Tut Stuck With the Gold Standard
abstract: Article on some precautions that should be taken when traveling to countries where personal hygiene is accomplished without intervention of paper products and paper money becomes breeding ground for some nasty germs; drawing (M)/

headline: New Image for a Wine Maker
abstract: Bolla is seeking to shed its staid image as classic Italian wine in favor of fresher , more informal approach; Brown-Forman Beverages, division of Brown-Forman Corp, is undertaking ambitious revival attempt; Price Weber produced $12 million ad campaign; photo (M)

headline: Drug Dispute Snags U.S.-Australia Pact
abstract: Dispute over prescription and generic drugs threatens to delay January 1 implementation of landmark US-Australian trade agreement; agreement, which promises $2 billion year in new industrial exports and possible creation of new jobs, has been dogged by disputes over ability of American pharmaceutical companies to challenge decisions about which drugs will be covered, and at what prices, under Australia's national health insurance program (M)

headline: The Fear Born of a Much Too Personal Look at Jihad
abstract: Doris Gluck is pseudonym of woman who recently published book in Germany, 'I Was Married to a Holy Warrior'; she describes how she fell in love with Egyptian, married him and then watched, appalled, as he became Islamic militant engaged in jihad; she is no longer married and is in witness protection program in Germany; photo (M)

headline: An Apology May Be Just the Start for Citibank Japan
abstract: BEFORE Citigroup's top executives came to Japan in October to apologize for the missteps that led regulators here to close its private banking group, they debated whether their chief executive, Charles O. Prince, should bow in public -- a common act of contrition in Japan, but one that may not have been well received in the United States.    In the end, Mr. Prince swallowed his pride, followed the custom and bent deeply from the waist, his eyes to the ground, after apologizing for several ethical lapses, including some that may have helped criminals to launder money. Industry experts here said that there was nothing else he could have done that would have helped more to restore the bank's reputation -- and to send a clear message that Citibank is in tune with customs and ready to follow them.

headline: Big Bets on Being Big and Widespread
abstract: Equity Office Properties Trust's chairman Sam Zell is sticking with nationwide strategy despite critics' contentions that company's performance for last few years has cast doubt on Zell's longtime motto that 'bigger is better'; Equity Office's returns during last three years have lagged all other real estate investment trusts, with average annual return of 6.7 percent; photo (M)

headline: World Briefing | Europe: Turkey: Objection To Europeans' New Conditions
abstract: In a rare show of unity, Turkey's president, prime minister, army chief and opposition party leader issued a strong joint protest against European Union moves to impose new conditions for the start of membership talks. They were reacting to the latest draft statement, prepared for the European leaders' Dec. 17 summit meeting in Brussels, which reportedly criticizes Turkey's record on torture and would set tougher standards for its entry to the European bloc than for other countries. France, Austria and the Netherlands, among others, have resisted issuing Turkey an invitation to begin negotiations. Their hesitation has fueled anger across Turkey, and the Turkish leaders, clearly irritated, suggested that the Europeans were treating them unfairly.   Susan Sachs (NYT)

Marks & Spencer, British Retailer, Sheds 6 Top Executives
abstract: Six top executives will leave British retailer Marks & Spencer as company reports plummeting profits and dip in sales in its home market in latest six-month period; company's six-member board is being pared to three: chief executive Stuart A Rose, Charles Wilson and new finance director; current finance director Alison Reed is stepping down after 20 years; other executives leaving are Maurice Helfgott, Mark McKeon, Laurel Powers-Freeling, Jean Tomlin and Jack Patterson; company says net income was down 40 percent, to 140 million pounds ($260 million) for six months ended September from year earlier; sales in Britain fell 0.4 percent, to 3.3 billion pounds; photo (M)

abstract: After years of debate and delay, the last concrete slab was put in place in Germany's Holocaust memorial in Berlin. The monument to the murdered Jews of Europe -- 2,751 concrete blocks on a five-acre site near the Brandenburg Gate -- will be officially opened by Chancellor Gerhard Schr√∂der in May.   Victor Homola (NYT)

abstract: General Motors continues to sell its 2004 Saturn Vue despite voluntary recall of about 25,000 vehicles in August after government tests showed Vue's suspension system collapsed during rollover testing; GM has sold more than 10,000 in last three months from dealer lots, and most of them were not fixed before they were sold; GM has fixed only few thousand of quarter-million existing Vue models because it takes time to procure new suspension parts for so many vehicles; 2005 models were fixed before they left factories; photos (M)

headline: Want to Profit From Vodka? Follow That Grey Goose
abstract: INSIDE one of Manhattan's monuments to vodka consumption, the Pravda bar in SoHo, Mike Lee orders a vodka on the rocks, letting the bartender choose among the esoteric collection of bottles lined up behind the bar.     Mr. Lee, 30, a stockbroker, usually drinks expensive vodkas like Belvedere, Chopin or the new Absolut brand, Level. But at Pravda, he can't order those mainstream brands.

headline: New Marketing Group Is Created at CBS
abstract: CBS Corp forms unit called CBS Marketing Group to oversee marketing across its divisions; George Schweitzer is named president of unit; Ron Scalera and Anne O'Grady are named executive vice presidents (S)

headline: Suicide Bomber Attacks Saudi Arabia's Interior Ministry
abstract: Militants apparently linked to Al Qaeda turn two neighborhoods of Riyadh, Saudi Arabia, into battle zones, with booby-trapped cars exploding outside landmark Interior Ministry and training center for Emergency Forces; seven militants responsible for car bombings are gunned down in police ambush, but final toll from all the attacks remains unclear; spokesman for ministry claims all injuries suffered are minor and only fatalities are militants; Prince Ahmed Abdel Aziz, deputy interior minister, goes on Saudi television to denounce attackers as criminals; effect of attacks is more psychological than physical; they show that militants are still capable of striking in very heart of capital despite 19-month, nationwide police crackdown that police claim has killed or captured three-quarters of most wanted terrorists inspired by al Qaeda and dismantled their networks; photo (M)

headline: ON ADVERTISING : Agencies home in on sponsoring
Mexico Arrests Man Suspected of Leading Drug Cartel's Assassins
abstract: The leader of a shadowy group of assassins who work for the Gulf drug cartel was arrested Friday in northern Mexico after a gunfight with federal agents that left two suspects and one law-enforcement agent dead, the attorney general of Mexico announced Friday afternoon.    The assassins' suspected chief, Rogelio Gonz√°lez Piza√±a, is also wanted in the United States, where he is accused of threatening agents from the Drug Enforcement Agency at gunpoint in 1999.

headline: Hong Kong leader vows to combat counterfeiting
Positive Economic Reports Push Share Prices Higher
abstract: Stocks rose yesterday as reports on personal income, consumer confidence and durable goods suggested the economy may sustain above-average growth through next year.    ''The trends supporting growth in the economy remain sound,'' said John Lynch, chief market strategist at Evergreen Investment in Charlotte, N.C., which manages $250 billion. ''We will probably see stocks gain into January.''

Mobile Carriers Move to Put Their Names on More Phones
abstract: United States cellphone operators, hoping to bolster their brands, are flirting with selling handsets that feature their names exclusively; move to exclude names of popular manufacturers follows trend in Asia and Europe; analysts say carriers want to better manage and tailor features and services on phones, gain leverage over phone makers and potentially cut costs; photo (M)

headline: On Turkey's EU fault lines
Some Hard-Liners in Turkey See Diversity as Divisive
abstract: Turkey defends individual freedom of worship but has long viewed its non-Muslim minorities with ambivalence; government tightly regulates affairs of religious institutions such as Greek Orthodox and Armenian churches; pressure from European Union is forcing Turkey to reassess policies; legal constraints have been relaxed on national level, but local officials may be reluctant to enforce changes; many people fear such action might endanger Turkey's secular foundations and promote separatism; photos (M)

headline: World Briefing | Middle East: Iran: 'Short' Nuclear Suspension Offered
abstract: Iran is willing to negotiate with Europe for a temporary suspension of its nuclear enrichment program, its top nuclear negotiator, Hassan Rowhani, said, but he ruled out a permanent suspension. ''If the question is that of a suspension for a short period, we can talk about it,'' he said on state television. ''But if the question is of depriving Iran of its rights, that is not negotiable.'' Britain, Germany and France are expected to offer Iran a package of economic incentives in the hope of persuading it to give up uranium enrichment, which Iran contends is for energy purposes.   Nazila Fathi (NYT)

headline: There Really Is No Business Like Show Business
abstract: Michael Ovitz, testifying at Disney shareholder lawsuit over his huge compensation, portrays Hollywood as place where agents and executives traffic in gossip, where money cements power and greases wheels of art and commerce and where intimidation and threats are cornerstone of deal-making; others in industry bristle at portrait, and it is not clear if Ovitz can mend his tattered image; photo (M)

headline: Letter from America : Navigating the straits of Senate confirmation
Back in Black
abstract: Nielsen/NetRatings finds record 13.3 million people visited online stores on Friday after Thanksgiving, up 11 percent from 2003 and 26 percent from previous Friday; EBay remains most popular Web site; graph of most popular sites; photos (S)

headline: In Northern Iraq, the Insurgency Has Two Faces, Secular and Jihad, but a Common Goal
abstract: After a three-hour firefight here in northern Iraq this month, American commanders were surprised to learn that one of the 22 insurgents they had killed was a Saudi. Even more intriguing, one of the principal leaders of the insurgency attended the funeral, the commanders learned.     This was Mohammed Sharkawa, who is described as a former member of the Ansar al-Sunna organization who now directs several hundred insurgents here in Mosul. As one commander, who said Mr. Sharkawa had killed several of his own cousins, put it, he is ''a brutally ruthless criminal, almost like a mob wiseguy who started whacking dudes.''

headline: ABBOTT TO ACQUIRE EAS FOR $320 MILLION
abstract: Abbott Laboratories acquires EAS, maker of diet and energy supplements, from North Castle Partners for about $320 million (S)

headline: Technology Briefing | Hardware: Samsung Sets Aside $100 Million For Price-Fixing Case
abstract: The Samsung Electronics Company, the world's largest maker of computer memory chips, said yesterday that it would set aside $100 million in relation to a federal investigation into reported industry price-fixing. Samsung Semiconductor, an American unit, will set aside the funds to cover possible losses from the results of the investigation, Samsung Electronics said in a regulatory filing. Samsung based in Suwong, South Korea, is not admitting guilt, a spokeswoman, Cho Sung In, said. The Justice Department inquiry is into whether Samsung Electronics and other makers of dynamic random access memory chips, or DRAM, conspired to fix prices.

abstract: Fannie Mae Board Ousts Top 2 Officials and Auditor  Under pressure from regulators, Fannie Mae forced out its chief executive, Franklin D. Raines, just days after the company was found to have violated accounting rules.    The chief financial officer of Fannie Mae, J. Timothy Howard, and the outside auditor, KPMG, are also leaving. [Page A1.]    U.S. Might Import Some Drugs  The Bush administration said that commercial importation of some low-cost prescription drugs from Canada might be feasible, but the savings to consumers would be small. [A1.]    Cablevision Delays Plan for Spinoff  Shares of Cablevision Systems rose 13 percent after the cable television provider suspended plans to spin off its media group, Rainbow Media Enterprises. The company, which had twice delayed the spinoff, said it would instead ''pursue strategic alternatives'' for the Rainbow group, which includes the Voom satellite television service. [C6.]    Newmont Mining Officials Warned  Top executives at Newmont Mining were warned in 2001 by an internal report that the company was putting tons of toxic mercury vapors into the air in Indonesia. [A1.]    Putin Sheds Light on Yukos Buyer  President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia said the buyers of the largest subsidiary of Yukos were private individuals but hinted that they would not have, or maintain, exclusive control over their new holding. [World Business, Page W1.]    2 Firms Report Strong Earnings  Morgan Stanley and Bear Stearns reported strong fourth-quarter profits, fueled by strong investment banking results. [C2.]    Tenet Settles Patient Lawsuits  Tenet Healthcare agreed to pay $395 million to settle litigation accusing one of its hospitals of performing unnecessary surgeries. [C10.]    Doubts Raised on United Air Plan  An official of the International Machinists and Aerospace Workers called the business plan United Airlines is using to line up post-bankruptcy financing unworkable. [C7.]    World Trade Group Backs U.S.  The World Trade Organization ruled that the European Union's system of protecting regional food names was exclusionary, backing complaints by the United States. [C10.]    Dow Surpasses June 2001 Closing  The Dow Jones industrial average hit a 31/2-year high, closing up 97.83 points, at 10,759.43. The Standard & Poor's 500 rose 10.80 points, to 1,205.45, and the Nasdaq composite index gained 23.06 points, to 2,150.91. [C7.]

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: DreamWorks Animation Raises $812 Million  DreamWorks SKG has priced shares of its animation unit above the level expected, raising $812 million in an initial public offering.      Heavy demand from investors for Dreamworks Animation SKG pushed the sale of 29 million shares to $28 a share, from an initial estimate of $23 to $25. Shares of Dreamworks Animation SKG will begin trading today under the symbol DWA on the New York Stock Exchange. Market Place. [Page C4.]    Ex-Macy's Chief to Head Penney  Myron E. Ullman III, left, a longtime retail executive who headed Macy's during its bankruptcy and recently led the luxury conglomerate LVMH Mo√´t Hennessy Louis Vuitton, will replace Allen I. Questrom as chief executive of J.C. Penney. His appointment leaves Vanessa Castagna, who had been the top internal candidate and who has been credited with leading many of the recent changes at Penney, without a clearly defined future. [C4.]    A Promising Therapy From Pfizer  Sildenafil citrate, the ingredient in Viagra, Pfizer's impotence pill, has proven effective in a clinical trial as a treatment for pulmonary arterial hypertension -- high pressure in the artery carrying blood to the lungs. [C8.]    Need for Oil Investment Cited  As high prices raise concerns about future supplies of oil, the International Energy Agency stressed the need for oil-producing countries and oil companies to increase their investments in finding and pumping oil. [C9.]    Systems for Auto Stability Helpful  A study by the Insurance Institute for Highway Safety found that the stability systems available in some cars and trucks can reduce the risk of getting in an accident. [C4.]    A Takeover Bid for Drug Company  The private equity unit of J.P. Morgan and the DLJ merchant banking group of Credit Suisse First Boston offered to acquire the Irish pharmaceutical company Warner Chilcott for ¬£1.62 billion ($3 billion). [C8.]    Earnings Soar 54% at Oil Company  ConocoPhillips reported a 54 percent increase in third-quarter profit as margins widened on diesel and other fuels and oil prices surged. Sales climbed 31 percent. The company expanded in countries with growing oil production, including Vietnam, Russia and Venezuela, as output declined from older fields in the United States and the North Sea. [C4.]    Profit rose 14 percent at Procter & Gamble on strong sales in all regions. [C2.]    Robust demand for military equipment and technology led Boeing and Northrop Grumman to post higher earnings. [C4.]    Comcast and Cox Communications reported strong profit and revenue growth because of growing demand for their digital video services and high-speed Internet connections. [C6.]    Kroll Offices in Brazil Raided  Police seized documents and arrested five people in a raid on the Brazilian offices of Kroll and a local private equity firm. [C8.]    Stocks Rally as Oil Prices Drop  Stocks rose sharply as investors expressed relief over a drop in oil prices. The Dow Jones industrial average gained 113.55 points, or 1.2 percent, to 10,002.03. The Standard & Poor's 500-stock index increased 14.31 points, or 1.3 percent, to 1,125.40; and the Nasdaq composite index jumped 41.20 points, or 2.1 percent, to 1,969.99. [C9.]    Moving Ideas Off Campus  In a financial bonanza for many universities, an increasing number of entrepreneurial students are helping commercialize technologies developed in their schools' laboratories. [C6.]    Where Are the Economists?  In the push for greater regulation after the corporate scandals, economists are notably absent. Jeff Madrick: Economic Scene. [C2.]

headline: Palestinians Worry About Cost of Peace
abstract: People of West Bank village of Jayyous take interest in Palestinian presidential election scheduled for Jan 9, but they are more absorbed with dramas of everyday Palestinian life: restricted access to water, land and livelihoods wherever Israeli separation barrier slices through West Bank; barrier cuts Jayyous off from 74 percent of its farmland and much of its well water; people of Jayyous can ouly reach their land through two Israeli checkpoints that are open for about an hour twice a day; each requires different permits, which must be renewed every six months and are usually denied to families of anyone who has been arrested; photos; map (L)

headline: For Africa's Poor, Pregnancy Is Often Life Threatening
abstract: Profile of Ethiopian woman Hiwot Taddessa, who was chosen at random along with five other pregnant women around globe in World Health Organization campaign to highlight dangers of pregnancy and childbirth and huge disparities in medical care worldwide from richest to poorest countries; 17-year-old Hiwot is unmarried and, statistically speaking, in group at greatest risk; other women being tracked are in Britain, Bolivia, Egypt, India and Laos; map; photo (M)

headline: An Interpublic Agency Loses Another Account
abstract: For the second time in three weeks, an advertising agency owned by the Interpublic Group of Companies has lost a large, longtime client in a consolidation.    Unilever said on Friday that it would consolidate its media planning and buying for Europe, with total spending estimated at $1.25 billion, at offices of MindShare, part of the WPP Group, which had handled the duties in Germany and Italy. Offices of the Initiative division of Interpublic had handled media planning and buying for Unilever in all other European markets.

headline: Dutch Soldiers Find Smiles Are a More Effective Protection
abstract: In a neighborhood here without lights, its pockmarked dirt streets and open sewers faintly visible under the full moon, the Dutch soldiers began a foot patrol on a recent evening. After getting out of their soft-top vehicles, the soldiers entered a street, wearing no helmets and pointing their guns down, chatting with Iraqis clustered in front of their homes.    ''Hello, Mister!'' some boys cried out, and they followed the soldiers to the bend in the road. Driving through the town later, the Dutch called out ''Salaam Aleikum'' to pedestrians. Many Iraqis, adults and children, waved at them.

headline: Fossils Found in Spain Seen as Last Link to Great Apes
abstract: Scientists in Spain discovered fossils of ape species from about 13 million years ago that they believe may have been last common ancestor of all living great apes, including humans; remains were found near Barcelona and named Pierolapithecus catalaunicus; drawing; Dr Salvador Moya-Sola describes find in journal Science (M)

headline: World Briefing | Europe: Spain: 13 New Suspects In Court Plot
abstract: The police arrested 13 men from Morocco and Algeria in connection with an alleged plot to blow up the national court in Madrid, the Interior Ministry said. The arrests follow the jailing over the past 10 days of 18 others linked to the plan, which the authorities say was organized by a cell of Islamic extremists. The government is seeking to extradite the suspected leader of the plot, Muhammad Achraf, believed to be an Algerian, from Switzerland, where he is being held.   Renwick McLean (NYT)

headline: Home Web Security Falls Short, Survey Shows
abstract: America Online and National Cyber Security Alliance study finds nation's Internet users are confused about computer security, 80 percent of their computers are infected with spyware and almost 20 percent of machines have viruses; finds 77 percent of those surveyed thought they were safe from online threats, while 67 percent did not have currently updated anti-virus software and two-thirds did not have firewall protection (M)

headline: Zimbabwe Extends Crackdown on Dissent as Election Looms
abstract: Political and human rights advocates in Zimbabwe cite growing suppression of civic life in country as Pres Robert Mugabe girds for national elections that his government cannot afford to lose; he and governing party have taken series of measures designed to minimize chances of another competitive ballot after coming unexpectedly close to being swept from office in parliamentary and presidential elections in 2000 and 2002; country's Parliament enacted legislation last month mandating two-year prison term for practicing journalism without license; second law makes it illegal to conduct voter education without government approval, requiring most election workers to register and clear electioneering materials with state; third law effectively places nongovernment groups, churches and charities under state control, empowering government to investigate their finances, to restrict their activities and, in many cases, to disband them at will; other restrictions include government monitoring and censoring of e-mail messages; photos; map (M)

headline: Japan's Troops Proceed in Iraq Without Shot Fired
abstract: Whenever a Japanese convoy leaves its base here in southern Iraq, the armored vehicles are so spotless that they appear to have just rolled out of a Tokyo car showroom into this crumbling Shiite Muslim town on the Euphrates.     They lack the dents and dirt of other nations' vehicles. Perhaps that is because of the Japanese troops' attention to maintenance or perhaps, as the Iraqis here say, their increasing tendency to stay inside their base with the violence rising outside.

headline: A Runaway Personifies Germany's 'Multi-Kulti' Debate
abstract: It would not seem, meeting her for the first time, that the young woman with a diamond nose stud and red cardigan was much different from any other teenager in Germany. But she has her own, difficult story.    She is 18 years old, living in a shelter whose address cannot be disclosed, having, in a cinematic episode, escaped from her Turkish-born parents. The reason, she said, was that they were threatening to kill her unless she agreed to marry a man from Turkey whom she had never met.

headline: China and Japan Jockey for Share of Russian Gas
abstract: In the latest jousting between China and Japan over Russia's energy riches, China is talking with the Exxon Mobil Corporation about buying gas from the Sakhalin Island field, which many Japanese assumed would power their nation for decades to come.    The gas talks come as China rues its loss of a Siberian oil pipeline that was once promised to run to Manchuria. Instead, Russian officials made clear this fall that the pipeline would go to a Russian port on the Sea of Japan. Russian leaders changed their minds after Japan's government offered billions of dollars to help finance the pipeline, which could be a $12 billion, 2,500-mile oil project running from Lake Baikal to Nakhodka.

headline: World Briefing | Europe: Ukraine: Putin Checks In Before Election
abstract: President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia will appear on Ukrainian television networks on Tuesday at the beginning of a three-day visit before the country's presidential election next Sunday. Supporters of Ukraine's leading opposition candidate, Viktor A. Yushchenko, have accused Mr. Putin of interfering in the election to replace President Leonid D. Kuchma. Mr. Putin has all but endorsed Mr. Kuchma's favored candidate, who has campaigned with promises of closer relations with Russia.   Steven Lee Myers (NYT)

abstract: U.S. marines and Iraqi soldiers found a massive supply of weapons that dwarfed any of the hundreds of caches yet found.

headline: World Briefing | Africa: Uganda: Government And Rebels In Talks
abstract: Peace talks began near the Uganda-Sudan border between the Ugandan government and an elusive rebel group called the Lord's Resistance Army, which has terrorized Ugandans for the last 18 years. The rebels, led by a mystic named Joseph Kony, have reinforced their ranks over the years by kidnapping children. The group's spokesman, Sam Kolo, told the government officials and journalists present: ''We could kill you all now for nothing but that's not our aim. We are committed to peace 100 percent.''   Marc Lacey (NYT)

headline: Entertainment Industry Asks Justices to Rule on File Sharing
abstract: Movie and music industries file petition asking Supreme Court to overturn federal appeals court decision that favored Grokster and StreamCast Networks, makers of software that allow users to trade copyrighted files; decision upheld notion that makers of technology with legal uses cannot be held liable because some-or even most--of its users deploy it to violate copyright; court relied on principles of 1984 Supreme Court decision known as Sony-Betamax case, which gave makers of electronic devices crucial legal protection against claims of copyright infringement; new petition argues appellate court misapplied Sony-Betamax decision (M)

headline: A Dinner in Ukraine Made for Agatha Christie
abstract: Mystery continues to surround poisoning of Ukrainian presidential candidate Viktor A Yushchenko, who is too busy campaigning for runoff election to cooperate with authorities; he is using poisoning almost as theme in his campaign, and has sought to meet with leaders of Security Service of Ukraine to discuss, among other things, death threats against him; it was at Sept 5 dinner meeting with Security Service leaders that he was allegedly fed food with dose of TCDD, most toxic of organic compounds known as dioxins; day after that dinner he was gravely ill, wracked with pain and his face erupting in grotesque mask of cysts; experts say dioxin is not known to act that fast; theories abound: he was poisoned by enemies in Pres Leonid D Kuchma's government, or by members of his own inner circle, or by Russia's intelligence services, or by organized crime figures working for any of above; although public attention remains focused on his late-night meal Sept 5, investigators say larger window of time needs to be examined; photos (M)

headline: Struggling, Nokia posts smaller net
Vivendi chief tries to recruit varied industries in creating global group : Diversity is new antipiracy strategy
BRISTOL-MYERS ASKS F.D.A. TO APPROVE DIABETES DRUG
abstract: The Bristol-Myers Squibb Company, the drug maker, said yesterday that it had asked federal regulators to approve its once-a-day diabetes drug. If the drug is approved, Bristol-Myers will sell it with Merck & Company. Both Bristol-Myers, based in New York, and Merck, based in Whitehouse Station, N.J., are hoping the drug, called muraglitazar, will help sales as competition increases for other medicines. The drug could have peak worldwide sales of more than $1 billion, John Boris, an analyst at Harris Nesbitt Gerard in New York, said last month. Merck agreed in April to pay Bristol-Myers as much as $375 million to share the rights to the drug. The companies said at the time that they planned to split costs and would jointly develop and sell the product. Merck is looking to make up sales lost when it withdrew Vioxx from the market.

abstract: Israeli Army kills nine Palestinians in Gaza Strip in on-going campaign to suppress firing of short-range Qassam rockets into Israel; Yasir Arafat and cabinet hold emergency session to denounce world's silence; Ministry of Health in Gaza says 56 Palestinians have died since Sept 29, though it is unclear how many were non-combatants (M)

headline: World Briefing | Africa: Sudan: Aid Worker Is Killed
abstract: Doctors Without Borders condemned the shooting death of one of its Sudanese relief workers in South Darfur. The worker was the second employee of the medical relief organization to be killed in the war-ravaged western region of Sudan in the last three months. The aid group said the latest killing occurred in the town of Labado during an attack led by government troops.   Marc Lacey (NYT)

headline: Wanted by the Police: A Good Interface
abstract: San Jose, Calif, police are having problems with new mobile dispatch system, including difficulties with user interface and lack of training officers; biggest misstep was that officers were not consulted in designing system; photo (M)

headline: Onetime Fugitive Gets 17 Years for Looting Insurers
abstract: Federal District Judge Ellen Bree Burns sentences Martin Franklin to term of 16 years and 8 months on fraud and racketeering charges in connection with looting of $200 million from insurance companies he owned; Franklin, who became international fugitive, apologizes in Greenwich, Conn, courtroom before sentencing (M)

headline: World Briefing | Middle East: Iran: Missile Test Before Talks
abstract: Defense Minister Ali Shamkhani said the country had again successfully tested its improved Shahab-3 ballistic missile. The missile can now hit targets as far as 1,250 miles away, putting all of Israel and parts of Europe in its range. The test came a day before negotiations in Vienna with several European nations over the country's nuclear program.   Nazila Fathi (NYT)

headline: Cellphone Unit Keeps Shoring Up Verizon
abstract: Verizon Communications said yesterday that profits in the third quarter grew meagerly as rising costs offset better-than-expected demand for its wireless and high-speed Internet services.     Verizon, the country's largest phone company, earned $1.8 billion, or 64 cents a share, in the third quarter, 0.5 percent more than in the same period a year earlier and in line with analysts' expectations. Sales rose 6.7 percent, to $18.2 billion, beating industry forecasts.

headline: LG.Philips to Spend $5.1 Billion on New Flat-Panel TV Factory
abstract: LGPhilips LCD Co, venture between LG Electronics of South Korea and Royal Philips Electronics of Netherlands, plans to spend record 5.3 trillion won ($5.1 billion) to build world's largest plant for flat-panel television sets; plant will begin producing 45,000 sheets of glass a month for 42-inch and 47-inch LCD sets beginning in first half of 2006, with production gradually increasing to capacity of 90,000 a month; photo (M)

headline: British Minister Who Resigned Is Cleared of Wrongdoing
abstract: David Blunkett was linked to a "chain of events" that hastened the approval of a visa for his ex-lover's nanny, a report released today concluded.

headline: Mortar attack hits Iraqi National Guard headquarters
World Briefing | Asia: China: 4 Imprisoned On Taiwan Spying Charges
abstract: China jailed four residents of Taiwan and one mainland Chinese accused of spying for Taiwan, state media said. The four, who were given terms of 7 to 10 years, were arrested this year in Zhejiang, a coastal province, and accused of working for Taiwan's intelligence agency. The arrests, which occurred as far back as August, may be in connection with statements by President Chen Shui-bian of Taiwan, who revealed detailed knowledge about the location and number of Chinese missile batteries aimed at the island, China's arch rival.   Joseph Kahn (NYT)

headline: Dassault shakes up Le Figaro's management
World Business Briefing | Asia: Japan: Interest Rate Kept Low
abstract: Bank of Japan decides to keep short-term interest rates at 0.001 percent to battle deflation and keep nation's economic recovery on track (S)

headline: World Briefing | Europe: Russia: A Pack Rat With Plutonium
abstract: Retired Soviet physicist Leonid Grigorov hands over eight small containers of plutonium-238 to Altai regional authorities after learning of reward being offered for weapons; holds he found material in laboratory scrap heap in 1997 or 1998 and has kept it in his garage; type of plutonium could be used in making dirty-bomb (S)

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: Merck Sets Up Bonus Plan For 230 Senior Executives  With its stock falling since it withdrew the arthritis drug Vioxx and its ability to thrive as an independent company uncertain, Merck has adopted a plan to give its executives a chance for bonuses if the company is taken over.    Merck said in a securities filing that its board had decided to give its 230 most senior managers the opportunity for a payment of up to three years of salary and bonus if another company buys Merck -- or merely buys more than 20 percent of its shares. [Page A1.]    Another Purchase by UnitedHealth  UnitedHealth said that it would buy Definity Health for $300 million. The acquisition was the latest move in the company's strategy of diversifying away from its signature managed care business. Earlier this year, UnitedHealth acquired Oxford Health Plans and Mid-Atlantic Medical Services. Shares of UnitedHealth are up 42.6 percent so far this year. Market Place. [C2.]    Traders Accused of False Reports  Five former traders for Reliant Energy, the El Paso Corporation and Dynegy were indicted on charges of reporting false trades to newsletters to manipulate natural gas prices. [C2.]    4 Studios Back DVD Format  A group of companies led by Toshiba made a major advance in the effort to define a new DVD standard as Paramount and three other Hollywood studios announced that they would release films in the group's high-definition DVD format by the end of next year. [C6.]    Witness Deferred to Eisner's Wish  Richard A. Nunis, a former director of Walt Disney, testified that he deferred to the decision of Michael D. Eisner in the firing of former president Michael Ovitz and in giving him a $140 million severance package. [C14.]    Bhopal Victims Not Fully Paid  Almost 20 years after a gas leak from a Union Carbide pesticide factory in Bhopal, India, that killed 7,000 people, the victims are poorly compensated and the companies have gone unpunished, a study by Amnesty International found. [World Business, Section W.]    Kellogg Picks Director as Chief  James M. Jenness, left, was named chairman and chief executive of Kellogg to succeed Carlos M. Gutierrez, who was nominated by President Bush to be commerce secretary. Mr. Jenness has been a Kellogg director since 2000 and serves as head of the board's consumer-marketing committee. He was once a vice chairman and chief operating officer of the Leo Burnett Company. [C4.]    Editor of Le Monde Steps Down  The editor in chief of Le Monde, Edwy Plenel, resigned from the paper, which has been struggling with a downturn in advertising and circulation. [World Business, Section W.]    Wal-Mart Appeals Earlier Ruling  Wal-Mart Stores asked an appeals court to overturn a ruling allowing 1.6 million women workers seeking back pay to sue the company for discrimination as a group. [C12.]    S.&P. and Dow Fall; Nasdaq Gains  The Standard & Poor's 500-stock index fell 4.08 points, to 1,178.57, on disappointing November sales at Wal-Mart. The Dow Jones industrial average lost 46.33 points, to 10,475.90. The Nasdaq composite gained 4.90 points, to 2,106.87, after three analysts raised their share-price forecast for Apple Computer, the maker of iPod digital music players. headline: Britain's Not-So-Civil War: Hunters Outfoxed?
abstract: Blencathra hunt in Threlkeld, in English Lake District, faces its end in two years as result of Parliamentary vote in Sept to ban hunting with dogs; chief huntsman Barry Todhunter says hunters are now quarry of opponents who would overturn centuries of tradition; photos; map (M)

headline: US Airways' Agents Approve a Pay Cut
abstract: The customer service and reservation agents of the US Airways Group have approved a 13 percent pay cut and the elimination of some jobs to save the carrier $137 million a year and help avoid liquidation.    The agreement was approved by 60 percent of the workers who voted, the Communications Workers of America said yesterday. The accord also reduces holidays and pension benefits, and offers as much as $20,000 to workers with at least five years' service who agree to leave the company early.

headline: Two explosions rock a cafe and market in Baghdad's Green Zone
Command Demystifies Missing Music Files
abstract: Q. I have some songs that play fine with the iTunes program, but when I look for the song files on my hard drive, I can't find them. How can I find these files?    A. Apple's iTunes for Windows and Macintosh is a versatile music-management program that can do everything from converting songs from CD's to computer-friendly digital audio files to loading up your iPod and printing fancy jewel-case covers for homemade mixes you make for friends and loved ones.    Although iTunes keeps its own default folder to store the audio files you make from CD's or for tracks you purchased from the online iTunes Music Store, the files do not have to be in this folder for iTunes to display or play them. That makes it possible for songs all around your hard drive to be listed in your iTunes database, regardless of whether they reside in the iTunes Music folder.

abstract: Verizon Wireless will pay $3 billion in cash for spectrum licenses owned by NextWave Telecom, move that should allow it to sign up new subscribers in 23 markets, including New York, Boston, Washington and Los Angeles; licenses will also give company greater ability to compete with Cingular Wireless (S)

headline: Pakistan Bans Public Meetings After 40 Die in a Car Bombing
abstract: Pakistani authorities announce nationwide ban on all political and religious meetings except Friday Prayer two days after car bombing in Multan that killed 40 people and wounded 100, and eight days after suicide bombing in Shiite mosque in Sialkot that killed 31 people; country has been racked by sectarian violence in recent years; officials are trying to play down sectarian aspects of these attacks, branding them as acts of terrorism aimed at destabilizing country (M)

headline: Iran Votes to Resume Nuclear Work
abstract: Hard-line Iranian Parliament unanimously approves bill supporting resumption of uranium enrichment; talks with European countries over Iran's nuclear activities have so far failed to produce agreement; speaker of Parliament says vote is message to world that Parliament will not give in to coercion, but political analysts say Parliament's action is largely symbolic; photo (M)

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: Ford Makes a Deal To Put Sirius in More Cars  Ford plans to announce today that it will offer Sirius Satellite Radio in more of its cars and trucks and that it will begin installing the systems at the factory. After more than two years of taking a backseat to XM, Sirius appears to be on the rise. Earlier this month, Howard Stern signed a deal to broadcast on Sirius.

abstract: US Commerce Dept reports that factory orders declined 0.4 percent in September, second consecutive monthly decline; back-to-back declines are first since Nov-Dec 2002 (S)

headline: Marsh Waited Far Too Long Before Starting 2-Minute Drill
abstract: Months of high-level fumbling at Marsh & McLennan in dealing with investigation by New York State Atty Gen Eliot Spitzer transformed what could have been manageable, though painful, scandal into all-out corporate crisis; internal struggles continued until last moment before decision to remove Jeffrey W Greenberg as chief executive; initial discussions among independent directors to bring in a Marsh executive as new leader were abandoned when they learned that Michael G Cherkasky, company executive who had no insurance background and was Spitzer's former boss, might resign if he was not selected for job; Marsh announces series of corporate reforms (Market Place column) (M)

headline: Creditors Devise Fallback Plan if Adelphia Assets Aren't Sold
abstract: Unsecured creditors of Adelphia Communications Corp, which is trying to sell its assets, say they had preliminary agreement on plan to overhaul company once it emerges from bankruptcy, in case they are not satisfied with offers from potential suitors; under plan, all unsecured creditors would receive common stock in new company (M)

headline: Business Index for Midwest Points to a Modest Slowdown
abstract: An index of Midwest business activity fell for a second consecutive month in December, a sign of slower growth in manufacturing.    The National Association of Purchasing Management-Chicago said yesterday that its business barometer declined to 61.2 this month, from 65.2 in November. Readings higher than 50 indicate growth.

abstract: Ryanair, the Irish discount airline, reported a 15 percent increase in half-year profit, to 201.3 million euros ($255 million) on revenue of 721.1 million euros ($915 million), beating analysts' expectations. The chief executive, Michael O'Leary, left, said that revenue earned from each passenger carried fell 5 percent in the six months to the end of September and would drop another 5 to 10 percent in the next two quarters.   Brian Lavery (NYT)

headline: Israel Frees 159 Prisoners In a Gesture Of Good Will
abstract: Israel frees 159 Palestinian prisoners, calling move gesture to Egyptian Pres Hosni Mubarak for freeing Israeli convicted of spying and imprisoned in Egypt; action is also seen as Israel's modest good will offering directed toward Mahmoud Abbas, favorite to win Jan 9 presidential election to replace Yasir Arafat as leader of Palestinian Authority; Abbas welcomes Israeli move while calling for release of thousands more Palestinians who remain jailed; another presidential candidate, Mustafa Barghouti, is briefly detained by Israeli police while campaigning in East Jerusalem; this is his third confrontation with Israeli security forces at checkpoints in West Bank; photo (M)

headline: Nigeria unrest drives oil higher
Fatah Arrayed Against Candidacy of Jailed Palestinian
abstract: Senior Palestinian figures in main political group, Fatah, close ranks against presidential candidacy of Marwan Barghouti, who is serving five life sentences in Israeli prison; even prominent younger Fatah militants of Al Aksa Martyrs Brigade who once saw him as their leader now criticize him for putting himself above Palestinian unity; furor is indicative of concern in Palestinian and Arab establishment that Barghouti victory would dash new optimism about progress in peace talks between Israel and Palestinians; photo (M)

headline: Dressing Down Tommy Hilfiger
abstract: MICK JAGGER was there that night in 1996, watching the cheering boys with dreadlocks and the girls in shirts embroidered with the enigmatic logo that Tommy Hilfiger created a decade before, when he was still a nobody. The rock star was among hundreds of people gathered in a tent near Lincoln Center to see Mr. Hilfiger, the charismatic clothier from Elmira, N.Y., receive the Menswear Designer of the Year award from the Council of Fashion Designers of America.    Back then, everything in the world seemed to be going Tommy's way. ''There were these city kids, along on this magical ascent, because Tommy had crossed the barriers -- he'd crossed both racial and demographic barriers,'' said Joseph Abboud, the clothing designer and a friend of Mr. Hilfiger, who was there that night. ''Tommy had become the darling, he was at the pinnacle; he had transcended the whole preppy-Ivy League-Ralph Lauren-wannabe image to create a whole new paradigm of what the market looked like.''

headline: S.E.C. Suit Accuses Company of Failing to Oversee Broker
abstract: Raymond James Financial Services Inc, its former president, J Stephen Putnam, and former branch manager, David L Ullom, are sued by SEC for failing to supervise Dennis S Herula, broker accused of cheating investors; SEC accuses company of fraud in connection with actions by Herula (S)

headline: Broker Who Aided U.S. Going on Trial for Fraud
abstract: Anthony Elgindy, formerly known as Amr Ibrahim Elgindy, who has served as government informant in some penny stock fraud cases, is set to go on trial on charges of conspiring with FBI agent to get data about government probes and using data to manipulate stock prices; is also charged with using data to extort money from companies; case has attracted attention because his efforts to sell stock on Sept 10, 2001, based on his alleged prediction that stock prices would collapse, raised concern that he had advance knowledge of Sept 11 attacks; FBI agent Jeffrey A Royer will be tried with him; Jonathan Daws, former FBI agent Lynn Wingate and Troy M Peters will be tried separately in case; photo (M)

headline: Best Buy Drops Ernst & Young as Auditor Over Link to Board

headline: Anti-French Riots Fade in Ivory Coast but Foreigners Flee Nation
abstract: Ivory Coast government loyalists end rioting in Abidjan after four days; French citizens, who have been targeted for much of violence, are being flown out on French government-chartered Air France planes and Col Henri Aussavy, French military spokesman in Abidjan, says more flights are scheduled for tomorrow; other countries and United Nations are helping other foreigners leave, if they want to go; violence erupted after government bombed French military base and killed nine peacekeepers and French retaliated by destroying government military aircraft; South African Pres Thabo Mbeki requests that UN Security Council give African Union time to help resolve crisis; council is discussing proposal that would impose embargo and other sanctions on Dec 10, if Ivory Coast rebels and government do not adhere to 2003 peace accord (S)

headline: Key oil producers vow to expand production
BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: 2 Top Officials at Marsh And Counsel Step Down  Two of the highest ranking executives of Marsh & McLennan's insurance brokerage business and the company's general counsel were forced out.    Roger E. Egan, the president of Marsh Inc., and Christopher M. Treanor, the chairman of Marsh Inc. and chief executive of Global Placement, the section of the brokerage business that has been the focus of a lawsuit by Eliot Spitzer, resigned. William L. Rosoff, who has been general counsel of the parent company, also stepped aside. [Page C2.]    H&R Block Accused by NASD  The NASD accused H&R Block of defrauding individual investors by selling them $16 million worth of bonds in Enron in the five weeks before it collapsed. The securities regulator said about 200 brokers at H&R Block Financial Advisors sold the bonds to 820 customers in 40 states without telling them about the high risk. [C12.]    Ex-Enron Officials Want Trial Moved  Lawyers for three of Enron's most senior former managers want to move their trial out of Houston. The managers are Jeffrey Skilling, Enron's former chief executive; Kenneth L. Lay, its former chairman, and Richard L. Causey, its former chief accounting officer. [C12.]    An Incomplete N.F.L. TV Package  For the first time in its history, the N.F.L. concluded only part of its next long-term television deal, settling its Sunday afternoon packages with Fox and CBS through the 2011 season, but leaving its prime time and cable packages unresolved. [D1.]    Exchanges Face New S.E.C. Rules  The Securities and Exchange Commission is expected to propose rules today to improve governance standards at the nation's leading stock exchanges. [C6.]    New Jersey Votes to Shift Pensions  The governing council for New Jersey's state pension fund voted to shift to a more aggressive investment strategy that would give some responsibility for investing the fund to outside money managers. [C2.]    America Online Chief Reorganizes  Jonathan Miller of America Online plans to create three units: content and advertising, Internet access and fee-based services. [C4.]    S.E.C. May Sue Ex-Lucent Officials  Lucent Technologies said that the Securities and Exchange Commission was considering suing three former executives over possible violations of the Foreign Corrupt Practices Act. The executives include Richard A. McGinn, left, the former chairman, and John Heindel, who ran Lucent's operations in Saudi Arabia. A third was not named. [C4.]    Panel Requests Computer Financing  A panel of computer scientists warned that unless the government significantly increased support for advanced research on supercomputing, the United States would be unable to retain its lead on that technological front. [C4.]    No Outside Opinion at Disney  The former board member of Walt Disney who negotiated a $140 million termination package for Michael Ovitz, testified that he never sought an outside legal opinion on whether Disney could fire Mr. Ovitz for cause. [C10.]    Boston Law Firm in Merger Deal  Ropes & Gray, one of Boston's most prominent law firms, is acquiring Fish & Neave. [C6.]    Stocks Mixed on Profit Taking  The S.&P. 500 fell 1.28 points, to 1,164.89; the Dow Jones industrials gained 3.77 points, to 10,391.31; and the Nasdaq composite inched up 0.31 point, to 2,039.25. [C14.]    Getting Too Familiar at Airports  Many female travelers do not like the new airport security procedures and intimate pat-downs. Joe Sharkey: On the Road. [C9.]

headline: In Russia, Dissent Grows Over Moves to Curb Autonomy
abstract: Pres Vladimir V Putin's plan to concentrate still more power in Kremlin inflames fierce popular discontent in regions of country that stand to lose most; in Cheboksary, capital of republic of Chuvashia, people fear that Kremlin is planning further steps to recreate Soviet-like power over people; polls suggest seething discontent in this and 20 other ethnic republics that achieved measure of autonomy since Soviet Union disbanded; Putin has defended his plan by saying he wants to unify Russia against threat of terror; many warn that it could have opposite effect, stoking ethnic divisions that in an extreme case dragged Chechnya, another of republics, into more than decade of bloodshed; photo; map (M)
