headline: Safire to End Column
abstract: William Safire's column has appeared on the Op-Ed Page of The New York Times for more than 30 years.

headline: Losses at Delta Renew Bankruptcy Speculation
abstract: Delta Air Lines said today that it expected to lose as much as $675 million for the third quarter.

headline: Italy revels in yearly calendar war
World Briefing | Africa: Zimbabwe: Opposition Leader Wants Elections Postponed
abstract: The leader of Zimbabwe's only opposition party, Morgan Tsvangirai, called for President Robert Mugabe to postpone national elections scheduled for March, saying needed democratic safeguards could not be in place in time to ensure a free and fair vote. Mr. Tsvangirai has vowed that his party will sit out elections until Zimbabwe meets voting standards set by the Southern Africa Development Community earlier this year. At a news conference in Johannesburg, Mr. Tsvangirai also gave a muted endorsement of efforts by South Africa's president, Thabo Mbeki, to close the bitter divide between Mr. Mugabe's government and the opposition, saying that his view of Mr. Mbeki had improved after meeting privately with him this week.   Michael Wines (NYT)

headline: French Play Down Report of Bribes in Iraq Scandal
abstract: France reacts cautiously to suggestions by top United States arms inspector for Iraq Charles Duelfer that French officials and business executives accepted bribes from Saddam Hussein as he sought to ease crippling United Nations sanctions against his country; report cites former Iraqi deputy prime min Tariq Aziz as saying that French government recipients of $1 million in cash understood that they were expected to make efforts to lift UN sanctions (M)

headline: Ukraine's Election Crisis Has Had Dim Mirror Images in Other Former Soviet Republics
abstract: Many former Soviet republics have seen accusations of election improprieties similar to those in Ukraine, although reactions have been more muted; elections in Azerbaijan, Kazakhstan and Belarus recalled; photos (M)

headline: Falluja Assault Roils Iraqi Politics
abstract: The country's most prominent Sunni political party said today that it was withdrawing from the interim Iraqi government, and the leading group of Sunni clerics called for Iraqis to boycott the upcoming elections.

headline: Bosnian Serbs express 'sincere regrets' for Srebrenica massacre
Mercedes Looks to Chief to Restore Its Prestige
abstract: Eckhard Cordes, the man DaimlerChrysler picked to put the luster back into Mercedes-Benz, has slipped out of the office during his first week on the job, joining colleagues in the Alps along the Swiss-Austrian border to test-drive cars made by the competition.    It is a handy way for Mr. Cordes to escape, at least briefly, the scrutiny that comes with running Germany's most famous carmaker. Few jobs in German industry carry more cachet -- or loftier expectations.

headline: HUBBELL PLACES CHIEF FINANCIAL OFFICER ON PAID LEAVE
abstract: Hubbell, a maker of electrical products, said its chief financial officer, William T. Tolley, had been placed on paid administrative leave amid an investigation into a restatement of his former employer's financial results in 2000. Mr. Tolley received a letter from the Securities and Exchange Commission that said the agency's staff was recommending that a civil injunction action be filed for violations of federal securities laws, the company said in an S.E.C. filing. The investigation does not involve Hubbell, the company said. Mr. Tolley is the former chief financial officer of the Chesapeake Corporation, which reduced 2000 earnings by $5.4 million because of accounting errors. Hubbell, based in Orange, Conn., named its chief accounting officer, Gregory F. Covino, as in interim successor to Mr. Tolley. Mr. Tolley could not be reached for comment.

headline: Henkel selling back Clorox to pay for Dial
Stocks rise after Bush victory
Many See Hope in Parkinson's Drug Pulled From Testing
abstract: Amgen, biotechnology company, earlier in year withdrew experimental drug for Parkinson's disease called glial cell line-derived neurotrophic factor (GDNF) because of safety issues; says drug had not proved better than placebo; Amgen's move has provoked outcry from some patients who say company is robbing them of their only hope; story of Amgen's drug shows clash between faith of patients and cold logic of science and business; photo of Steve Kaufman, Parkinson's patient who says he was making progress with GDNF (M)

headline: Fewer Cellular Carriers, but Not Fewer Services
abstract: Rapid consolidation in mobile phone industry, as illustrated by last week's proposed merger of Nextel and Sprint and Cingular's recent acquisition of AT&T Wireless, raises question of whether fewer carriers means shift in power away from consumers; industry analysts and executives argue there is still plenty of competition between remaining providers and number of regional companies to ensure that consumers not only have ample choices, but also receive better service and prices (M)

headline: Comic Books of the West Head East

headline: The Fallout From Celebrex
abstract: Announcement by Pfizer that patients in cancer study who used widely prescribed painkiller Celebrex had heightened incidence of heart attacks leaves lawyers wondering whether legal troubles will match those of Merck, which withdrew Vioxx on September 30; lawyers say case against Pfizer does not appear as strong because major clinical studies suggest that Celebrex does not pose as great a risk as Vioxx; photos; graphs (M)

headline: Supporters of President-Elect in Ukraine Push Back
abstract: Regional leaders supporting the embattled president-elect signaled an intention for the eastern section of the country to seek autonomy if the impasse persists.

headline: In the Air: Shopping, Shopping Everywhere
abstract: Article on new age in retail as shoppers are offered wide variety of points of sale--from traditional stores, huge malls and box stores and surfing the Web to ordering from television and perusing catalogs; photos (Special section, Retail) (L)

headline: DANA REDUCES SALE PRICE OF ITS AUTO PARTS UNIT
abstract: Dana Corp reduces acquisition price of its automotive replacement-parts business, which is being bought by Affinia Group, to $1.02 billion (S)

headline: Many in Europe See U.S. Vote as a Lose-Lose Affair
abstract: Many Germans fear for American-European relations, no matter who wins presidential election; reasoning is that if Pres Bush wins, it would be seen as bad judgment of American electorate, and if Sen John Kerry wins, he will ask Germany and France to come to aid of United States in Iraq, they will refuse, and Americans will feel angry and betrayed; animating idea in Europe is that whoever is elected, future of world depends on continuation of healthy relations between America and Europe and common appreciation of bedrock values of their alliance (M)

headline: Times Co. Posts Decline in Earnings in 3rd Quarter
abstract: New York Times Co says earnings in third quarter fell 3.7 percent; net income was $48.3 million, down from $50.1 million year ago; revenue rose 1.9 percent, to $773.8 million, from $759.3 million year earlier; advertising revenue rose 3.7 percent, from $480.4 million to $498.2 million; chief operating officer Janet L Robinson comments (M)

headline: PeopleSoft Shareholders Have Opposing Views on Oracle Bid
abstract: Capital Guardian Trust, which owns about 5.9 perent of PeopleSoft's stock tells Oracle Corp that it has decided to accept its takeover bid for PeopleSoft and tender all its shares; Private Capital Management, which has 9.3 percent of PeopleSoft's shares, says it will not tenders its shares to Oracle; Paulson & Co will tender its 9.1 million PeopleSoft shares, or roughly 2.4 percent of all outstanding shares (M)

headline: Violence in Ivory Coast
abstract: Ivory Coast jets attacked French forces, killing nine peacekeepers and an American civilian. The French later destroyed the aircraft, apparently at the order of President Jacques Chirac.     Article, Page 22.

abstract: AT&T will introduce local phone service that routes calls over Internet; residential plan will cost $19.99 per month for unlimited local calls; customers who make additional local toll and long-distance calls in US and Canada will be charged 4 cents per minute; service begins Oct 17 (S)

Hungary Joins Others in Pulling Troops From Iraq
abstract: Hungary announces that it will withdraw its 300 troops from Iraq, becoming latest country in United States-led coalition to bow to public pressure and prepare to bring its soldiers home; 32 countries have provided 22,000 soldiers as part of multinational force established by United States to stabilize postwar Iraq; over last few months several countries have withdrawn; some cite cost but others voice concern about security; many governments face increasing public opposition to war; two large contributors to international force--Britain and Italy--insist they will not withdraw (M)

headline: Annan Says His Son's Payments Created a 'Perception Problem'
abstract: United Nations Secretary General Kofi Annan says he did not know his son Kojo continued receiving payments until Feb 2004 from Cotecna Inspection Services, Swiss company being investigated for suspected fraud and abuses in oil-for-food program in Iraq; denies any wrongdoing; Cotecna spokesman says company made payments to Kojo Annan after he left firm to prevent him from working for its competitors; says such 'noncompete' payments are required by Swiss law (M)

abstract: Roundup of week's performance in stock markets and other economic sectors; graphs

headline: $10 for a Plain CD or $32 With the Extras
abstract: Record companies, while continuing to discount new releases to combat file-sharing and widespread CD-burning, are also offering some big titles in more costly special editions to expand top end of market; such editions come with everything from hard cover books to T-shirts; sales graph; photos (M)

headline: Pfizer Says It Will Do Study of Possible Benefits of Celebrex
abstract: Pfizer said today that it would sponsor a major clinical trial of Celebrex, its prescription arthritis pain medication, to assess the cardiovascular benefits of the drug.

headline: Gaullist Party Chooses a New Leader With Presidential Ambitions
abstract: French Finance Min Nicolas Sarkozy becomes leader of country's dominant political party, Union for a Popular Movement; post seen as important step toward fulfillment of his avowed presidential aspirations (M)

headline: A Down-Market Publisher Dresses Up
abstract: Bauer Publishing USA, Heinrich Bauer division that produces mass magazines at low prices aimed at grocery shoppers in Middle America, is set to begin publishing celebrity fashion weekly, Life & Style; new magazine's calmer layouts and product-focused features are clear bid to entice advertisers that have shunned company's In Touch despite celebrity magazine's strong sales; president Hubert Boehle comments; photos (M)

headline: France and Germany Get Deficit Reprieve
abstract: European Commission freezes threat of fines against France and Germany, granting two biggest economies in euro zone extra year to bring down their bloated budget deficits; decision will help heal relationship between European Union's executive arm and finance ministers of member states, which has been tense since commission first tried to punish France and Germany year ago for failing to play by budget rules; Joaquin Almunia, economic and monetary affairs commissioner, says France and Germany must make structural changes, not quick fixes; photo (M)

Louvre forges new links with U.S. museums
French merger push risks German anger
With Steel Prices Climbing, Bankrupt Producer Gets Bids
abstract: Soaring world steel prices ignite bidding war for bankrupt Stelco, Canada's largest steel maker; photo; Severstal of Russia makes bid to expand North America operations, with other offers also on table; Stelco at same time reports record profits, which may encourage shareholders to overturn bankruptcy altogether (M)

headline: Turks Worry That a Union With Europe Will Cost Them Their Soul
abstract: Many Turks, while aware of economic benefits of joining European Union, bridle at constant flow of outside criticism and analysis that have come with their application, and at storm of public opposition in Europe; Europe has long been Turkey's obsession, firing desires of Ottoman sultans and portrayed as model of civilization, but prospect of membership also sets Turks on soul-searching analysis of where they belong and what they want; Nahit Koran, powerful hereditary landlord in ancient Anatolian heartland, expresses fear of many about loss of sovereignty, and objects to European countries with barbaric background telling Turks how to live; photos; map (M)

headline: Singapore recovery hits a speed bump
World Business Briefing | Australia: Trade Gap Widens
abstract: Australia's trade deficit widened in Sept to 2.11 billion Australian dollars ($1.57 billion) as 5 percent rise in imports outpaced 4 percent rise in exports (S)

headline: World Briefing | Europe: Belgium: Arrest In Threat Against Lawmaker
abstract: Belgian police arrest Muslim convert for allegedly sending death threats to Senator Mimount Bousakla, who has been critical of fundamentalist Muslims; suspect, who news agencies say confessed to sending threats, is member of European Arab League, small Islamic party in Anvers (S)

headline: Yahoo Tripled Profits in Quarter, Thanks to Google Shares
abstract: Yahoo continued to ride growth of online advertising in third quarter, but more than half its profit in quarter came from success of its rival Google; reports profit of $253 million, nearly three times figure from year earlier; of that, $129 million came from its sale of Google shares during that company's initial public offering and tax breaks associated with sale; earned $124 million in quarter; revenue was $655 million, up 84 percent (M)

headline: Southwest Offers $100 Million for ATA Assets
abstract: Southwest Airlines proposes $100 million deal for some assets of bankrupt ATA Airlines; offer is $10 million more than bid by AirTran Airways before ATA filed for bankruptcy protection; Southwest move is sign of competition that is emerging in industry's low-fare segment (M)

headline: Israeli Parliament Votes Its Displeasure With Sharon's Plan for a Gaza Pullout
abstract: Prime Min Ariel Sharon's plan to withdraw Jewish settlers from Gaza Strip suffers symbolic setback when Parliament votes to reject speech in which he raises proposal; vote is nonbinding, but it demonstrates tough opposition he is facing; Sharon might fare better when actual vote on Gaza proposal is held in Parliament on Oct 25; if he does not win passage of Gaza initiative, it would bode ill for survival of his coalition government; photo (M)

abstract: Vivendi Universal reports third-quarter earnings of 776 million euros ($1 billion) and 6 percent increase in revenue, to 4.7 billion euros (S)

Fuel Efficiency
abstract: New Embraer 170-passenger jet has been burning 2 percent less fuel than predicted before plane went into commercial use in March; Internal Revenue Service says business travelers will be able to deduct 40.5 cents for each mile driven on business in 2005, compared with 37.5 cents in 2004; Shanghai officials say number of foreign visitors to city this year will double from last year, to four million; PKF Hospitality Research says average room rates in top 50 domestic hotel markets increased 4 percent this year, and they are expected to rise 4.7 percent in 2005; biggest increases will be in New York City, where cost of room is expected to rise 13.7 percent, to $236.97; imminent sharp reduction of operations by Delta Air Lines at Dallas-Fort Worth International Airport will cost North Texas region 7,000 jobs and about $800 million a year in revenue (Memo Pad column) (M)

headline: U.S. Cutting Food Aid Aimed at Self-Sufficiency
abstract: Bush administration is reducing its contributions to global food aid programs in face of growing budget deficit growing and Pres Bush's promise to reduce spending; tells represesntatives of several charities that it is unable to honor some earlier promises and will have money to pay for food only in emergency crises like that in Darfur, in western Sudan (M)

headline: World Briefing | Europe: Risk Of Heat Waves Rising With Emissions
abstract: Oxford University and Hadley Center for Climate Prediction and Research team predicts in journal Nature that global buildup of greenhouse gas emissions has at least doubled chance that Europe will have another record-breaking heat wave this summer (S)

headline: Rebels Loyal to Shiite Cleric Begin Handing In Arms in Iraq
abstract: The surrender of arms is part of a deal struck with the Iraqi government and the American military to end months of fighting.

abstract: Deloitte & Touche is expected to be named Fannie Mae's new auditor, replacing KPMG, which was dismissed after 35 years, according to a person who had been briefed on the search process.    However, that person cautioned that a final decision had not yet been made.

headline: 3 Iraqis Held in Germany on Evidence Linked to Plot to Assassinate Allawi During His Visit
abstract: Pentagon investigation of interrogation techniques at military detention centers in Cuba, Afghanistan and Iraq concludes that senior defense officials exercised little or no oversight of interrogation policies outside of Guantanamo Bay, leaving field commanders to develop some practices that were unauthorized; inquiry by Vice Adm Albert T Church, naval inspector general, finds that by Jan 2003, military interrogators in Afghanistan were using techniques similar to those that Defense Sec Donald H Rumsfeld had approved for use only at Guantanamo Bay; photo (M)

abstract: Warren Buckleitner roundup of simulation games; photos (M)

headline: World Briefing | Americas: Honduras: Leader Blames Gangs For Attack
abstract: President Ricardo Maduro blamed street gangs for an armed attack on a public bus last week that left 28 people dead. At least three suspected members of the feared Mara Salvatruchas were detained over the weekend in connection with the attack, as hundreds of police officers and soldiers conducted raids on poor neighborhoods in the northern city of San Pedro Sula and the central province of Comayagua, where authorities believe the attack was planned. Armando Calidonio, the vice minister of security, said another six people were detained for belonging to gangs but had so far not been linked directly to the latest violence. President Maduro has said the gangs hoped the violence would intimidate his government, which last year approved laws that punish gang members with up to 12 years in jail.   Ginger Thompson (NYT)

headline: BOOK REPORT : The guru's last crusade

abstract: Nat Ives Advertising column on Procter & Gamble's experimental promotion for its Secret Sparkle deodorant using music stars' personal profiles on Myspace.com networking Web site; home page features profile of singer Hillary Duff accompanied by logos for deodorant; photo (M)

headline: Settlements Seen in U.S. Inquiries Into Time Warner
abstract: Time Warner is expected to announce a settlement with the Justice Department in its investigation of advertising deals between America Online and smaller Internet companies that may have allowed America Online to exaggerate its growth, an official close to the case said yesterday. The announcement could come as early as today.    The company may also announce a tentative agreement with the enforcement division of the Securities and Exchange Commission, which is conducting a separate investigation into accounting irregularities at America Online, the official said. Time Warner is expected to pay $500 million to $600 million to settle all civil and criminal accusations with the two agencies.

abstract: South Korean central bank, in surprise move, cuts benchmark rate to 3.25 percent, hoping to turn around two-year slump in consumer spending; photos (S)

abstract: The F.C.C. relaxed rules that had required the nation's four large Bell telephone companies to give their rivals access to their networks at discounted wholesale rates.

abstract: Treasury securities prices rise slightly; 10-year note rises 4/32, to 100 22/32, to yield 4.17 percent; graph of 3-month Treasury bills; key rates table (S)

headline: Its Creditors Stand to Gain as Thai Oil Goes Public

headline: Agreement Reached to Sell Jerusalem Post
abstract: Hollinger International will sell Jerusalem Post's publishing group as company continues to unload its assets amid battle with Conrad M Black, its major shareholder and former top executive; Mirkaei Tikshoret Ltd agrees to buy Hollinger's Israeli publishing arm for $13.2 million in all-cash deal that is expected to be completed by mid-December; Mirkaei Tikshoret also announces plans to sell half of its new ownership stake to CanWest Global Communications; two companies will run Jerusalem Post and its related properties; Ravelston Management, holding company through which Lord Black controls his stake in Hollinger, says it will offer $60.9 million in cash and stock to take newspaper company private; Ravelston owns 78 percent of Hollinger (M)

headline: EBay at a Crossroads: Can `Buy Now' Share Space With `Bid Now'?

headline: Round 3 coverage
Is the Low-Carb Boom Over?
abstract: Article on general malaise that is overtaking low-carb boom in America; some 3,737 products, including new flavors and varieties of existing foods, have been introduced in last two years but manufacturers are reporting sharp decline in orders and sharp increase in inventories; many food industry analysts say low-carb movement, if not dead, is at least deeply wounded; photos; graph (L)

headline: Bush, in Colombia, Says He Will Seek More U.S. Antidrug Funds
abstract: The president did not mention a specific sum, but he was effusive in his praise of the Colombian leader's antidrug efforts.

abstract: Brazilian government reports that trade surplus declined to $3.01 billion in October, compared to $3.17 billion in September; year-to-date surplus is up 38 percent from 2003, to $28.12 billion (S)

headline: No Deal Yet in Ukraine After Talks on Political Changes
abstract: Ukraine's fractious lawmakers reached a tentative agreement on Monday to end a political stalemate before a new presidential election later this month. But President Leonid D. Kuchma and the two presidential contenders failed to approve the deal after hours of talks that stretched into Tuesday morning.    The agreement would have made sweeping changes in the country's political system, to reduce the power of the presidency, but that proved to be an insurmountable obstacle for now. So did the demands by supporters of Viktor A. Yushchenko, the opposition leader, that Mr. Kuchma dismiss Prime Minister Viktor F. Yanukovich, the presidential candidate Mr. Kuchma had anointed, and the government.

headline: Saudi Raid Survivors Say Human Shields Were Used
abstract: Eight men said today they were used as human shields during Monday's armed assault against the American consulate in Saudi Arabia.

headline: Italy is abuzz as hazelnut spread turns 40 : The politics of Nutella
Technology Briefing | Hardware: Researcher Predicts Linux PC Sales
abstract: IDC says sales of new and used personal computers running Linux operating system will reach $10 billion by 2008; reports about 17 million Linux personal computers will be sold that year, bringing total installed base to 42.6 million (S)

headline: Yasir Arafat, Palestinian Leader, Dies at 75
abstract: Yasir Arafat was the wily, enigmatic father and leader of Palestinian nationalism for almost 40 years.

headline: By Balance Sheet : If alarm bells don't ring
Do I.R.A.'s Have Protection in Bankruptcy Proceeding?
abstract: Supreme Court agrees to decide whether individual retirement accounts have protection under bankruptcy laws, which were drafted before IRA's became important vehicle for retirement savings and whose ambiguity on issue has led to contradictory rulings in federal courts around country; case before court is appeal by Richard and Betty Jo Rousey, Arkansas couple approaching retirement age, who tried to shield $65,000 in their two IRA accounts when they filed joint bankruptcy petition in 2001 (M)

headline: Want to Retire Early, It May Take Some Work
abstract: LYDIA POSNER was not considering retirement last year when Verizon offered her a buyout package. ''I always felt like I would work forever, so this was a very emotional decision for me,'' said Mrs. Posner, who was employed as a technical writer. ''I drove my husband and children crazy for six weeks talking about it, until my kids finally said, 'Mom, you worked for 31 years, you deserve this.'''    Mrs. Posner was 56 when she retired in 2003. She is among the thousands of employees who have decided to call it quits in recent years after being offered buyout packages, which many companies have been turning to as an alternative to involuntary layoffs during cost cutting. Many other workers are quitting their jobs years before they qualify for Social Security payments, without the incentive of a buyout.

headline: International team finds few problems : Thumbs-up from monitors
Constellation Agrees to Acquire Robert Mondavi for $1 Billion
abstract: Constellation Brands announces agreement to acquire California wine maker Robert Mondavi for about $1 billion; acquisition, which began with unsolicited offer by Constellation two weeks ago, follows yearlong period of financial difficulty and internal wrangling at Mondavi, which is 85 percent controlled by Mondavi family (M)

headline: COMPANY BRIEFS
abstract: ROPER INDUSTRIES INC., Duluth, Ga., maker of inspection and measuring equipment for the oil and gas industries, said it had agreed to buy TransCore Holdings, Hummelstown, Pa., a maker of systems technologies, from an investor group led by KRG Capital Partners, Denver, for about $600 million.    J.M. SMUCKER CO., Orrville, Ohio, the maker of jellies and jams, said it had sold its operations in Brazil to closely held Cargill Inc., Wayzata, Minn., the agricultural company.    CHOICE ONE COMMUNICATIONS INC., New York, a provider of Internet and telephone services, filed for bankruptcy protection in New York with a plan to give its lenders 90 percent of the company's stock.

headline: Signs That Japan's Economic Recovery Is Fading
abstract: String of disappointing economic reports, including one showing unexpectedly steep decline in industrial output, heightens concerns that Japan's recovery may be fading fast; industrial output fell 1.6 percent in October from September, biggest decline in eight months; economists say decline suggests that worries about high oil prices, rising yen and slackening demand overseas are causing companies to curtail production more than anticipated; separate figures show jobless rate rose in October to 4.7 percent from 4.6 percent in September as 260,000 jobs were lost; spending by households headed by wage earners fell 1.2 percent in October from month earlier; benchmark Nikkei 225 stock average drops 78.64 points, or 0.72 percent, to close at 10,899.25; graphs; charts (M)

headline: Photo edict muffles gossipy press
EU sues Germany on VW law
Chirac nets over $4 billion in orders : France-China deals awaken Europeans
A Comeback Role for Westwood Village
abstract: Article on work by several local developers, including Topa Management Co, in trying to revitalize Westwood Village, retail complex in Los Angeles that opened in 2002; Casden Properties expects to begin construction early next year on Palazzo Westwood, $10 million complex with 350 residential units and 50,000 square feet of retail space, on long-vacant 4.25-acre site straddling Glendon Ave; Westwood Village, which is near affluent residential neighborhoods, lacks convenient parking and absence of business property leadership; photo; map (M)

headline: People
abstract: Colle & McVoy, part of MDC Partners, names John Jarvis chief executive, succeeding Chuck Kushell; Jarvis will continue as president and chief creative officer (S)

headline: Net jumps at Infosys
Doctors 'clearly' see a 'third-party' role : Yushchenko poisoning suggests plot
Looters at Weapon Site
abstract: Looters stormed Al Qaqaa, a weapons site in Iraq, just days after American troops swept through on their way to Baghdad in early April 2003, four Iraqi witnesses reported. Their accounts do not directly address the question of when 380 tons of powerful explosives vanished from the site sometime after early March 2003, the last time international inspectors checked the seals.     Article, Page A26.

headline: U.S. Acts to Take Over Faltering Pilots' Pension Plan at United
abstract: The government said the unusual step was needed to keep the airline and the pilots' union from abusing the federal pension-insurance program.

headline: Fingerprinting Glitches Are Said to Hurt Antiterror Effort
abstract: Problems in searching fingerprint databases have left US military unable to check fully identities of thousands of detainees in Iraq and Afghanistan, raising concerns about premature releases of terrorist suspects; Defense Department biometrics officer discusses efforts to address FBI complaints that Pentagon data are not compatible with FBI's use of customized portable units, which meet global standards; photo (M)

headline: Economic Calendar
abstract: Today.

headline: Rebirth of the Potion That Made Val-de-Travers Famous
abstract: New law in Switzerland will lift ban on absinthe; this will allow dozens of underground absinthe makers to seek amnesty and produce it legally; distillers hope to obtain official governmental 'appellation' declaring that Val-de-Travers region produces only real absinthe in world; legalization will help Swiss cash in on rising global market for absinthe, which can be bought easily over Internet; absinthe, once thought to cause insanity, is not sold legally in United States; photos; map (M)

headline: Boom Time for Credit in Southeast Asia
abstract: Strengthening economies in Southeast Asia enable more consumers to move up from poverty to lower middle class, prompting expansion of consumer credit opportunities for companies like Capital OK; consumer credit in Thailand grew 35 percent last year, pushing average household's debt up to 52 percent of its income; photo; boom also spurs competition for region's banks from aggressive foreign institutions like Citibank and Aeon of Japan, which pioneered consumer finance in region (M)

headline: G.M. Enlists Orman to Pitch Financing Promotion
abstract: General Motors taps Suze Orman, financial planner, motivational speaker and CNBC talk show host, to pitch company's latest marketing program, which GM is calling 'Lock 'n Roll'; deal allows consumers who qualify for no-interest financing or other special low rates on 2005 GM models to get same low rate on purchase of their next GM vehicle; photo (S)

headline: AOL Is Said to Plan 700 Layoffs
abstract: America Online is preparing to lay off 700 US workers; company faces continuing decline in subscriber base and lags behind competitors Yahoo and Microsoft in online advertising (M)

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: Nintendo and Sony Pursue Older Hand-Held Gamers  Nintendo is hoping that its new portable device, the Nintendo DS, above, will win over older, more sophisticated gamers who otherwise would be playing consoles like the Xbox and Sony's PlayStation 2. But Sony is going after the same market with its PSP, a ''PlayStation Portable'' that will also play music and video.     The challenge from Sony could put Nintendo's dominance in the hand-held market, an important and growing part of its business, into question. [Page C3.]    Building a Medical Data Network  Digital patient records could become building blocks in a nationwide biomedical computer network for assembling and distributing up-to-the-minute studies of disease. To protect privacy, personal identifiers would be stripped out. New Economy. [C3.]    West's Comic Books Head East  Deepak Chopra, the spiritual guru, is part of an effort to bring Western comic-book titles like ''Batman'' and ''Superman'' to India's booming youth market. [C6.]    Advertisements You Didn't Demand  Video-on-demand specials have so far appeared without advertisements. But Fox Cable Networks and Visa plan to try including ads in a show in January. Advertising. [C5.]    Battle for PeopleSoft Continues  Oracle will continue its pursuit of PeopleSoft this week, asking a judge to dismantle one of the last obstacles to a deal. [C2.]    Airlines Compete for China Routes  Five United States airlines are fighting for the right to offer two daily round trips from a major American city to Shanghai or another large city in China. [C2.]    TV Sours Trump-Branson Relations  When ''The Rebel Billionaire,'' a reality show starring Sir Richard Branson, left, failed to match ''The Apprentice'' in the ratings, Donald J. Trump sent him a not-very-supportive letter. ''You have no television persona,'' he wrote. In his response, Sir Branson struck a more conciliatory tone and said he had decided to ''rise above'' Mr. Trump's comments. [C6.]    Angry Soccer Fans Scare Bankers  Plans for an American takeover of the Manchester United soccer team have been so unpopular with fans that no British bankers seem willing to help its suitor. [C4.]    Europe Moves on Accounting Rules  The European Commission will leave it up to banks to decide whether they will fully comply with international rules aimed at preventing financial institutions from hiding losses. [C2.]    Human Genome Picks New Chief  Human Genome Sciences plans to announce that H. Thomas Watkins, a former Abbott Laboratories executive, will be its new chief. [C7.]    Fox News Moves to Canada  Canada's broadcasting regulator has given cable and satellite television services permission to carry the Fox News Channel. [C6.]

headline: Ukraine Crisis Brings Out People of Faith
abstract: Politial upheaval in Ukraine has brought to streets members of almost all of country's religious communities; most support opposition candidate Viktor A Yushchenko; Ukraine has two Orthodox patriarchates, one supporting Yushchenko and other backing Moscow's favorite, Prime Min Viktor F Yanukovich (S)

headline: Gadget of the week: Turning wax into MP3
F.D.A. Approves a Multiple Sclerosis Drug
abstract: Food and Drug Administration approves drug Tysabri developed by Biogen Idec and Elan that has shown early evidence of being more effective than existing drugs; analysts predict annual sales will eventually surpass $2 billion (M)

headline: REALLY VIRTUAL
abstract: Dawn G Lepore, who created online trading at Charles Schwab, will become chief executive and chairwoman of Drugstore.com, succeeding Kal Raman and Peter Neupert respectively

headline: California Backs Merger of 2 Giant Blue Cross Plans
abstract: Anthem and WellPoint Health Networks, two giant Blue Cross plans, finally win approval from California's insurqnce commissioner, John Garamendi, for their $16.4 billion merger, which would create nation's largest health insurer; two companies had to promise to spend $265 million to help improve health services in state; photo (M)

headline: Schr√∂der opens bid to broaden China trade
Gift Bags on Continental
abstract: Continental Airlines plans to introduce luxury gift bags provided by Premier Bags Inc for first-class passengers on transcontinental flights from Newark (S)

headline: U.S. Grand Jury Indicts a Briton, Charging He Supported Terrorists
abstract: Babar Ahmad, British citizen arrested in London at request of United States government, is indicted on charges of running Internet site supporting terrorist causes and arranging for purchase of gas masks, camouflage suits, night-vision goggles and other possible terrorist tools; indictment also alleges that he was in contact with Muhammad Naeem Noor Khan, who was arrested by Pakistani authorities in July and who allegedly possessed surveillance information on financial centers in Nwe York, Washington and New Jersey (M)

headline: No Cure Seen for Growth in Employers' Health Costs
abstract: The growth in health care spending by private employers slowed in recent years, creating some optimism that the employers had turned the corner in their struggle with rising costs. But any relief appears to have been short lived, according to a study to be released today.    Growth in spending in the first half of 2004 was about the same as it was in 2003, according to the Center for Studying Health System Change, a nonprofit research group in Washington that tracks spending levels. Largely driven by the growth in hospital costs, total health care spending increased 7.5 percent.

headline: Bitter Divisions Rife in Ukraine as Voting Nears
abstract: Ukraine, over month after disputed presidential election, prepares for new vote that has raised hopes that amicable end to its deeply divisive political crisis is near; Prime Min Viktor F Yanukovich, who was declared winner of election overturned by Supreme Court, says results of Dec 26 vote will be illegitimate and vows to fight them in court; polls show opposition leader Viktor A Yushchenko with comfortable lead; map; photo (M)

headline: Style by Way of Grandmother's Closet
abstract: Michelle Slatalla Online Shopper column on purchasing fall fashions for women online; drawing (M)

headline: McCann Worldgroup Buys Agency in Utah
abstract: McCann Worldgroup is acquiring Boede & Partners, ad agency in Salt Lake City (S)

headline: COURT RULING WILL GIVE GOODRICH A $145 MILLION GAIN
abstract: Goodrich Co says recent Federal judgment upholding $82.8 million tax refund to former Goodrich unit Coltec Industries will likely result in $145 million gain (S)

headline: Fixed income hurts Morgan profit
Twists of fate make its European roots less of a worry for Pentagon : EADS takes aim at U.S. defense deal
Technology Briefing | Deals: SBC Unit Will Acquire Yantra
abstract: SBC Communications says its Sterling Commerce unit will buy privately held Yantra Corp, which makes supply-chain fulfillment software applications, for about $170 million in cash (S)

headline: Gadgets That Cut You Loose
abstract: David Pogue describes some of his favorite new electronic and computer gadgets; photo (Special section, Retail) (M)

headline: Technology Briefing | Telecommunications: Cablevision Gains Internet Phone Subscribers
abstract: Cablevision Systems has signed up more than 250,000 Internet phone customers in year since it introduced service (S)

headline: Oracle at Impasse With PeopleSoft
abstract: Oracle says it is at impasse with PeopleSoft Inc, signaling that software makers will wage proxy battle to resolve Oracle's takeover bid (M)

headline: World Briefings
abstract: OCEANIA.

headline: Kiwi Shoe Polish Aims to Escape Invisibility
abstract: Sara Lee Corp, which owns Kiwi line of shoe care products, has come up with new marketing campaign that uses sardonic humor to get consumers to use Kiwi polish they already have in their homes; campaign was created by Richards Group; photo (M)

headline: Choose Your Role: Vampire or Card Wielder
abstract: Charles Herold Game Theory column reviews Vampire: The Masquerade Bloodlines and Baten Kaitos: Eternal Wings and The Lost Ocean; photos (M)

headline: World Briefing | Europe: Russia: TV Journalist Suspended For Comment
abstract: News anchor Aleksei Pivovarov, who works for television channel that has been perceived as pro-Kremlin, is suspended after making sarcastic comment about Leonid Parfyonov, who was recently fired from station and made Russian editor of Newsweek (S)

headline: PEPSICO TO CUT 780 U.S. JOBS; PROFIT UP 35% IN QUARTER
abstract: PepsiCo Inc says that third-quarter earnings increased 35 percent, helped by sales gains in Asia and by lower taxes; company's Frito-Lay snacks unit says that it will close four American plants, cutting 780 jobs; net income rises to $1.36 billion, or 79 cents a share; sales rise 6.3 percent, to $7.26 billion (S)

headline: Ovitz Queried on Expenses in Lawsuit Against Disney
abstract: Walt Disney Co's former president Michael S Ovitz finds himself on defensive about his continuing relationship with talent agency he left for Disney in testimony at Disney shareholders trial; Steven G Schulman, lawyer for Disney shareholders suing over board's handling of Ovitz's controversial tenure in mid-1990's, attacks one of tenets of Ovitz's defense: that he gave up lucrative career at Creative Artists Agency after 21 years to join Disney in 1995; Schulman points out that Ovitz still received rent from building where agency he co-founded is located; adds Ovitz also gets stake in commission in current Creative Artists, which was reorganized when he left; presses Ovitz about joint venture--to produce advertising--that he helped former Creative Artists colleagues set up with Coca-Cola Co and Disney; photo (M)

headline: Chinese Plan to Buy Big Miner Stirs Canadians Left and Right
abstract: China Minmetals Corp is expected to make formal bid for Noranda, Canada's largest mining company; announcement has set off protests by Canada's political left and right; biggest concern seems to be that China Minmetals is government-owned; some political critics have raised questions about Chinese company's commitment to environmental protection; Bloc Quebecois politicians are concerned that Minmentals will move ore processing to China; Stockwell Day, member of Parliament from Conservative Party, says Minmetals' labor practices need to be scrutinized; David Kilgour, Liberal member of Parliament, says he and his constituents do not want merger because Chinese company is branch of government department; Canada's Industry Min David Emerson says China's human rights record would be considered in decision to allow sale; Noranda chief Derek G Pannell says any deal is unlikely to close before first quarter of 2005; photo (M)

headline: Washington Station Offers Gas, Snacks and Hydrogen
abstract: Ordinary filling station in Washington, DC, offers hydrogen, along with usual selection of regular, premium and diesel at pumps; it uses hydrogen pump installed by Shell and GM; for $1.99 a kilogram, drivers can choose between liquid hydrogen, chilled to nearly 300 degrees below zero, or gaseous hydrogen, at 500 pounds per square inch of pressure; that amount of hydrogen, when burned, produces about same amount of energy as gallon of regular unleaded gas; photo (M)

headline: MAGNUM HUNTER SAYS IT MAY BE FOR SALE
abstract: Magnum Hunter Resources Inc, oil and natural gas producer, says company may be sold (S)

headline: World Business Briefing | Europe: Britain: Profit At Telephone Company
abstract: BT Group reports third-quarter net income of $790.7 million, up 14 percent from same period last year; graph (S)

headline: When Big Law Firms Trip Over Their Own Clients
abstract: whe√Ø

headline: World Briefing | Europe: Ministers Split Over Migrant Camps
abstract: At a meeting of European interior ministers in Italy, Spain and France came out against a plan to create camps in North Africa to hold illegal immigrants. It was supported by Germany and Italy. The Spainish interior minister, Jos√© Antonio Alonso, said he was unsure that the camps would be able to provide humane treatment and expressed doubts that they would reduce illegal immigration.   Renwick McLean (NYT)

headline: Kurds Enjoy a Calmer Corner of Iraq
abstract: Dusty, sprawing city of Erbil, in Iraq's northern Kurdish region, is oasis of relative calm, largely spared violence wracking rest of country; map; area has enjoyed de facto autonomy since end of Persian Gulf War and Kurds who fled Saddam Hussein's regime years ago have returned to take up posts in government, business and education (M)

headline: Palestinians Hold Meeting Among Rivals About Power
abstract: Mahmoud Abbas, Palestine Liberation Organization's new chairman, meets with militant leaders, Gaza, as politicians, security chiefs and militants vie to preserve or increase their power in wake of Yasir Arafat's death; reportedly does not raise question of whether Palestinians should halt attacks on Israelis; urges militant groups Hamas and Islamic Jihad to join in Palestinian Authority elections; militant leaders demand Arafat's dominant Al Fatah faction share more power; say they will consider joining Palestine Liberation Organization if it retreats from its support of Oslo accords with Israel; Abbas faces challenge of holding Fatah together while somehow disarming or containing militants, step more powerful Arafat was unwilling to take; Islamic Jihad leader Muhammad al-Hindi says group would not discuss cease-fire with Israel; photos (M)

headline: INVACARE LOWERS OUTLOOK FOR QUARTER AND NEXT YEAR
abstract: Invacare Corp lowers its earnings estimates for fourth quarter and next year (S)

headline: Caution at the border
Macedonian bishop's struggle reflects wider Balkan upheaval
Technology Briefing | People: IAC Names Financial Chief
abstract: IAC/InterActive Corp appoints Thomas J McInerney, chief of its HSN home-shopping network, to be chief financial officer, succeeding Dara Khosrowshahi, who will become chief executive of IAC's travel division; Erik Blachford, current head of IAC Travel, might leave company (S)

headline: With Premier's Trial Over, Italians Hope for Judicial Reforms
abstract: Judicial commentators in Italy voice hope for much needed reforms in country's justice system following dismissal of bribery charges against Prime Min Silvio Berlusconi; there is widespread agreement among Italy's politicians that judiciary is seriously flawed, that it moves far too slowly and that magistrates are overworked (M)

headline: This Kansan Made Good, Maybe Too Good, Some Say
abstract: David Wittig's spoils from his tenure as chief executive of Kansas' largest electric utility, a company once brash enough to be called the Enron of the Midwest, are the talk of Topeka.       There is the Ferrari, a 550 Maranello model, purchased for $229,751, and the Landon mansion, this city's most luxurious home, refurbished by a celebrity decorator from New York at a cost of nearly $2 million. And, of course, more than $25 million in salary and other compensation that Westar Energy paid over seven years to Mr. Wittig, 49, including $2 million from a life insurance policy while he is still alive.
