headline: U.S. Envoy Reports Success in Restive Afghan City
abstract: Zalmay Khalilzad declared a success today for the government of President Hamid Karzai, reporting a rapid disarmament operation in the western city of Herat.

headline: For White Men, Military Service Does Not Pay Later in Life
abstract: THE risk of serious injury or death to members of the armed forces is clear enough, but their economic risks are less apparent. Veterans Day is a fitting occasion to recognize the economic sacrifices of veterans.     For a long time, it was believed that veterans of popular wars benefited from their service when they rejoined the civilian labor market, while veterans of unpopular wars lost out. A growing body of research, however, shows that most veterans -- whether inductees during a draft or enlistees in the voluntary forces -- suffer an earnings penalty in the civilian economy. Military experience appears to be worth little to most private-sector employers.

headline: China Relents, and Promises Textile Tariffs
abstract: China's Commerce Ministry says it would impose tariffs on some textile exports, step that could avert trade war with United States and European Union over new influx of low-cost Chinese garments expected to flood Western markets starting Jan 1; does not specify level of export taxes or what textiles would be taxed; if tariffs are not high enough to limit competitiveness of Chinese exports, Bush administration might proceed with recent threats to impose new limits on shipments by China; complex system of quotas has limited international trade in textiles and apparel for decades but will expire on Jan 1 under agreement worked out in 1993 as part of creation of World Trade Orgn; Chinese decision represents first sign of compromise on contentious issue by China, and appears to represent victory for Bush administration; it has been under strong pressure from apparel manufacturers and their workers in Southern states, who warn of large-scale layoffs if nothing is done (M)

headline: Under Siege in Afghanistan, Aid Groups Say Their Effort Is Being Criticized Unfairly
abstract: During the Soviet occupation, the civil war that followed, the rule of the Taliban and its aftermath, aid groups like CARE and the Swedish Committee for Afghanistan filled the gaps where a state had once been, providing education, health care, and employment to Afghans at home and in exile.    Today, as Afghanistan struggles to rebuild, the groups continue to support schools and clinics, provide clean drinking water, and more, often carrying out projects for a government without the capacity to do so itself.

headline: G.E. TO ACQUIRE IONICS FOR $1.1 BILLION
abstract: General Electric will acquire Ionics Inc for $1.1 billion in cash to take advantage of rising demand for water purification and treatment in developing countries (S)

headline: Iraqi Indicted for Proposal to Open Talks With Israel
abstract: A court of Iraq's interim government has brought criminal charges against a prominent politician for attending an antiterrorism conference in Israel and publicly suggesting that Iraq should open talks with Israel.      The indictment and arrest warrant, based on a 1969 law promulgated by the Baath Party that bars Iraqis from having contacts with enemy states, are likely to anger the United States government, which has sponsored Iraq's new courts and is a close ally of Israel.

headline: A.I.G. Says It Is Target of Midwest Inquiry
abstract: American International Group is target of federal grand jury investigation over its role in helping cellphone distributor Brightpoint Inc of Plainfield, Ind, cover up millions in business losses; AIG agreed year ago to pay $10 million to settle Securities and Exchange Commission complaint that it provided contract for Brightpoint that had appearance of insurance but was merely exchange of money; deal allowed Brightpoint to reduce its losses for 1998 by nearly $12 million; AIG did not admit any wrongdoing in settlement; AIG chairman-chief executive Maurice R Greenberg comments; photo (M)

headline: Lockheed and BAE Protest Boeing Contract
abstract: Lockheed Martin and BAE Systems filed protests to Air Force to $4 billion contract to upgrade C-130 transport plane that former Air Force official Darleen Druyun has said was improperly awarded to Boeing; protests are first step in process that could ultimately lead to termination and rebidding of contract; Druyun was sentenced to nine months in prison last week for role in awarding contract to Boeing; photos (M)

headline: Detours ahead for global transport
World Business Briefing | Europe: Britain: Pub Concern Acquired
abstract: Wolverhampton & Dudley Breweries agrees to purchase Burtonwood, which operates 460 British pubs, for 119 million pounds sterling ($231 million); Wolverhampton reports 26 percent rise in annual profit, to 48.4 million pounds sterling; graph (S)

headline: Egyptian Officials Pursue a Lead in Inquiry Into the Sinai Bombings
abstract: Egyptian investigators reveal their first lead into three suicide bombings at Taba Hilton and two beachside holiday villages popular with young Israelis; say Bedouin tribesman has confessed to selling large quantity of explosives to young Egyptian, and provided police with physical description of buyer; Bedouin's tale has varied concerning what he thought buyer planned to do with explosives, and when he sold the explosives; numerous Bedouin tribesman have been rounded up for questioning; Egyptian analysts are leaning toward Al Qaeda as likely culprit, suspicion Israelis discussed from the start given coordinated nature and size of explosions, and fact that Al Qaeda's No 2 man Ayman al-Zawahiri recently encouraged attacks on Israel and Egypt (M)

headline: A Stock Party, Then a Retail Hangover
abstract: Gretchen Morgenson column expresses skepticism about real estate and tax considerations that have generated such enthusiasm for Kmart and Sears merger; cites view of Martin J Whitman, fund manager with stake in Kmart, that only way for deal to succeed is for new company to find way to compete in retail world dominated Wal-Mart, Target and Costco (M)

headline: DANAHER TO BUY MAKER OF ELECTRICAL TESTING EQUIPMENT
abstract: The Danaher Corporation, the maker of Craftsman hand tools and Fluke electronic testing equipment, has agreed to buy LEM Instruments for about $57 million in cash, adding business in Europe. LEM Instruments, which produces electrical measurement equipment, generated about $45 million in revenue in fiscal 2004, Danaher said. Danaher is buying the unit, which has been unprofitable, from LEM Holding, based in Geneva. LEM Instruments will become part of Danaher's electronic testing business. Danaher, based in Washington, made more than $1.58 billion in purchases this year before the LEM acquisition. The sale is expected to close in the first quarter, the company said.

headline: Amazon Rumor Ruffles DVD Rivals
abstract: DVD rental industry is shifting course on just rumor that Amazon will offer competing online service; Netflix drops its prices on rumor and Blockbuster quickly followed suit; Amazon offers no details, but says it is well positioned to enter business; photo (M)

headline: World Briefing | Europe: Spain: Islamic Militant Sought From Swiss
abstract: The Spanish government plans to ask Switzerland to extradite Mohamed Achraf, identified by the police as the leader of the Islamic militants arrested in Spain this week in connection with a plot to bomb the national court in Madrid.   Renwick McLean (NYT)

headline: Miscellany
abstract: Outdoor Advertising Association of America reports outdoor-advertising revenue in the third quarter rose 3.6 percent, to $1.4 billion; Massive, which sells advertising in video games, names Nielsen Interactive Entertainment to provide ratings to advertisers (S)

headline: Technology Briefing | Telecommunications: Corning Reports Loss For Quarter
abstract: Corning reports loss of $2.49 billion for third quarter; net loss of $1.78 per share is in contrast to profit of $33 million, or 2 cents, year earlier; sales rose 30 percent, to $1.01 billion (S)

headline: Police Arrest 8 Tied to Suspect in Killing of Dutch Filmmaker
abstract: Dutch police arrest eight men suspected of being Islamic militants in connection with killing of Theo van Gogh, Dutch filmmaker, on street in Amsterdam; say men acted 'from a radical Islamic conviction'; van Gogh was outspoken opponent of Islamic extremism and recently received death threats after broadcast of his short film, Submission, which criticizes mistreatment of Muslim women; shortly after his death police arrested Dutch and Moroccan national following exchange of fire that wounded both him and police officer; justice ministry says man is known to Intelligence Service (M)

headline: A leaning tower aspires to Pisa-dom
World Briefing | Middle East: Lebanon: Prime Minister Quits
abstract: Rafik Hariri, the billionaire construction tycoon who has been prime minister for much of the past 12 years, resigned, declining to form a new cabinet. The resignation brings to a head a long-running dispute with President √âmile Lahoud, who gained another three years in office last month after Syria strong-armed the Lebanese Parliament into extending his term. That vote prompted the United States and France to sponsor a United Nations resolution calling on Syria to relinquish its control over Lebanon. The poisonous relation between the two men has long stymied much-anticipated economic and other reforms. It remained unclear who might form the next government.   Neil MacFarquhar (NYT)

headline: Oil Prices and Weather May Slow Growth in India
abstract: India's economy expands 7.4 percent in the quarter ended in June, driven by sizzling growth in manufacturing and services, but slowed a bit by uneven rains that reduced farm output; stop-and-start monsoon and rising global oil prices are expected to drag on India's economy this year, paring annual growth to around 6 percent after economy roared ahead by 8.2 percent last year; photos (M)

headline: Details on Hussein Moves
abstract: A report to be made public this week is said to give new details on how Saddam Hussein tried to undermine sanctions as part of a plan to produce weapons. Page A10.

headline: World Briefing | Asia: Japan: Shrine Visits Said To Hinder China Ties
abstract: Japan's Foreign Min Nobutaka Machimura says that Prime Min Junichiro Koizumi's annual visits to Yasukuni Shrine, which neighboring nations see as symbol of Japanese aggression, are hindering relations with China (S)

headline: Merck's Board Appoints Panel to Investigate Handling of Vioxx
abstract: Merck & Co's directors open independent investigation into whether company acted properly regarding Vioxx, which was withdrawn from market in September; William G Bowen, president of Mellon Foundation, will lead committee, which has hired law firm Debevoise & Plimpton to conduct review; Merck chief executive Raymond V Gilmartin says company's management will cooperate fully with review (M)

headline: Advertisements You Didn¬ít Demand
abstract: Behind the Mysteries, coming video-on-demand program on National Geographic Channel, will be shown with commercials, a first for video-on-demand; Visa, advertiser, and Fox Cable Networks, partner in channel with National Geographic Television and Film, seek to test viewer tolerance for ads within video-on-demand, an increasingly alluring idea for cable companies; photo (M)

headline: Spinach Power Adds Muscle to Batteries
abstract: Consortium of scientists develop phyotosynthesis-powered chip that may be able to extend life of batteries in cellphones and other portable electronic decides; photo (M)

headline: Bosnian Serb Premier Quits, Criticizing West
abstract: Dragan Mikerevic, leader of Bosnian Serb government, resigns to protest what he describes as unconstitutional interference in his government's affairs by country's Western administrator, Lord Ashdown; acts day after Ashdown took measures to punish Bosnian Serb authorities over their failure to locate and arrest war crimes suspects (M)

headline: World Business Briefing | Americas: Brazil: Budget Airline Posts Profit
abstract: Brazil's budget airline Gol Linhas Aereas Inteligentes says third-quarter profit was flat at 96.9 million reais ($34 million), but market share increased and revenue rose 28 percent; sales totaled 517.2 million reais (S)d

headline: 2 Big Law Firms to Merge
abstract: American law firm Piper Rudnick and London-based law firm DLA agree to merge in largest international merger of law firms; new firm DLA Piper Rudnick Gray Cary will have 2,700 lawyers in United States, Europe and Asia (S)

headline: World Business Briefing | Asia: Malaysia: Exports Rise
abstract: Malaysia's exports rose 23.7 percent in August from August 2003, led by demand from United States; nation's monthly trade surplus rose to record 8.06 billion ringgit ($2.12 billion) (S)

headline: Confused by Camera Modes, Some Choose Ignore
abstract: Digital camera manufacturers offer numerous settings, but some users find them too complex, opting instead to use auto setting (M)

headline: Dot-Com Star, Indie Filmmaker
abstract: Stephan Paternot, former co-founder of theglobe.com, creates with several partners Palm Star Entertainment, to make low-budget independent films; photo (S)

headline: Ovitz Testifies He Was Sabotaged at Disney
abstract: Walt Disney Co's former Michael S Ovitz vigorously defends his 14-month tenure, saying his efforts to expand and improve company were undercut at nearly every turn by recalcitrant senior executives and chief executive Michael D Eisner; is witness in trial of lawsuit filed by Disney shareholders, who contend its board of directors breached its fiduciary responsibility when Eisner hired Ovitz as president in 1995 and then signed off on severance package valued at $140 million 14 months later; spends much of his four hours of testimony decribing how his vision for substantially different Disney was thwarted; photo (M)

headline: Hilfiger Sales and Net Fall Amid Inquiry
abstract: Tommy Hilfiger Corp announces delay in formal release of quarterly earnings as result of criminal investigation that could affect tax liability; company, which is facing probe by US attorney's office into reporting of overseas commissions, says pretax profit fell 14 percent from one year ago on lower-than-expected sales; reduces outlook for year ending March 31 (M)

headline: China Detains a Human Rights Advocate
abstract: The Chinese police have detained a leading human rights advocate who represented farmers in lawsuits against the government, expanding a crackdown on writers, intellectuals, lawyers and journalists who challenge the Communist Party authorities.    The advocate, Li Boguang, was detained by the police while visiting Fujian Province last Tuesday, his family said. The reasons for his detention are unclear.

headline: Internet Retailers Reaching Out to Mailbox Surfers
abstract: Online retailers like eBay, Amazon.com, Eziba and RedEnvelope are increasingly trying to lure customers with catalogs; have found that online sites are strong for taking orders but weak in reaching new customers, especially those who are not frequent Internet shoppers; eBay's auction business poses challenge for catalog specialists; photos (M)

headline: Sudan Orders the Expulsion of Aid Officials From 2 Groups
abstract: Government of Sudan orders country directors of two Britain-based aid agencies that provide relief to displaced people in Darfur region to leave country, accusing them of making statements in support of rebels; expulsion orders come three weeks after Sudanese authorities and their rebel enemies signed agreement promising to expand access for aid efforts in Darfur; groups are Oxfam Great Britain and Save the Children UK (M)

headline: Food Imports Close to Matching Level of Exports, Report Says
abstract: US Agriculture Department says in 2005, for first time in nearly five decades, US could import as much food as it exports; US exported more food that it imported until now; one out of every three acres in US is planted for export; department predicts in 2005 imports of farm products will equal exports, which are estimated at $56 billion (M)

headline: Wieden & Kennedy Fills  Creative Post
abstract: Wieden & Kennedy Fills Creative Post.

headline: MARSH & MCLENNAN COMPLETES NEW CREDIT AGREEMENT
abstract: Marsh & McLennan completes and expands $3 billion credit agreement with banks led by Citigroup; company was forced to renegotiate its credit after New York State Atty Gen Eliot Spitzer sued company, accusing it of rigging bids and taking kickbacks (S)

headline: Singapore Oil Company Chief Arrested in Trading Losses
abstract: Singapore Oil Company C

headline: Aides Quit American's Bid for Soccer Club
abstract: J P Morgan Chase, Brunswick Group and Allen & Overy step down as advisers to Malcolm Glazer, reportedly because he is ignoring their advice on bid for Manchester United; Glazer, with 28.1 percent stake now, votes three team directors off board at annual meeting, and could be planning hostile takeover (S)

headline: Palestinians Start to Think About Life Without Their Leader
abstract: As Yasir Arafat's helicopter lifted off in the rain and fog, above the ruins of his headquarters and the debris of cars crushed two years ago by Israeli tanks, there was a profound sense of leave-taking and anxiety.     There was a silent line of a hundred security men in green uniforms, like an honor guard, and Palestinian leaders gathered in suits, and all of Mr. Arafat's loyal lieutenants tried to touch him a last time before his bodyguards gently pushed him into the chopper. As it flew away, hundreds of hands waved in loyalty, a thank you but also a kind of goodbye.

headline: Southwest Is Adding Flights to Protect Its Chicago Hub
abstract: Southwest Airlines will add 16 flights a day from Chicago Midway Airport in January in order to protect valuable hub amid fight breaking out over assets of bankrupt ATA Airlines, airport's biggest carrier; flights will be to 13 cities it already serves from Midway (S)

headline: Annan's Comment on U.N. Abuse Case Helps Appeal, Lawyer Says
abstract: Lawyer for United Nations staff member who brought sexual harassment charges against Ruud Lubbers, high commissioner for refugees, says Secretary General Kofi Annan's admission that he overruled his own investigators in clearing Lubbers would support appeal against ruling (M)

headline: Oracle Nominates 4
abstract: Microsoft will not demand withdrawal of evidence submitted against it in European antitrust case by Novell and Computer and Communications Industry Trade Association, which have since dropped their support for case (S)

headline: Others deny claims by U.S. inspector that they took bribes from Saddam : France criticizes charges in report
Nickelodeon Tries a Hotel
abstract: Nickelodeon cable channel, joining list of marketers extending their brands to physical sites, will add its name to Holiday Inn Family Suites Resort, Lake Buena Vista, Fla; Nickelodeon Family Suites by Holiday Inn will include suites with children's rooms festooned with images of Nickelodeon characters, actors dressed as characters to entertain children and specialty retail shop; channel will promote hotel on own shows and other outlets of parent Viacom; photo (M)

headline: A Helping Hand That Magnifies Even the Fine Print
abstract: Pulse Data myReader allows visually impaired users to scan printed text and displays it in large format on monitor; photo (S)

headline: COMPANY BRIEFS
abstract: GERDAU, the Brazilian steel company, said yesterday that it had agreed to buy Gate City Steel and RJ Rebar, both in Indianapolis. Terms were not disclosed.    ESSEX PROPERTY TRUST, Palo Alto, Calif., which manages apartment buildings, said yesterday that its Essex Apartment Value Fund sold seven properties in California to United Dominion Realty Trust, Richmond, Va., for about $322 million.    COMPUTER SCIENCES CORP., El Segundo, Calif., the seller of computer services, said yesterday that it had won a $1.1 billion contract to manage computers for Textron, Providence, R.I., the maker of business jets.    FEDERATED INVESTORS, Pittsburgh, an asset manager, said yesterday that it had agreed to buy the money market business of Alliance Capital Management Holding, New York, for as much as $118 million.

headline: ON ADVERTISING : EU tries to clear the smoke
JOHNSON & JOHNSON HALTS EFFORT ON NEW USES OF DRUG
abstract: Johnson & Johnson abandons efforts to develop its Topamax epilepsy medicine as treatment for obesity and diabetes after studies show it is not effective (S)

headline: A Toy With a Story
abstract: Interview with Jeri Ellsworth, high school dropout and self-taught computer chip designer, who compressed into joy stick that attaches by cable to television set device that can run 30 video games, mostly games for obsolete Commodore 64 home computer from early 1980's, without hassle of changing game cartridges; device, sold by Mammoth Toys, has been hot item on QVC; her efforts in reverse engineering old computers and giving them new life inside modern custom chips shows spirit that once led from Silicon Valley garages to big computer companies still thrives; photos (M)

headline: Dollar Skids, Despite Stock Rally and a Strong Jobs Report
abstract: Dollar skids to record low against euro, despite surprisingly strong jobs report for October and another rally in stock market; Standard & Poor's 500-stock index climbs 4.50 points, to 1,166.17, a high for year; Dow Jones industrial average rises 72.78 points, to 10,387.54; Nasdaq composite index climbs 15.31 points, to 2,038.94; bond prices drop; yield on Treasury's 10-year note jumps to 4.17 percent; price falls 26/32, to 100 19/32; tables; graph shows Dow (L)

headline: Investor Suit at Disney Puts Exits in a Spotlight
abstract: Delaware court is set to begin hearing shareholder suit charging Walt Disney Co board breached its fiduciary responsibility when chief executive Michael D Eisner hired his friend, Michael S Ovitz, as president in 1995 and when it signed off on Ovitz's $140 million severage package 14 months later; directors may find themselves personally responsible for not carefully considering Ovitz's fitness for job; Eisner, set to retire at end of Sept 2006, could face renewed demands for earlier exit; suit charges that Ovitz wasted corporate assets and that board should have fired him for failing to do job; table of expenses Ovitz billed to Disney; drawing; photo (M)

headline: INVESTING : Spread your bets
Technology Briefing | Telecommunications: AT&T Wireless Outlets Converted
abstract: AT&T Wireless retail outlets will be converted into Cingular Wireless stores beginning Nov 16; move comes three weeks after Cingular completed its $41 billion purchase of AT&T Wireless to become largest cellphone carrier in US (S)t

headline: Nuclear Deal With Iranians Has Angered Hard-Liners
abstract: Iran's hard-line parliament reacts angrily to complex deal reached with Germany, France and Britain that calls for Iran to stop enriching uranium during talks on benefits to be received in exchange for suspending program; pact also lifts threat of UN penalties (S)

headline: CANADIAN REGULATOR BACKS COORS-MOLSON MERGER
abstract: Molson and Adolph Coors Co wins clearance from Competitive Bureau of Canada for their planned $3.4 billion merger (S)

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: Justice Department Is Said To Start Fannie Mae Inquiry  The Justice Department has started a criminal investigation of Fannie Mae, the nation's largest mortgage buyer, in response to a federal report accusing executives at the company of sloppy accounting practices, said an official who has been briefed on the matter.

headline: New Executive Named For G.M. Account
abstract: Leo Burnett USA names Tor Myhren as executive vice president and executive creative director for General Motors ad account managed by Burnett unit Chemistri (S)

headline: SCHAWK TO BUY SEVEN WORLDWIDE TO EXTEND FOREIGN REACH
abstract: Schawk, a supplier of digital imaging for the packaging and advertising industries, acquires Seven Worldwide for about $191 million (S)

headline: White House Defends China on Currency
abstract: Treasury Department, in report to Congress, dismisses complaints from some manufacturers and members of Congress that undervaluation is worsening US trade deficit, once again declares that China is not manipulating its exchange rate; says China is laying groundwork for shift to market-based flexible exchange rate (M)

headline: How to Rate a Fund Ratings System
abstract: Strategies column on assessing stock fund rankings of Value Line, Morningstar and others ystems; graph (M)

headline: Lenovo will cede control to IBM team
4 European Nations Accused of Unfairly Favoring Intel
abstract: European Commission says France, Netherlands, Sweden and Finland unfairly favored Intel in public contracts for computer equipment; begins formal inquiry into their procurement practices; Advanced Micro Devices complained 10 months ago that practice by four countries was anticompetitive (M)

headline: Corrections
abstract: Correction of November 21 article about disputed sales of art previously seized by Cuban government; Cintas Foundation unsuccessfully sued Sotheby's in 1995 in Britain (S)

headline: World Business Briefing | Europe: Russia: More Tax For Yukos
abstract: Russian Tax Ministry claims added $10 billion in back taxes from oil company Yukos, bringing company's total back tax bill to $17.5 billion (S)

headline: World Briefing | Europe: Italy: Berlusconi Seeks Immigrant Curbs In Libya
abstract: Italian Prime Minister Silvio Berlusconi visits Libyan leader Col Muammar el-Qaddafi to open 335-mile gas pipeline between countries and to discuss ways to control increase in illegal immigration to Italy from Africa; Italy's new policy of immediately deporting all illegal aliens has been criticized by human right agencies (S)

headline: Ex-General Is Sworn In as President of Indonesia
abstract: Former Gen. Susilo Bambang Yudhoyono promised a new era of cleaner government and renewed growth for Southeast Asia's largest economy.

headline: Journal Columnist and Editor Is Set to Join Bloomberg News
abstract: Albert R Hunt, columnist and former Washington bureau chief of Wall Street Journal, who has spent nearly four decades working at paper, will join Bloomberg News's Washington bureau as managing editor for government reporting (S)

headline: F.D.A. Approves a Pill for Lung Cancer to Be Sold by Genentech and OSI
abstract: Genentech and OSI Pharmaceuticals win Food and Drug Administration approval to sell Tarceva, drug to treat lung cancer; Tarceva will be priced at slightly more than $2,000 wholesale for month's supply (M)

headline: Europe Union Agrees to Lift Arms Embargo on Libya
abstract: The move marks a further step toward returning Libya to the international diplomatic fold.

headline: Israeli Role in Gaza Strip Is to Expand
abstract: Prime Min Ariel Sharon says Israel is strengthening its military presence in northern Gaza Strip and will keep troops there until Palestinians stop firing rockets into Israel; in five days of often intense clashes in and around Jabaliya refugee camp, about 60 Palestinian have been killed, including militants and civilians; on Israeli side, two soldiers and three civilians have been killed; photo (M)

headline: World Business Briefing | Americas: Brazil: Soft Drink Investigation
abstract: World Business Briefi

headline: Ever-rising traffic overtaxes system : A rough road lies ahead for global transportation
Man Sentenced in Tax Schemes Also Releases Data on Lawyers
abstract: Federal Judge Susan Illston sentences Jerome Schneider, US's most prominent seller of offshore banks in tax evasion schemes, to six month prison term; Schneider releases documents identifying Manhattan lawyers who worked with him; says Justice Department and IRS broke promise to ask that he spend no time behind bars in return for his cooperation; says he will no longer cooperate with prosecutions unless government seeks reduction in sentence to no jail time (M)

headline: Jobs and health spur clash in last debate
Big Swiss Bank Receives a Warning Notice From the S.E.C.
abstract: UBS might face legal action from Securities and Exchange Commission over work it did for HealthSouth, hospital operator accused of nearly $3 billion in accounting fraud; UBS spokesman Mark Arena says SEC notice does not mention any bank employees by name; has opportunity to present its position before SEC makes any formal recommendation; photo (M)

headline: I.B.M. Prepares Substitution for Pensions of New Hires
abstract: IBM, dogged by complaints about changes it made in employee pensions in 1990's, decides to close its pension plan to new employees at end of year and give all new workers 401(k) plan instead; spokeswoman says that despite change, company is 'still committed to defined-benefit pensions' (M)

headline: Pilots Union Agrees to Cuts at Northwest
abstract: Northwest Airlines and Air Line Pilots Association reach tentative agreement on deal that would save airline $300 million in labor costs; settlement includes $265 millino in cuts, first granted to airline by any of its labor groups; photo (M)

headline: PlayStation 2 Shortage Frustrates More Than Buyers
abstract: Shortage of Sony PlayStation 2 consoles leaves retailers scrambling to meet holiday demand; Sony says shortage is tied to popularity of new console, but some analysts contend there may also be manufacturing problem (M)

headline: World Business Briefing | Australia: New Bid For Dairy Concern
abstract: San Miguel Corp of Philippines, raising prospects of bidding war with Fonterra Cooperative, offers 1.78 billion Australian dollars ($1.38 billion) for National Foods, Australia's biggest dairy company; graph (S)

headline: A Pouchful of Protection for Scary Times in the Sahel
abstract: War in Sudan has revved up business for makers of hijabs, leather-pouch amulets believed to ward off harm that are worn widely across Muslim region of Sahel; hijab makers there cater to all sides of conflict, rebels fighting Sudanese government, pro-government Arab militias and civilians seeking refuge from fighting; attachment to hijab, while marker of grave dangers of war in Darfur, also testifies to shared culture in this part of country; photos (M)

headline: G.M. Europe Picks Universal McCann
abstract: The European division of General Motors has consolidated the media planning and buying duties for car and truck brands like Chevrolet, Opel, Saab and Vauxhall in 45 markets at Universal McCann, part of the McCann Worldgroup division of the Interpublic Group of Companies. Billings were estimated at $700 million, of which Universal McCann had already handled about $500 million.    The decision came after a four-month review among Universal McCann and four others on the General Motors European media-agency roster: Carat, part of the Aegis Group; Initiative, also part of Interpublic; OMD, part of the Omnicom Group; and Starcom, part of the Starcom MediaVest division of the Publicis Groupe. Initiative continues to handle media duties for General Motors in Britain.

headline: On Italian Isle, Migrant Plight Draws Scrutiny
abstract: Hundreds of migrants in rickety boats who landed on Italian island of Lampedusa in recent days have been sent back to Libya almost immediately by airplane; Italian government responds quickly and contentiously this time to problem that other European governments have tried, and so far failed, to solve: what to do about flow of asylum seekers, mostly from Asia and Africa, many hundreds of whom have drowned while trying to cross Mediterranean after being put into unseaworthy boats by human traffickers; European leaders are debating plan proposed by German Interior Min Otto Schily to stem flow by building holding centers in North Africa and allowing only those whose asylum applications are approved there to proceed to Europe; Italy supports plan but officials from France, Belgium and Sweden object that camps would be set up in countries with poor records in protecting refugees' rights; human rights groups and United Nations warn that it could seal Europe off from legitimate asylum seekers; map (M)

headline: Stocks: 3M results offset gains from falling oil prices
World Business Briefing | Americas: Canada: Bank's Earnings Decline
abstract: Royal Bank of Canada reports 31 percent decline in fourth-quarter earnings, to 507 million Canadian dollars ($427 million); reports rise in revenue, to 4.6 billion Canadian dollars from 4.4 billion (S)

headline: Banks Test ID Device for Online Security
abstract: For years, banks gave away toasters to people who opened checking accounts; soon they may be distributing a more modern kind of appliance.    Responding to an increase in Internet fraud, some banks and brokerage firms plan to begin issuing small devices that would help their customers prove their identities when they log on to online banking, brokerage and bill-payment programs.

headline: World Business Briefing | Europe: Britain: Reuters Relocates Jobs
abstract: Reutern

headline: But Parliament chiefs say they want more commission changes : Withdrawal of nominee eases crisis for Europe
Germany Deports Radical Long Sought by Turks
abstract: German police arrest Metin Kaplan, founder and chief leader of Caliphate, banned Islamist organization, and put him on plane to Turkey; Kaplan is sought by Turkey to answer charges that he led 1998 foiled plot to fly explosive-armed plane into Ataturk mausoleum during ceremony to be attended by top leaders; Turkey's extradition request had been tied up in German court, but was recently approved; photo (M)

headline: Workers Demand Union at Wal-Mart Supplier in China
abstract: Thousands of Chinese workers at factory that makes telephones for Japanese company Uniden walk off job, demanding right to join labor union; workers, mostly yong women, are angry over their wages and what they say are abusive work conditions; scene at Uniden plant, in Shenzhen, reveals situation typical in China's booming new economy, where government is reluctant to enforce law that would oblige foreign companies to allow unions, for fear of losing overseas investment; analysts of China's labor scene say strikes are becoming far more common as younger migrant workers exposed to wealth of China's relatively rich eastern cities grow increasingly angry over what many see as their exploitation; map; Uniden supplies products to Wal-Mart; map (M)

headline: Murdoch Moves to Avoid a Friendly Fight for Control
abstract: News Corp chairman Rupert Murdoch is lining up support for succession plan involving his sons Lachlan and James in wake of Liberty Media head John C Malone's decision to increase its stake in voting shares in News Corp to 17 percent from 9 percent; Malone says he has no plans to try takeover, and people who know him say purchases is way to gain leverage in his effort to swap some of his cable programming assets for nonvoting shares in News Corp; Murdoch is said to be furious over Malone's move; Prince Walid bin Talal of Saudi Arabia says his holding companies own 3 percent of nonvoting shares in News Corp; says he is prepared to raise his stake and swap his nonvoting shares for voting shares in support of Murdoch; photo (Market Place column) (M)

headline: 6% Growth Surprises Government in Philippines
abstract: Philippine government reports 6.3 percent growth in economy in third quarter, compared with 4.8 percent a year earlier, beating expectations of economists; cites robust performance in agriculture and services, which grew 7.9 percent and 7.1 percent, respectively; photo (M)

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: The Future of Air Travel: Cheap Is In, Frills Are Out  No longer aspiring to be luxury liners, planes are now subways of the sky. Airlines like United and American still promote the full-service approach to flying, but the airline carrying the most passengers within the United States is Southwest, a discount carrier.     The transformation in the industry is rewarding companies like Southwest and JetBlue that are thinking up new ways to meet their customers' needs with few frills and low fares on popular routes. [Page A1.]    United Airlines will most likely terminate its employee pension plans and replace them with less-expensive retirement benefits, its chief financial officer said in an interview. [C3.]    Delta Air Lines is Atlanta's largest private employer, so the city is watching closely as the airline teeters on the edge of bankruptcy. [C3.]    A High-Tech Merger in France  Sagem, a French maker of electronic equipment, and Snecma, a state-controlled manufacturer of aircraft engines, announced a merger plan that would create a company worth more than $9 billion. Some analysts said the merger was driven by political interests. But Gregoire Olivier, above, Sagem's chief executive, said it made business sense. [C2.]    Questions for Ovitz in Disney Case  Michael S. Ovitz, the former president of Disney, described an aborted attempt to join the Sony Corporation and was grilled about whether Disney board members were informed about his performance. [C4.]    Lehman Settlement in Enron Suit  Lehman Brothers will pay $222.5 million to settle a class-action lawsuit contending that it and other brokerage firms and banks helped Enron mislead investors. [C2.]    China's Move Is Taken in Stride  Most Asian financial markets reacted with surprising calm to the Chinese central bank's announcement of its first increase in interest rates in nine years. [C2.]    Japan's central bank said consumer prices would turn slightly higher in 2005, heralding a possible end to a period of deflation. [C2.]    NTT DoCoMo Reports Profit Drop  NTT DoCoMo, Japan's top provider of mobile phone service, said its profit fell 6 percent for the most recent six-month period from a year earlier. Its rivals have moved more quickly to cut prices and offer faster data services. [C2.]    Oil Helps Stocks End Week Higher  Blue-chip stocks ended higher, helped by gains in energy companies. The major indexes rose for the week, with the Dow Jones industrial average rising 2.8 percent, and the Nasdaq composite index and the S.&P. 500-stock index each rising 3.1 percent. [C4.]    EBay Is Asked to Police Artifacts  The British Museum has asked eBay to stop the sale of ancient artifacts dug up by Britons who failed to report their discoveries as required by law. [B7.]    U.S. Asks Merck for Added Data  The Food and Drug Administration told Merck that it needed further data before it would approve the drug Arcoxia, a successor to the pain reliever Vioxx. [C3.]    Aon Withdraws Earnings Forecast  Aon's stock fell 5.6 percent after it withdrew its earnings forecast because of slow sales and the loss of contingency commissions, which it halted last week amid an investigation by Eliot Spitzer, the New York attorney general. [C12.]    ChevronTexaco Profits Rise 62%  ChevronTexaco said its third-quarter profit rose 62 percent, to $3.2 billion, as a result of rising oil prices. [C4.]

headline: Product Placement Moves to Cartoons
abstract: Cartoon series Shorties Watchin' Shorties on Comedy Central will incorporate names and products of sponsors into animated action; viewers will see animated product placements, ranging from subtle to blatant, in three of seven 30-minute episodes for Domino's Pizza, Red Bull energy sneakers and Vans sneakers; Activision will not have its video games placed in episodes, but will use characters--two babies who behave like rambunctious young aduts at whom shows are aimed--to introduce commercials for video game featuring skateboarder Tony Hawk; financial terms undisclosed; photo (M)

headline: Premier Says Ex-Government Erased Data on Madrid Attack
abstract: Prime Min Jose Luis Rodriguez Zapatero of Spain contends that government of his predecessor Jose Marie Aznar erased all presidential records related to Mar 11 train bombings before leaving office in Apr; aide to Zapatero says government officials worry that destruction of files might have eliminated evidence relevant to bombings; head of Aznar's party Angel Acebes says government did not erase any official documents or anything that could be useful to new government (M)

headline: Russia Moves to Auction Crucial Unit of Yukos
abstract: Several German companies that rushed to have their shares traded on exchanges in United States during bull market of late 1990's are now seriously thinking about abandoning market; are disenchanted by United States as source of capital and offended by what they view as oppressive new regulations adopted in aftermath of Enron and other corporate scandals; with trading volumes in New York that are, in most cases, a small fraction of their turnover in Europe, companies are less willing to bear legal costs, liability and bureaucracy of complying with rules; table shows German companies trading in United States (M)

headline: Top Shiite Leader in Iraq Is Unhurt in Bombing
abstract: Abdul Aziz al-Hakim, who has emerged as one of the country's most powerful political figures, was inside the building but unhurt in the blast.

headline: PeopleSoft's Ex-Chief Says He Misspoke to Analysts
abstract: Ousted PeopleSoft chief executive Craig A Conway, testifying in trial of Oracle suit against PeopleSoft's takeover defenses, says he was unclear but did not lie to analysts in 2003 when he suggested that pending software orders had been completed; says most of orders had been completed; Oracle lawyer suggests statement amounted to securities fraud (M)

headline: People and Accounts of Note
abstract: The Anheuser-Busch division of the Anheuser-Busch Companies in St. Louis has added to its agency roster the Playa del Rey, Calif., office of TBWA/Chiat/Day, part of the TBWA Worldwide division of the Omnicom Group, which will create campaigns for Michelob and Michelob Light beer. Spending for those brands, which had been handled by various agencies, was estimated at $25 million to $30 million.

headline: The Incredible Shrinking Investment Bank
abstract: Outlook for famous companies like Merrill Lynch and Morgan Stanley discussed in light of encroachments by universal banks such as Citigroup and J P Morgan, with their swollen balance sheets and ripe ambitions; investment bankers say two old-line firms are in similar quandaries but that Merrill faces most pressure to merge because it has become so much smaller; cite upcoming public offering of DreamWorks SKG's animation unit as example of how big banks use financial brawn and deal-making skill to muscle in on territory long owned by investment banks; photos; graphs showing stock declines this year for major Wall Street firms (M)

headline: Food Prices Slow in China, but Rises Loom in Other Sectors
abstract: After two years of accelerating inflation, consumer prices in China unexpectedly rose more slowly in October than in any month since April, as a bountiful harvest led to less rapid increases in food prices.

headline: An S.A.T. Tool Aimed at Children
abstract: A popular gift for children facing ever more standardized tests is the Time Tracker, which is meant to help children as young as 4 learn to manage their time. Page C2.

abstract: The Ad Store Hires.

headline: Legislators in Iran Dismiss Khatami Ally

headline: COMPANY BRIEFS

LEVEL 3 COMMUNICATIONS, Broomfield, Colo., bought the wholesale dial Internet access business of Sprint Corp., Overland Park, Kan., for $34 million in cash, to expand its managed modem business into selected new markets. headline: Oil slips again as price starts to hinder growth
European Public Uneasy Over Turkey's Bid to Join Union
abstract: European Union's executive committee will vote Oct 5 on report that says Turkey has reformed itself enough to merit entry talks; prospect of admitting Muslim country has set off fierce debate on nature of European identity; opinion polls indicate Europeans feel Turkey is not a European country; EU report largely ignores problems posed by Turkey's religious and cultural heritage and contends Turkey's embrace of liberty, democracy and rule of law could be model for other Muslim countries; photo; graph (M)

headline: Rights Group Finds Russia Ignores Sometimes Fatal Military Hazing
abstract: Human Rights Watch reports that hundreds of thousands of conscripts in Russian armed services are abused each year under cruel system of hazing that military leaders are unwilling to stop; says tradition is so vicious that thousands of first-year Russian soldiers are injured and dozens of them die; blames Pres Vladimir C Putin, among others, saying Russian government has been aware of situation for 10 years (M)

headline: Where Are the Economists?
abstract: WHEN you think about the economic issues facing the next president, you have to wonder why either candidate wants the job. There are the outsize budget deficits, high levels of private debt, a soaring trade deficit, growing numbers of Americans without health insurance, a possible bust in the housing bubble and an expansion that is not creating enough jobs and is probably already tapering to a crawl.    But at least these issues have come up in the campaign. One issue that has not is the corporate scandals that rocked the nation two years ago. Now Eliot Spitzer, New York's attorney general, has uncovered another dark hole of apparent corporate wrongdoing among the nation's largest, most respected insurance companies.

abstract: PeopleSoft Director Cites Reasons for Chief's Firing  A director of PeopleSoft said that Craig A. Conway, the company's chief executive, was fired on Friday in part because he made false statements at an analysts' conference in Sept. 2003.

headline: Bosnian Serbs Chided Over Pay in War Crimes
abstract: Officials at international criminal tribunal for former Yugoslavia criticize Bosnian Serb government for offering financial rewards to war crimes suspects who surrender to prosecutors; spokeswoman for court's chief prosecutor Carla Del Ponte accuses government of 'treating war criminals as VIP's' (S)

headline: Karzai Formally Named Winner of Afghan Presidential Election
abstract: A panel announced that irregularities it had investigated were not significant enough to change the overall result.

abstract: McDonald's Holdings of Japan says its profit tripled for first nine months of year, to 2.05 billion yen ($19.2 million); revenue rises 3.2 percent, to 230 billion yen ($2.2 billion) (S)

headline: New Violence Hinders Relief Efforts in Western Sudan
abstract: Sudanese government crackdown on camp for displaced people in Darfur keeps out relief organizations even as peace talks continue; UN envoy Jan Pronk and Sec Gen Kofi Annan denounce forced dispersals from camp (S)

Rights Group Says U.S. Fails to Investigate Abuses in Afghanistan
abstract: Human Rights Watch said today that new cases of deaths of men in United States custody in Afghanistan have come to light.

headline: Aid to Iraq should be sent faster, donors say
NIKE TO APPEAL CHINESE COPYRIGHT RULING
abstract: Nike Inc. said yesterday that it would appeal a Chinese court ruling ordering it to pay a cartoonist 300,000 yuan ($36,000) for copyright infringement. A Beijing court ruled on Wednesday that a stickman figure used in a worldwide Nike advertising campaign infringed on the copyright for the ''Little Matchman'' character created by a Chinese cartoonist, Zhu Zhiqiang. The court ruled that Nike must also post a public apology to Mr. Zhu on the Web site Sina.com, The Beijing Star Daily newspaper reported, citing a court statement. Wen Liyuan, a Nike spokesman in Shanghai, said the ''the stickman works of Nike were created and completed independently by a third party under the commission of Nike.'' Nike is in Beaverton, Ore.

headline: Karzai Promises Security in First Speech Since Election
abstract: President Hamid Karzai today delivered his first speech since the election commission declared him the official winner of the Oct. 9 presidential race.

headline: Spain Is Seeking to Integrate Growing Muslim Population
abstract: La Giralda, this city's grand tower, with its warm terra-cotta colors, delicate brick patterns and a height of almost 300 feet, was once called Spain's perfect minaret. Its twin stands in Marrakesh, Morocco, a reminder of the centuries-old ties between the two countries.     Seville's minaret has been the bell tower of the city's Roman Catholic cathedral for the past 500 years. Today, however, many of those who walk by it daily are again Moroccans, part of the growing number of Muslim immigrants to Spain. While they have not talked about reclaiming the minaret, they are seeking permission to build a large mosque here, as have Islamic immigrants have in six other Spanish cities.

AT&T to Settle a Shareholders' Suit
abstract: AT&T Corp agrees to pay $100 million to settle lawsuit by shareholders who claimed carrier lied about its finances; payment will be split between AT&T and broadband subsidiary MediaOne Group purchased by Comcast Corp in 2002; AT&T says it will seek reimbursement from insurers (S)d

headline: A City Seeks to Sell Itself
abstract: Jacksonville, Fla, home of Super Bowl XXXIX, begins brand-identity campaign timed to capitalize on Super Bowl; campaign was developed by Dalton Agency; photo (M)

headline: Woolworths wins fight for Australia liquor company
The Pitcairn Paradise, or an Island of Depravity?
abstract: Pitcairn Island, most remote inhabited island in world, is scene of sex crimes trial involving half permanent male population of island; seven men are accused of 55 counts of rape, indecent assault and gross indecency against Pitcairn girls ages 5 to 15; island, before trial, was primarily known as site where Bounty mutineers, led by master's mate Fletcher Christian, fled to escape prosecution in 1789; is primarily inhabited by crew's descendants and descendants of Tahitian girls brought to island after mutiny; recent allegations of sexual misconduct have made it possible for many women to speak out who had maintained silence because of small, intimate life on Pitcairn; island life described; intermingling between those accused and their accusers discussed; photos; map; (M)

headline: Taiwan makes an overture to Beijing
Country's insatiable demand robs Japanese steel firms of ability to set prices : China alters the balance at iron ore talks
World Business Briefing | Asia: Japan: Air Freight Rescue For PlayStation
abstract: Sony Corp is using Russian cargo planes to fly new version of its PlayStation 2 games console to Europe after incident in Suez Canal disrupted supplies (S)

headline: Breakfast of Champions on the Tundra
abstract: Back in the mid-90's, I was working with a curator, and we agreed we would travel to the sub-Arctic of Russia. This curator said that there were communities in the sub-Arctic that had folk traditions, folk music and folk dance that had never been seen outside Russia, and that we should go on a curatorial journey to discover them.    So it was in the middle of winter, and we flew to Moscow and then from Moscow we flew up into these small towns. I couldn't even begin to articulate their names. There is no such thing as a hotel, just community centers in which there was a bed with a sheet on it, and a thin blanket, and there was a hole in the floor with cardboard covering it from the rest of the room, and a sink with cold water.

headline: Can Stern Play Media Kingmaker?
abstract: Advertisers and analysts say Howard Stern's planned move from Infinity Broadcasting to Sirius Satellite Radio could be seminal moment in battle between satellite and broadcast radio; also say Stern could be used as weapon for Sirius in its rivalry with larger XM Satellite Radio; say Stern will help attract demographic group highly valued by advertisers, men 18 to 34 (M)

headline: FANNIE MAY CANDY STORES START TO REOPEN
abstract: Fannie May Confections reopens first of 47 stores it plans to bring back in next month in Chicago area, including two in Wisconsin and four in Indiana; Fannie May and Fannie Farmer were bought by Alpine Confections in April for $38.9 million; Archibald Candy Corp filed for bankruptcy in January and closed stores and its Chicago factory in February (S)

headline: Israeli Military Kills 4 Palestinian Militants in Gaza Operation
abstract: Israeli military kills two armed members of Al Aksa Martyrs Brigades and two members of Hamas in separate airstrikes, as troops in tanks and armored vehicles push into Beit Lahia in Gaza Strip, extending two-week-old operation aimed at silencing Palestinian rocket fire; Palestinians fire two more rockets at Israeli communities just outside Gaza; they fall harmlessly, as they usually do; Israeli radar system, built to warn of incoming rockets, works as intended for first time, sounding siren before rockets landed (M)

headline: RYERSON TULL WILL BUY INTEGRIS METALS FOR $410 MILLION

abstract: Luis German Sanchez, Quintana Roo state police commander, reports that three federal agents and six other people found dead at two separate locations outside Cancun, Mexico, appear to have been victims of drug trafficking related violence (S)

abstract: United Airlines, trying to restructure after nearly two years in bankruptcy protection, tells its unions that it wants to terminate its four employee pension plans and seek additional wage and benefit cuts, as part of plan to cut another $2 billion per year in costs; termination of pension plans would require approval from Federal Bankruptcy Court; United would have to convince judge that it has no other chance of survival to secure approval; if United terminates its plans, federal Pension Benefit Guaranty Corp, which insures pension benefits in event of default, would have to assume most of airline's unsecured debt to its present and future retirees, which it estimates at $8.3 billion; government has calculated that it would be responsible for about $6.4 billion of that total (M)

headline: Nordic Countries Come Out Near the Top in Two Business Surveys
abstract: Reports by World Economic Forum and World Bank show Nordic countries dominate top ranks of lists of most competitive economies in world and best places to do business; World Economic Forum survey shows Finland is world's most competitive economy, and Sweden, Denmark, Norway and Iceland were 3d, 5th, 6th and 10th, respectively; World Bank report shows Denmark, Finland, Norway and Sweden are ranked near top as well, with US coming in second on both lists (M)

headline: World Business Briefing | Americas: Brazil: Inflation Up
abstract: Inflation in Brazil rose in Oct on surging fuel prices, reinforcing expectation that central bank will raise interest rates; consumer price index rose 0.44 percent (S)

headline: Airbus Says Its A380 Jet Is Over Budget
abstract: Airbus says development costs for A380, which will be world's biggest passenger jet when it enters service in 2006, will exceed budgets by 5 percent to 15 percent; says cost overrun will have little impact on profitability of program; expects to achieve 10 percent operating margin in 2005 (S)

headline: Roads Lead to a New Way of Life for Rural Ethiopia
abstract: Public road-building project leads to better life for rural residents of Ethiopia; World Bank transport director Maryvonne Plessis-Fraissard explains changes in lending program, which has doubled money for African roads since 2000 to $800 million; villagers describe how life has changed since road was built between Awasa and Shamene village; Joseph Lekie, father of nine, sees road as opportunity for his children to have better future; photos; maps (M)

headline: Digital Picture Frames Reviewed
abstract: David Pogue State of the Art column on digital picture frame, flat-panel screen designed exusively for showing digital photos; connects to computer by USB cable and doubles as memory-card reader; user can change display at touch of button or use it for slide show; photos; drawing (M)

headline: Cuba Counters Prostitution With AIDS Programs
abstract: Like many prostitutes who ply their trade in the darkened bars and discos near tourist hotels here, Mar√≠a says she does not go out every night. But whenever money gets tight and her 12-year-old son is hungry, she puts on a red miniskirt, puts rouge on her lips and heads for El Conejito bar, a thinly disguised rendezvous point.    ''Most of the tourists come to look for girls, tobacco, you know, the things they cannot get in their country,'' she said. ''They say the Cuban girls are very hot.''

headline: All Things Dutch and and Top Down Music
abstract: Lisa Napoli Online Diary column; Holland Ring links more than 800 sites dedicated to information about Holland; Web site bubbieandzadie.blogspot.com brings Hanukkah alive for children, especially those without living grandparents; thestepfamilylife.com provides information and help to people in blended families; music video recreates road trip from Los Angeles to New York City in a convertible; drawings (M)

headline: The Year on Wall Street: Treating Investment Bankers Like Bartenders
abstract: IT was a great year for Wall Street, or so the earnings numbers seem to say. New stock issues are selling again and corporate bond underwriting set a record. President Bush is pushing a Social Security plan that would divert huge sums of money into investment accounts, generating fees for Wall Street. Brokerage stocks have been market leaders in the postelection rally    But the real man of the year on Wall Street -- or at least the man whose plight is emblematic of the new Wall Street reality -- will not be sharing in those bonuses. Instead, Daniel Bayly is awaiting sentencing in federal court in Houston, where he is likely to be ordered to spend a few years in prison for doing something that few on Wall Street would have seen as a crime.

headline: Simple Twist of Fate
abstract: Artemis Records chief executive and chairman Danny Goldberg comments on his career; list; photo (M)

headline: BlackBerry, Beloved Gadget, Continues to Thrive
abstract: Research in Motion's BlackBerry wireless e-mail device continues to thrive despite challenge from PalmOne's Treo, which offers more features; is example of how smart engineering and keen understanding of customers can let small company survive in shadow of better-financed giants; drawing (M)

headline: New king in Cambodia
World Briefing | Europe: Britain: 3 Charged In 'Dirty Bomb' Sting
abstract: Three men in Britain are arrested and charged with seeking dirty bomb-making materials; News of the World, British tabloid, arranged undercover sting operation and then notified police (S)

headline: When a Utility Saves Money, Who Benefits?
abstract: Texas Pacific Group that is trying to buy Portland General Electric from Enron Corp for $2.3 billion says at Oregon Public Utility Commission hearing that if savings resulted from combining functions like accounting, money must be returned to customers; says if savings are in taxes, utiilty's owners are entitled to money; case has significance beyond Oregon because it has prompted corporations and landlords to begin asking if they are being overcharged for electricity, issue that may spread to other cities as companies seek ways to lower costs (M)

headline: Dutch Hold 38 on Terror Charges After Raid on Camp
abstract: Dutch police raid terrorist training camp for Kurdish separatists in Liempde; arrest 38 people there and at other places in country in ongoing crackdown on militants; are looking for Abu Khaled, Syrian who they say is leader of Islamic cell responsible for killing Dutch filmmaker Theo van Gogh; map (M)

headline: World Business Briefing | Asia: Japan: Steel Shortage At Carmaker
abstract: Nissan Motor chief executive Carlos Ghosn, citing shortage of steel, says company may be forced to reduce production by as many as 40,000 vehicles; says loss may reduce company's profit by as much as 16 billion yen ($155 billion) (S)

abstract: Article by One Remote Systems chief executive Ken Scharen on his experiences outsourcing work to computer programmers and artists in remote offices around world; photo (M)

abstract: Steven Schulman, lawyer for shareholders who are suing Walt Disney Co, begins spirited cross-examination of chief executive Michael D Eisner, sparring with him on topics ranging from early days of his career to involvement of board in firing former president Michael S Ovitz (M)

abstract: Economic View column notes statement by Rep Jim Saxton, vice chairman of Congressional Joint Economic Committee, questioning wisdom of Federal Reserve's decision to raise short-term interest rates on Nov 10; says some economists say Saxton crossed line that separates monetary policy from politicians who control fiscal policy; photo (M)

abstract: Nortel Networks says it is delaying for third time a restatement of its results dating back to 2001 and that it had found additional errors that would result in reductions in revenue for 1999 and 2000 (S)

abstract: North Atlantic Treaty Orgn is winding up its peacekeeping operation in Bosnia and making way for new European-led force; European Union has never before taken on military operation on this scale (M)

abstract: Intelsat reports it has lost contact with one of its satellites and that, as result, $3 billion takeover deal with consortium led by Apax Partners could fall apart (S)

abstract: Federal Judge Leonard B Sand rules that former Adelphia Communications vice president Michael J Rigas must face second trial on 15 securities fraud counts; first trial resulted in deadlock in July (S)

abstract: Emmis Communications will buy WLUP-FM Chicago from Bonneville International in exchange for three of its Phoenix radio stations; Bonneville will also pay $70 million (S)

headline: Equity Firm Said to Have Deal to Buy Control of Fortunoff
abstract: Fortunoff, the jewelry and home furnishings company founded in 1922, is expected to announce today that it will sell its business to Trimaran Capital Partners, a private equity firm, in a deal that values the chain at $280 million.    The Fortunoff family would retain 25 percent of the company, executives involved in the deal said last night. ''They still want to be part of its growth,'' one executive said.

headline: Giuliani Forms Investment Advisory Firm
abstract: The former prosecutor who targeted insider trading in the 1980's is now joining Wall Street.

headline: Large-Capacity Hard Drive to Go Is More Than Just a Flash of Memory
abstract: New USB Pocket Hard Drive from Seagate crams storage power of 2.5- or 5-gigabyte hard drive into shockproof, palm-size chassis; photo (S)

headline: Iraqi Judge Questions Aides of Hussein With Lawyers
abstract: The chief investigative judge for the Iraqi tribunal established to try Saddam Hussein and his top aides said Saturday that he had held formal interviews with Ali Hassan al-Majid, known to Iraqis as Chemical Ali, and Sultan Hashim Ahmed, the Iraqi defense minister during the United States-led invasion last year.    Their questioning followed a flurry of statements by top Iraqi officials indicating that the beginning of formal trials was imminent for least some of a core group of 12 former members of Mr. Hussein's government who are being held in an American military detention center near the Baghdad airport. On Thursday, a Jordan-based legal team retained by Mr. Hussein's family said the former Iraqi ruler had met with a lawyer for the first time since his capture on Dec. 13 last year.

headline: Vodafone seeks 3G breakthrough in Europe : Mobile phones' new tune
Some cringe, but others see profit in a new demographic : 'Chav' enters the British lexicon

abstract: Estonian Customs Department spokesman reports that smugglers are using underwater hose and plastic pipe to illegally transport alcohol into country from Russia and Belarus and avoid high excise duty (S)

headline: China Preparing to Enact Law Against Taiwan Secession
abstract: China's legislature has indicated that it may mandate military action if Taiwan declares independence.

headline: Cingular Deal Is Approved; Some Assets Must Be Sold
abstract: Justice Department regulators approve $41 billion purchase of AT&T Wireless by Cingular Wireless; says Cingular and AT&T Wireless must sell airwave licenses, customer contracts and other assets in 11 states to ensure that rivals can provide competing service; Federal Communications Commission is expected to approve merger (M)

headline: HAD ENOUGH?
abstract: National Fluid Milk Processor Promotion Board hires Lindsay Lohan and other young celebrities for 'Got Milk? campaign, but promotion of flavored milks raises questions about promoting more sugar consumption (S)

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: Continental Airlines Wants $500 Million in Reductions  Continental Airlines said that it must cut wages and benefits by $500 million a year to become profitable given industry conditions.

headline: Be Commander in Chief of a 30-Foot Radius
abstract: Belkin's MediaPilot wireless keyboard works with Windows and Mac computers and other electronic equipment within specified range; photo (S)

headline: Fox News, Media Elite
abstract: Fox's cable news channel dramatically consolidated its ratings gains of past few years on Election Night, drawing 8.1 million viewers, more than tripling its own election night prime-time performance in 2000 and clobbering other cable news networks; Nielsen Media Research says CBS, ABC and NBC lost millions of viewers; Fox News came closer to CBS in ratings than CNN did to Fox News; top rating among cable news channels will make it harder for Fox News to present self as scrappy underdog and could undercut its claim to serve as alternative to what its executives and some of its on-air talent distainfully call media establishment; chairman Roger Ailes comments on identity crisis, phone interview; ratings graphs; photos (M)

headline: Help! What Do We Do With All This Stuff? 'Regift,' of Course
abstract: Some people, it should be noted, would never ''gift.'' They're not Scrooges, they just shudder at what they see as another symptom of language's decay. But ''regift''? Now there's a word that o'erleaps linguistic pickiness. It's modern poetry.     But it's a word, or at least a concept, that's on a lot of minds today, as much of America faces a cold gray dawn awash in stuff, scratches its collective head, and muses furtively, ''Do you suppose I could just rewrap that and give it to Aunt Mabel?''

headline: Management Shake-Up Continues at Schwab
abstract: Jody Bilney resigns as executive vice president of Charles Schwab Corp; is at least fourth senior executive to leave firm this year (S)

headline: Wall St. Lobby Quietly Tackles Social Security
abstract: Wall Street has begun quiet lobbying campaign in support of Pres Bush's plan to funnel hundreds of billions of dollars of future Social Security funds into privately held investment accounts; chief executives of most financial firms have refused to take public stand in support of private accounts, wary of being seen as too eager to embrace potential new revenue stream; Securities Industry Association recently issued report arguing that private accounts would not be financial bonanza for Wall Street; Investment Company Institute, lobbying arm for mutual fund industry, has not endorsed private accounts nor has it lobbied Congress on matter; institute recently hired as its communications director F Gregory Ahern, former executive at State Street Corp who was involved in that firm's aggressive lobbying effort for private accounts during late 1990's; Alliance for Worker Retirement Security has begun meeting with Congressional and White House staff members, pushing idea that private accounts are not only good for country but also good for business; Club for Growth, group financed largely by conservative business leaders that supports like-minded Congressional candidates, has also been active in drive for privately held Social Security accounts; many top Wall Street executives are strong supporters of Pres Bush and are philosophically in agreement with idea of applying independence of capital markets to Social Security program; chart; photo (M)

headline: Filipino journalist is 4th killed in month
World Business Briefing | Asia: Japan: Hitachi Forecasts Profit
abstract: Japanese electronics company Hitachi raises its forecast for profit in six-month period ended Sept 30, citing strong demand in United States for digital electronics products like flat-panel televisions and DVD players; expects to report profit of about 41 billion yen ($382 million) for period, first half of its fiscal year, up from 5.4 billion yen year earlier (S)

headline: Delta Reports That Its Cash Is Dwindling Rapidly
abstract: Delta Air Lines, which is struggling to avoid bankruptcy filing, expects to lose as much as $675 million for third quarter and is using cash at steep rate (S)

headline: Ethnic Clashes Erupt in China, Leaving 150 Dead
abstract: Violent clashes between members of the Muslim Hui ethnic group and the majority Han group left nearly 150 people dead, journalists and witnesses in the region said today.

headline: World Briefing | Africa: Congo: Renegade Soldiers Gain Ground
abstract: Raising concerns of a surge in Congo's five-year war, renegade soldiers in the country's east took two more villages -- Kayna and Kirumba -- in their battles with government troops sent to the region by President Joseph Kabila, officials said. A government delegation sought to defuse tensions in the volatile North Kivu region and get the peace process back on track through negotiation.   Marc Lacey (NYT)

headline: Religious Leader's Arrest in Killing Incites Holy Men and Hindu Nationalists Across India
abstract: November 11 arrest of Hindu leader Jayendra Saraswati for orchestrating murder of temple manager A Sankaraman, who questioned Saraswati's policies and ethics, has set off protests by thousands of his devotees in Uttar Pradesh; Hindu nationalists, including Bharatiya Janata Party, which lost elections in May, see case as way to galvanize supporters; map; photos (M)

headline: Two Law Firms to Join Forces
abstract: Piper Rudnick, corporate law firm with offices mainly in mid-Atlantic and Midwest, will merge with Gray Cary, which has large technology practice in California, to create one of largest national law firms; merger will result in corporate firm with more than 1,300 lawyers and 20 offices; new firm will be called Piper Rudnick Gray Cary LLP; will be run by four-member executive team, headed by Piper Rudnick co-chairmen Frank B Burch Jr and Lee I Miller; Gray's chairman-chief executive J Terence O'Malley will serve as US managing partner (M)

headline: A New Account for Goldfish
abstract: Pepperidge Farm unit of Campbell Soup Co asks BrightHouse Live in Atlanta to develop concepts for advertising Goldfish line of crackers, pretzels and other snacks, which Young & Rubicam Advertising has handled since 1998; Pepperidge Farm decision is first step affecting Campbell Soup account at Young & Rubicam; photo (M)

headline: Technology Briefing | Telecommunications: Scientific-Atlanta Posts 31% Profit Rise
abstract: Scientific-Atlantic's profit rose 31 percent in fiscal first quarter ended Oct 1; earnings rose to $55.9 million compared with $42.7 million year ago; sales increased 14 percent, to $452.7 million from $395.6 million year earlier (S)

headline: Balance Sheet : Derivative ambiguity
Internet Giants File 7 Suits Aimed at Stopping Spam
abstract: America Online, Microsoft Corp, Yahoo and EarthLink files new round of lawsuits against senders of junk e-mail, or span; suits include first filed by America Online against spammers who use instant messaging, practice online industry calls spimming; seven lawsuits are filed in four states under federal antispam law; Yahoo sues East Coast Exotic Entertainment Group and Epoth, providers of sex-related content, accusing them of sending anonymous e-mail with sexually explicit subject lines and with no option for removing name from mailing list (M)

headline: Rumsfeld Urges a Latin Push Against Terror
abstract: Defense Sec Donald H Rumsfeld says that ability of terrorist organizations to move people, weapons and money across Latin American borders can be constrained only through increased cooperation among governments in region; discusses issue at defense ministers' meeting in Ecuador (S)

headline: A Torture Report Compels Chile to Reassess Its Past
abstract: Investigative commission has completed and is about to publish 1,200-page report on torture and disappearance of political prisoners in Chile under military rule of Gen Augusto Pinochet between 1973 and 1989; report is based on testimony of 35,000 victims and details techniques and locations where torture occurred; commander of army Gen Juan Emilio Cheyre admits uniformity of torture reports betrays 'institutional' responsibility, but other branches of military remain quiet, particularly Navy; judges have ruled that military officers involved in disappearances can be denied amnesty and required to serve prison terms; Socialist-led government of Pres Ricardo Lagos must now decide how to compensate victims; photo (M)

headline: For the No-Return DVD Rental, It's '48 Hrs.,' Then Fade to Black
abstract: Flexplay movie rental service uses special DVD that becomes unplayable 48 hours after packaging is opened; photo (S)

headline: Trump Hotels Said to Avoid Bankruptcy in Deal
abstract: Trump Hotels and Casino Resorts Inc, struggling holding company that controls Donald J Trump's casinos, reaches preliminary agreement with its investors to restructure $1.8 billion in debt, fending off possible bankruptcy filing and leaving Trump as company's chairman and chief executive; Trump's stake in company will be reduced from 56 percent of shares to about 27 percent; bondholders will be swapping about $575 million in debt in return for equity stake that will leave them in control of about 63 percent to 65 percent of company's shares (M)

headline: Political Ad Policy At Viacom Is Protested
abstract: Advocacy group Compare Decide Vote starts campaign urging Viacom to accept political advertising on its MTV Networks cable channels; campaign began after one of group's commercials promoting Sen John Kerry was rejected by Comedy Central; MTV says its policy prohibits accepting all political advertising for MTV channel or any political spots for other channels that are not sponsored by candidates or party committees (S)

A High-Wire Act at Warner Brothers
abstract: Warner Bros, which is opening five major films by end of year backed by pricey marketing campaigns, gets off to disappointing start with release of Polar Express; poor opening is blow to studio, but is unlikely to significantly change studio's strategy of making big bets on star vehicles and event films; president Alan Horn comments; photos (M)

headline: Palestinian Led Sinai Blasts, Egypt Says
abstract: Egyptian Interior Ministry announces that bombings of three resort areas along Sinai coast on Oct 7 were organized by Eyad Said Saleh, disgruntled Palestinian who worked as driver and was bent on killing as many Israeli tourists as possible in revenge for Israeli assault against Gaza Strip that killed and wounded scores of Palestinians; says nine men were involved in attack and two of them, including Saleh, died unintentionally in attack at Taba Hilton (S)

headline: Vodafone to Buy Back More Shares
abstract: Vodafone Group reports 4 percent increase in sales, to 16.8 billion pounds sterling, for six months ended September 30; reports net loss for period of 3.2 billion pounds sterling; plans to double dividends and increase share buyback program by 1 billion pounds sterling ($1.9 billion); photo (M)

headline: Technology Briefing | Telecommunications: Nokia Gains Market Share
abstract: Nokia, world's largest maker of mobile phones, reportedly gains market share in third quarter, to 30.9 percent from 29.7 percent; Samsung overtakes Motorola to become world's second largest mobile phone company, with 13.8 percent of market (S)

headline: Giving Voice to Video Games
abstract: Game producers are turning to voice-over professionals to weave spoken narratives throughout games as video games take on cinematic feel; use of union artists assures quality, but at high cost that worries industry; photos (M)

headline: In Drowned Village, Grim Searches, Quick Burials
abstract: Many of undersea earthquake's victims are also most vulnerable--old men, women and children unable to outrun the sea; in Cuddalore, on India's southeast coast, fisherman spends day searching for bodies of his wife and three children; wife's body, found in morgue, is quickly buried in mass grave; photo (M)

headline: Inkjets Shrink, and Hewlett Sees Many New Uses
abstract: Hewlett-Packard plans to use improved technology for inkjet printing to aggressively enter range of new markets beyond printing, including television and computer displays, printed electronic circuits, automotive fuel-injection systems and even drug delivery; is poised to offer inkjet nozzle with over 3,000 tiny jets crammed onto surface of each print head; diversification strategy is one reason Vyomesh Joshi's Imaging and Printing Group is thriving in face of new competition in printer business from Dell Inc, which has cut into Hewlett-Packard's market share; graph of technology's increasing speed; photo (M)

headline: After Corporate Scandals, Seeing the New Challenges
abstract: Former Honeywell chief executive Larry Bossidy discusses tough new competitive challenges facing corporations and management executives, interview (S)

headline: Open Season on Others' Ideas
abstract: Daniel Akst column comments on growing phenomenon of people benefiting from intellectual efforts of others without paying full freight; cites examples of bootlegger selling illegal copy of movie, teen-ager trading music files over Internet, and American patient importing prescription drugs; holds while free flow of intellectual property can be wonderful, there is something to be said for profit enjoyed by creators of patented or copyright-protected ideas or products (M)

headline: Worried Merchants Throw Discounts at Shoppers
abstract: American merchants, worried over mediocre post-Thanksgiving weekend sales, rush to mark down merchandise; retail analyst John Morris says retailers have made complete about-face since beginning of November, when 5 percent fewer goods than last year were marked down; photos (M)
