abstract: Brazilian peacekeepers and Haitian police surround heavily armed former soldiers and open talks to eject rebels from home of former Pres Jean-Bertrand Aristide (S)

headline: Iran Reportedly Hides Work on a Longer-Range Missile
abstract: Iranian dissident group will claim that Iran is secretly developing longer-range ballistic missile than it has publicly acknowledged, with capacity to strike targets as far away as Berlin; group, National Council of Resistance, will say missile could have capacity to carry nuclear warheads, and is being developed with help from North Korean scientists even as Iran agrees to curbs on its nuclear porogram in new pact with three European countries; Defense Min Ali Shamkhani rejects reports that Iran is seeking to produce longer-range missile; photo (M)

headline: Magazine Ad Pages Up 3.8% in November
abstract: Publishers Information Bureau reports that magazine ad pages rose 3.8 percent in November (S)

headline: F.T.C. Files Complaints Over Weight-Loss Ads
abstract: FTC, continuing its efforts to reduce fraudulent weight-loss advertisements, files complaints against six marketers and sends cautionary letters to publications that printed their ads (S)

headline: From Colombia's Upper Class, Rebel and His Foil Diverged
abstract: Jailed Colombian guerrilla commander Ricardo Palmera and his brutal exploits are front-page news as government prepares to extradite him to US on cocaine-trafficking charges, but in his northern hometown of Valledupar Palmera is recalled as prominent member of oligarchy who produced plays, hobnobbed in elite social club and had bright future as banker; photos; map; Rodrigo Tovar, right-wing antiguerrilla leader and Palmera's adversary, is similarly remembered as party-going aristocrat who grew up on same upper-class street; 54-year-old Palmera, who may be extradicted unless rebels free 63 kidnapping victims, started attending clandestine meetings in late 1980's of leftist professionals committed to addressing wide disparity between rich and poor and was later in forefront of peasant movement; he left for mountains in 1989, while Tovar, landowner and target for rebel extortionists, joined paramilitaries that are now negotiating with government (M)

headline: New shopping buzz in Paris
Effort to cool economy has a way to go in China
Remark on Homosexuality Delays Seating of European Panel
abstract: Jose Barroso, set to take over presidency of European Commission, European Union's executive body, withdraws his slate of commissioners rather than withdraw nomination of Rocco Buttiglione as commissioner for justice, freedom and security; Buttiglione raised hackles amoung union's left-leaning legislators at confirmation hearing by calling homosexuality 'sin;' commission of current president, Romano Prodi, will stay on as caretaker until Barroso presents new lineup to Parliament; dispute suggests there is some life in Parliament, often maligned as costly and moribund (M)

headline: EU hints at easing arms embargo on China
On the Open Internet, a Web of Dark Alleys
abstract: Recent arrest of Mark Robert Walker on charges of using roommate's computer to offer aid to terrorist group and helping run jihadist Web site highlights near impossibility of tracking terrorist communications online; case reportedly was broken only after Walker's roommate tipped off police; ability of terrorists and other dark elements to communicate covertly online remains daunting security problem that may prove impossible to solve; drawing (M)

headline: J.P. Morgan Forms Venture With Broker to Britain's Elite
abstract: J P Morgan Chase and Cazenove Group, 181-year-old broker with gilt-edged relationships to some of Britain's most powerful executives, announces long-awaited joint venture that puts Cazenove in charge of all of J P Morgan's British investment banking business; new partnership, J P Morgan Cazenove, will be 50 percent owned by each firm and will handle corporate finance and merger advice for both companies' British clients (M)

headline: BLACKSTONE TO SELL REMAINING STAKE IN OIL REFINER
abstract: Blackstone Group will sell its remaining 21 percent stake in oil refiner Premcor for about $620.3 million (S)

headline: A Chip That Holds Your Medical Profile
abstract: Med-InfoChip is offering consumers pinky-sized device costing $70 that, when plugged into computer, displays a complete medical profile; drawing (S)

headline: The Dollar's Long-Term Direction: Down
abstract: US dollar is seen resuming downward course following slight upturn on news of Pres Bush's re-election; most economists believe further declines in dollar are inevitable as administration attempts to narrow current accounts deficit, which has reached nearly $600 billion; some economists believe crisis could occur as Asian policy makers shift from present export-led growth strategies, which rely on large purchases of US Treasury securities, to policies aimed at managing internal demand (M)

headline: Banning channel accused of hate speech could be difficult : France finds Beirut station a turnoff
'Desperate Housewives' Can Follow You, Wirelessly
abstract: LocationFree LCD television set from Sony connects wirelessly to Internet for Web surfing, e-mail and television sites; base station allows wireless viewing anywhere at home when connected to cable or satellite box; photo (S)

headline: Weak Dollar Sending More U.S. Investors Abroad
abstract: Americans have been stepping up purchases of foreign stocks and bonds as dollar's decline has accelerated and foreigners have slowed their buying of securities in US; Americans bought $51.9 billion of foreign stocks and bonds as of end of October, compared with $36.2 billion in all of 2003; recent fall in dollar, which has amounted to 6.3 percent against broad index of foreign currencies since August, is intensifying focus on investing abroad; largest flow to one country, $12.3 billion, went to Britain in October; in Japan, American investors bought $2.7 billion worth of stocks and sold $531 million worth of bonds; Pres Bush says that 'policy of my government is a strong-dollar policy,' but traders have been ignoring such comments because they believe administration will accept further decline in currency; euro is valued at $1.3412 after 0.8 percent decline in dollar; 1;1 percent drop against Japanese yen leaves dollar at 104.23 yen (M)

headline: Afghan Militants Threaten to Kill 3 U.N. Workers
abstract: Militants said they would be killed if demands for the release of prisoners and the withdrawal of foreign troops were not met by noon Wednesday.

headline: China Sees Chances for Fun and Profit Offshore
abstract: Flood of Chinese tourists across South Pacific, in places like Northern Mariana Islands, reflects China's new interest in region for tourism, fishing and investment; photo; map; China, with new air links, is emerging as economic power in Pacific, where mini-states of Oceania straddle crucial shipping lanes and valuable fishing grounds (M)

headline: World Briefing | Africa: South Africa: Icons? Check No. 19
abstract: The public television network SABC apologized for broadcasting the series ''Great South Africans,'' in which viewers' nominations and votes determined a list of the 100 greatest South Africans, after the poll conferred greatness on some unsavory characters, including white supremacists and a disgraced match-fixing cricket captain. The No.1 spot was given to Nelson Mandela, but viewers awarded the 19th spot on the list to Hendrik F. Verwoerd, the principal architect of apartheid who forced millions of blacks into so-called homelands. Eugene TerreBlanche, a self-proclaimed racist who recently completed a prison sentence for attempted murder, was voted No.25. Network officials said the series, modeled on a popular BBC program, had ''no intention to hurt'' but was flawed in its formulation. The series was pulled.   Michael Wines (NYT)

headline: Canada's Farmers Profit From Being Told What to Do
abstract: Canada's dairy and poultry farmers benefit from Canada's unusual system known as supply management; system allows only trickle of duty-free imports and otherwise imposes tariffs reaching 300 percent; country's 22,680 dairy, chicken, turkey and egg farmers produce fixed amount under quotas in system that maintains stable prices and assures markets; World Trade Organization's current attempt at overhauling global agricultural trade will most likely turn some of its attention to Canadian arrangement; photo (L)

headline: Journalist is latest killed in Philippines : Reporter is found dead
Technology Briefing | Deals: Red Hat To Buy Some Netscape Software
abstract: Red Hat, world's biggest distributor of free Linux computer-operating system, agrees to buy Netscape security software from America Online unit of Time Warner for $20.5 million (S)

headline: World Business Briefing | Europe: Germany: A Charge At Truckmaker
abstract: World Business Briefing: Germany: A C

headline: World Briefing | Africa: Zimbabwe: U.N. Report Rejected
abstract: Zimbabwe government criticizes United Nations report accusing Pres Robert Mugabe's government of mismanaging country; holds that report, which was presented at conference in Ethiopia, should have been shown to government in advance (S)

headline: Rival of Chirac's takes helm of French governing party
Culinary haute couture:the designing of 'concept' foods
Get the Wrong Answer, Ask Another Lawyer
abstract: Patrick McGeehan column on efforts by management of TV Azteca to find law firm willing to support its view that company did not need to disclose that Ricardo B Salinas Pliego, its chairman, and a partner bought company debt at deep discount and resold it to company for full price, realizing $109 million profit each on the deal; notes that Munger, Tolles & Olson, Los Angeles law firm working for committee of independent directors of TV Azteca, issued draft report criticizing management for withholding important information from board, failing to correct false public statements by Salinas Pliego and giving explanations for its actions that were not credible; SEC is investigating; photo (M)

headline: Advertisers Learn From Candidates
abstract: Sampling of lessons advertising experts are taking from presidential campaign; photo (M)

headline: Britain to Send 850 Troops Toward Baghdad
abstract: The troops will replace U.S. fighting units that are expected to mount an assault on Iraqi insurgents west of the capital near Falluja.

headline: Sainsbury profit drops two-thirds
World Briefing | Asia: Thailand: Extinction Threatens 15,000 Species
abstract: International Union for Conservation of Nature releases report finding that more than 15,000 species, including one third of all amphibians, are at risk of extinction over next few decades; cites habitat destruction as primary cause; photo (S)

headline: Steam Engines, Search Engines
abstract: Sir Harold Evans wrote a 500-page book chronicling 180 of his favorite American innovators.

headline: World Briefing | Africa: Zimbabwe: Cash Crunch Shuts Youth Camps
abstract: Ziana, Zimbabwe's state-run news agency, reports that three-year-old youth camp program will close because of shortage of funds (S)

headline: Verizon Wireless Makes an Appeal to Rival's Subscribers
abstract: Purchase of AT&T Wireless by Cingular Wireless is just a few weeks old and already company is under attack from its biggest rival, Verizon Wireless, which is trying to recapture top spot in cellphone industry; Verizon Wireless starts advertising campaign that takes aim at customers of AT&T Wireless; photo (M)

headline: Goldman Sachs Says Earnings Rose 23% for Quarter
abstract: Goldman Sachs reports 23 percent increase in earnings for fourth quarter; earned $4.6 billion on $20.6 billion in net revenue, compared with earnings of $3 billion on $16 billion in revenues in fiscal 2003; earnings rose 52 percent for fiscal year ended Nov 26; chairman-chief executive Henry M Paulson comments; photo (M)

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: Unknown Company Wins Bidding for Yukos Unit  Russia completed the dismantling of Yukos, selling off the country's largest oil subsidiary to a company that was essentially unheard of until three days ago. The announcement was a surprise because Gazprom, the country's natural gas monopoly, had appeared to have positioned itself to take over the unit.    The mystery surrounding the winner -- a company called Baikal Finans Group -- immediately raised suspicions in the minds of industry analysts that the winning bidder was acting on behalf of Gazprom, or even the state itself. [Section A.]    Online Shoppers Get a Late Break  In years past, procrastinating holiday shoppers who ordered from online retailers would have faced steep shipping charges for last-minute purchases. But some companies are offering to ship goods via standard ground delivery as late as tomorrow while still guaranteeing pre-Christmas delivery. Bob Tedeschi: E-Commerce Report. [C4.]    U.S. Withdraws Tax Shelter Suit  The Justice Department has withdrawn its lawsuit against a San Diego financial services firm that it said sold questionable tax shelters to thousands of doctors and dentists. The firm, Xelan, is still the subject of a criminal federal grand jury investigation, and the Internal Revenue Service is seeking reimbursement of hundreds of millions of dollars that it says is owed by users of Xelan financial plans. [C6.]    Flaw Found in Google Search Tool  A Rice University computer scientist and two of his students have discovered a potentially serious security flaw in Google's recently distributed desktop search tool for personal computers. The flaw, which could permit an attacker to secretly search the contents of a personal computer via the Internet, emerges when separate components interact. [C3.]    Tenant Delays Big Hong Kong Deal  A lawsuit by a public housing tenant forced the Hong Kong government and three of the world's largest financial institutions to postpone a $2.73 billion real estate offering. [C6.]    Don't Call It a 'Diet' Drink  Soft-drink makers are racing to replace or play down the word ''diet'' in brand names in favor of alternative terms they hope will help fatten sales. Stuart Elliott: Advertising. [C9.]    Mobile Carriers Limit Content  With new functions to send e-mail messages, take pictures and listen to music, the mobile phone has turned into a portable minicomputer. But the operators of phone networks are resisting new services that proved very popular on the old personal computer: pornography and violent video games, like one based on the movie ''Kill Bill.'' [C8.]    Kia Spectra Receives Lowest Rating  The Kia Spectra, a compact car from the Korean automaker Hyundai, was the first vehicle in three years to receive the lowest rating on a frontal crash test from the Insurance Institute for Highway Safety. [C2.]

headline: North Korea threatens Japan nuclear-talks role : Seoul favors 'dialogue' (folo)
A Hard-to-Swallow Lesson on Pensions
abstract: Halliburton is using loophole in law to reduce pension payouts at Dresser-Rand unit in Olean, NY; Halliburton says it has honored its commitment to Dresser-Rand employees under pension plan, followed letter and spirit of laws applicable to plans, and made no profit related to plan; says former partner in joint venture Ingersoll-Rand let workers down; Ingersoll-Rand spokesman dispute that assertion; photo (M)

headline: Stores Are Hoping to Do Well by Urging Shoppers to Do Good
abstract: National retail chains are for first time involving their customers in charities, either ones they have supported through corporate contributions or ones created for holiday season; at ABC Carpet & Home, $135 buys buffalo delivered to village in Cambodia; The Gap is offering $20 teddy bears, with money going toward purchase of coats for poor children; Nike, Build-A-Bear Workshop and Discovery Channel stores sell $1 Lance Armstrong Live Strong bracelets to finance cancer research; retail consultant says such retail-hosted charitable events and promotions have at least tripled since 2000, and have clearly accelerated in past year; retail analysts attribute this to social and economic conditions that may have made some consumers feel guilty about indulging themselves; retailing consultant Paco Underhill says merchants faced with competition from Wal-Mart or even thrift shops are seeking ways to be more creative; photo (M)

headline: World Business Briefing | Europe: Britain: Libel Claim Restricted
abstract: World Business Briefin

headline: Judge Rejects Bid for Testimony From Top Officers in Abuse Trial
abstract: A military judge on Friday rejected efforts by two soldiers charged in the Abu Ghraib scandal to obtain testimony from military intelligence officers about whether the soldiers were ordered or encouraged to take part in abuse of detainees.    The judge ordered the soldiers, Specialist Charles Graner and Sgt. Javal Davis, to stand trial in Baghdad early next year. Lawyers for the two men had sought immunity grants for officers, including Col. Thomas Pappas, the head of the military intelligence brigade at the prison, in an effort to show that their clients had been acting under orders.

headline: N.A.A.C.P.'s Chief Supports Nielsen
abstract: NAACP president and chief executive Kweisi Mfume says in letter to Nielsen Media Research that he supports changes Nielsen is making in way it measures television audiences in local markets; letter represents only Mfume's position, and is not official stand by NAACP (S)

abstract: Johnson & Johnso√Ø

The 2 New 'Must Haves' of Auto Safety
abstract: Auto experts say there are two important must-have safety features: side air bags specificially designed to protect person's head, and electronic stability control, which helps drivers regain control of swerving vehicle by automotically applying brake pressure; recent studies have suggested these two features are most effective of wide range of new safety technologies available on cars and trucks; photos (M)

headline: Air traffic revives, but airports are squeezed by security costs
Technology Briefing | Hardware: Rambus Shares Soar After Patent Ruling
abstract: Shares of Rambus, designer of high-speed memory chips, rise as much 21 percent after Federal Judge Ronald Whyte issues ruling defining terms in patent dispute with Hynix Semiconductor; graph (S)

headline: Is new kind of best seller handicapping German literature?
The Collections / Milan : African rhythms and tribal patterns
US Air Asks Court to End Labor Contracts
abstract: US Airways asks bankruptcy court to throw out contracts covering passenger service agents, flight attendants, mechanics and other workers in favor of less expensive arrangements; also seeks to replace remaining traditional pension plans with cheaper benefits like 401(k) plans, all with goal of saving $1.3 billion a year (M)

headline: Experts Say A.I.G. Case Is Tip of the Iceberg
abstract: Industry specialists say preliminary settlement between American International Group and regulators will not be last word on use of finite risk insurance; add details about other questionable transactions may soon emerge (M)

headline: Cambodia's New King Dances Into a Land of the Absurd
abstract: As he prepared for his coronation at the end of the month, Cambodia's new king, Norodom Sihamoni, stepped gingerly into the roiling politics of his country with an apology (''I lack experience'') and a promise (''I will not interfere'').    The smoothness of his election to the largely ceremonial post last week by a nine-member Throne Council was deceptive. An ambiguous, possibly unconstitutional arrangement, it was the result of a nimble maneuver by his father, Norodom Sihanouk, who suddenly announced his abdication two weeks ago.

headline: A Finishing School for All, Disney Style
abstract: Walt Disney Co hopes to bring bit of Disneyland to its new flagship Manhattan World of Disney store, even as it looks to sell off bulk of its money-losing retail outlets elsewhere; seeks to draw on success of other retail experiments that feature in-store activities and entertainment based on products; offers rooms dedicated to interactive games and jewelry-making, kiosks to book Disney vacations and live theater like program on becoming princess; photo (M)

headline: S.E.C. Names 8 in Kmart Accounting Case
abstract: Securities and Exchange Commission files accounting fraud charges against three former Kmart executives and five representatives of companies that supplied company with brand-name products; contends Kmart executives prematurely booked promotional allowances from suppliers like Coca-Cola Enterprises, PepsiCo and Eastman Kodak, allowing it to increase profits for fourth-quarter 2001 by $24 million; five of eight people named in complaint have reached separate settlements with SEC, each accepting civil penalties of up to $55,000 without admitting or denying wrongdoing; others said they should not be named in complaint (M)

headline: In France, Gay TV Channel Is a 'Small Step in Heels'
abstract: Along the boulevards, images of two cuddling men in the tall grass can still bring some pedestrians to a halt below a slogan promoting Libert√©, √âgalit√© and T√©l√©.    But the advertisements for Pink TV, France's new gay television channel, delivered its most provocative message with a 1984 black-and-white photograph of two familiar politicians, Fran√ßois Mitterrand and Helmut Kohl, in suits and sober expressions, hands linked. With it was a caption: ''There's more to life than sex.''

headline: Miramax Sues Ex-Chief in Italy, Saying He Had 2 Jobs
abstract: Miramax Films division of Walt Disney Co sues Fabrizio Lombardo, former head of its Miramax Italy office, claiming that while in Miramax's employ he simultaneously held another full-time job as member of board of directors of Luxembourg company that forms part of Ricucci Group, real estate concern; photos of Lombardo and Harvey Weinstein, Miramax chairman and a longtime friend of Lombardo's (M)

headline: World Briefing | Europe: Turkey: Kurds Held In Concert Bombing
abstract: Mersin, Turkey, police arrest three Kurdish men who allegedly are involved with separatist Kurdistan Workers Party and are suspected of planting bomb that exploded at Sept 19 pop music concert and injured 13 people (S)

headline: Theatrical Drill in Pacific Meant to Send Signal to North Korea
abstract: Part training exercise, part political theater, this international naval interdiction drill, code-named Team Samurai, had a clear audience: North Korea.

headline: Mine Blast in China Leaves Over 160 Missing
abstract: A gas explosion may be the country's worst coal-mine accident in recent years.

headline: World Briefing | Europe: France: Plutonium Shipment Arrives
abstract: Three-hundred-pound cargo from United States of weapons-grade plutonium arrives at night in Cherbourg (France); plutonium is destined for Cadarache to be turned into fuel for nuclear reactors; protesters are under court order to stay 100 yards away from shipment (S)

headline: Amid Battle With Oracle, PeopleSoft Fires Its Chief
abstract: In a surprise move, PeopleSoft today fired its president and chief executive officer, Craig Conway, citing a "loss of confidence."

headline: Business users worry that open-source could mean open season for lawyers
For Brazil's Economy, the Doctor Is In
abstract: Antonio Palocci, doctor from heartland of Brazil's farm belt and former Trotskyite, finds himself presiding over Brazil's most robust economic expansion in decade; thanks to boom in exports, country is on track to post trade surplus this year of almost $33 billion, largest on record; economy expanded 6.1 percent in third quarter from year ago; photo (M)

headline: Taiwan May Have Experimented With Atomic Bomb Ingredient
abstract: Associated Press says International Atomic Energy Agency found evidence that plutonium separation experiments were carried out in Taiwan during island's brief revival of nuclear weapons program in 1980's under Pres Chiang Ching-kuo; nuclear experts have long suspected that Taiwan carried out such experiments; questions about its past nuclear ambitions resurfaced in Aug after leading newspaper there suggested that nuclear weapons would be effective deterrent for threat posed by mainland China; Prime Min Yu Shyi-kun denies that any such program exists (M)

headline: THE END USER / A voice for the consumer : Icann seeks an identity
DEERE'S INCOME ROSE FIVEFOLD IN THE FOURTH QUARTER
abstract: Deere & Co says fourth-quarter profit surged fivefold; net income for quarter ended Oct 31 increased to $356.7 million from $70.6 million year earlier; farm-machine sales rose 35 percent, to $2.7 billion (S)

headline: In Paris, dignity and a meal for hungry
ADELPHIA WINS COURT APPROVAL FOR AUCTION PLAN
abstract: Adelphia Communications, bankrupt cable television operator, wins court approval for asset auction to raise money for creditors; plans to sell its assets in seven regional cable groups averaging about 750,000 subscribers each (S)

headline: The Dollar Is Defying Both Expectations and Gravity
abstract: Portfolios column on dollar continuing to confound investors, nibbling into returns from abroad; graph; discusses dollar's surprising strength, given record trade deficit (M)

headline: Rebels Inflict Heavy Losses on the Iraqis
abstract: Insurgents continue their relentless assault on Iraq's fledgling security forces, killing at least 23 police and national guard officers in multiple attacks mainly across Sunni-dominated zone north of Baghdad; photo (M)

headline: Delta to Pursue Note Swap to Try to Avoid Bankruptcy
abstract: Delta Air Lines fails to persuade enough intermediate and long-term bondholders to exchange debt and will proceed with short-term bond exchange to help avoid filing for bankruptcy protection (M)

headline: News Corporation's Profit Rises on Strong Cable Ad Sales
abstract: News Corp reports net income of $536 million for fiscal first-quarter ended Sept 30, up 27 percent from year-earlier period; sales rose 12 percent to $5.19 billion (S)

headline: Technology Briefing | E-Commerce: India's Wireless Game Market Expands
abstract: India's booming wireless game market is expected to continue to expand, generating annual revenue of $336 million by 2009 (S)

headline: Two Days Later, Investors Still Like What They See
abstract: Dow Jones industrial average closes up 177 points at 10,314.76; Nasdaq composite index rises 19.30 points to 2,023.63; Standard & Poor's 500-stock index closes up 18.47 points at 1,161.67; 10-year US Treasury note is unchanged at 101 13/32; yield is 4.08 percent; graph; chart (M)

headline: World Briefing | Europe: Spain: Blasts Rock Five Madrid Gas Stations After ETA Warning
abstract: Five small bombs explode in gas stations outside Madrid after warning from ETA, Basque separatist group; Spanish Interior Min officials report that some police officers did sustain minor injuries, but no one else was hurt (S)

headline: World Briefing | Europe: New European Commissioners
abstract: European Union Parliament approves new executive branch to be led by incoming commissioner Jose Manuel Durao Barroso of Portugal (S)

headline: Mars Alters Its Lineup And Eliminates Grey
abstract: Mars is consolidating most of its worldwide assignments for creative advertising at two agencies, eliminating from roster Grey Worldwide; Grey will continue to handle other assignments for candy brands (S)

headline: Closure Medical Reduces '04 Forecasts
abstract: Closure Medical Corp, maker of Band-Aid Liquid Bandages and Dermabond surgical adhesive, reduces its 2004 forecasts for revenue and profit, causing decline in its stock price (S)

headline: Treasury Bills Set for This Week
abstract: The Treasury's schedule of financing this week includes today's regular weekly auction of new three- and six-month bills and an auction of four-week bills tomorrow.    At the close of the New York cash market on Friday, the rate on the outstanding three-month bill was 2.02 percent. The rate on the six-month issue was 2.25 percent, and the rate on the four-week issue was 1.83 percent.

headline: COMPANY BRIEFS
abstract: HARLEY-DAVIDSON INC., Milwaukee, the motorcycle maker, said its chief executive, Jeffrey L. Bleustein, would retire in April. James L. Ziemer, who is vice president and chief financial officer, will succeed him effective April 30, 2005.    KNBT BANCORP INC., Bethlehem, Pa., said it would buy Northeast Pennsylvania Financial Corp., Hazelton, Pa., the parent of First Federal Bank, for about $98 million.    ASSOCIATED BRITISH FOODS, the British owner of Mazola cooking oil, said it planned to start a British joint venture that would combine its Allied Grain business with Banks Cargill Agriculture, a unit of Cargill Inc., Wayzata, Minn., the food and grain producer.

headline: Police Investigate 2 Canadian Muslims Over Comments About Jews
abstract: Two prominent Canadian Muslims who made derogatory remarks about Jews have been condemned by moderate Muslims and other Canadians, and the police have opened investigations to determine whether the men have broken any laws.    A statement on a Web site by a Muslim cleric from Vancouver calling Jews ''the brothers of monkeys and swine'' was perceived as particularly disturbing, especially after Russia reported that one of his followers had left Canada to join rebel forces in Chechnya and had been killed in combat.

headline: Colombia Proposes 10-Year Terms for Paramilitary Atrocities
abstract: Panel of legislators reportedly will propose to Colombian Pres Alvaro Uribe's government bill to provide prison sentences of up to 10 years for any right-wing paramilitary fighters found guilty of atrocities and to require them to return any ill-gotten gains; proposed penalties would be part of government's conditions for peace accord with United Self-Defense Forces; paramilitaries, although illegal, consider selves allied with state against rebels; have been pressing for amnesty and protection from extradition in exchange for complete demobilization of their 15,000 fighters by end of 2005 (M)

headline: Questions on the $3.8 Billion Drug Ad Business
abstract: Issue of drug advertising directly aimed at consumers was thrust into news recently when Merck withdrew its arthritis painkiller Vioxx from market, citing studies indicating risk of heart attacks or strokes; critics noted role that advertising and marketing played in drug's being widely prescribed to patients who might have done as well with ibuprofen or other inexpensive over-the-counter remedies; prescription drug advertising has grown into $3.8-billion-a-year business in seven years since FDA lifted strictures against such ads; FDA has no plans to place new curbs on such ads despite controversy accompanying withdrawal of Vioxx; vice presidential candidate Sen John Edwards during debate last week said drug ads on TV are out of control and that he and Sen John Kerry would do something about ads if elected; Megan Houk, deputy policy director for Bush-Cheney campaign, accuse Democratic candidates of exaggerating issue; charts; photos (M)

headline: A Top-End Digital S.L.R. Offers a Crisper View
abstract: Canon's new single-lens-reflex camera has highest resolution of any 35-millimeter-style digital reflex, 16.7 megapixels; photo (S)

headline: Sun Reports Smaller Loss and Calls It a Turnaround
abstract: Sun Microsystems reduced its net loss in first quarter to $174 million from $286 million loss year earlier; revenue rose 3.6 percent to $2.63 billion, compared with $2.54 billion year ago; chief executive Scott McNealy says results are indication that turnaround is in progress, though not yet completed (M)

headline: PeopleSoft Rejects Latest Oracle Bid as Inadequate
abstract: PeopleSoft rejects Orac

headline: Regulators Adopt Tighter Rules on Accounting for Stock Options
abstract: Financial Accounting Standards Board adopts rules requiring publicly traded companies to treat stock options they give to employees as normal business expenses; rule change is scheduled to take effect July 1, 2005, though coalition led by technology companies, which often used stock-based compensation plans, has vowed to continue fighting it (M)

headline: Banks Are Staying Clear of a Proposed Soccer Club Takeover
abstract: Malcolm Glazer, owner of Tampa Bay Buccaneers of National Football League, is having difficulty enlisting bank to help him take over Manchester United, English soccer team, in face of fierce opposition from fans and management (S)

headline: P.L.O. Aides Put Off Trip to Arafat Doctors
abstract: Confusing and sometimes conflicting accounts of health of Palestine Liberation Organization leader Yassir Arafat, who is being treated in French hospital, motivate Palestinian leaders to plan trip to visit him; Suha, Arafat's wife who has been living in France and not seen husband in past three years, reproaches those who she believes want to prematurely take over PLO leadership and refuses to share medical information; trip by Mahmoud Abbas and Palestinian Prime Min Ahmed Qurei to see Arafat is cancelled as result; concern over future Palestinian leadership discussed (L)

headline: COURT CUTS AWARD CANTOR FITZGERALD MUST PAY BROKER
abstract: London appeals court cuts 117,000 pounds from amount Cantor Fitzgerald is being forced to pay to broker Steven Horkulak who says his boss Lee Amaitis bullied him; says original award of 912,000 pounds ($1.64 million) was 'perversely high'; Horkulak sued Amaitis contending that Amaitis's regular use of foul language and dictatorial manner drove him from his job (S)

headline: France must work harder or stagnate, report warns
A Black Rocket Founder Is Leaving Agency
abstract: A Black Rocket Founder.

headline: From the bathtub to the table:Holiday carp
Medical Tests for Arafat in Early Stage
abstract: As Yasir Arafat underwent medical tests in France, a Palestinian diplomat said Saturday that the initial findings indicated he did not have leukemia. Early on Sunday, senior aides to Mr. Arafat said tests had ruled out any life-threatening condition, Reuters reported.     ''The latest tests have found that President Arafat does not suffer from any life-threatening illness and what he has is curable,'' Nabil Abu Rdainah, a senior aide, was quoted as saying.

headline: Politicus : Schr√∂der is rethinking German role vs. U.S.
When Wireless Networks Merge
abstract: Cingular Wireless will spend hundreds of millions of dollars in coming weeks on its ad campaign on its acquisition of AT&T Wireless; company's goal is to reassure its own 25.7 million customers, to welcome 21.9 million customers of AT&T Wireless and to woo tens of millions of customers of competitors; capaign is by Atlanta and New York offices of DDDO Worldwide; photo (M)

headline: Chinese firm plans car plant in Malaysia
Can't Remember the Movie? Look for an Oscar-Season Ad
abstract: Movie studios are already placing ads positioning their films for consideration for Academy Awards even though awards are four months away; ads are expected to herald notably wide-open and expensive Oscar campaign season, even though awards ceremony has been moved up to late Feb; there is no front-runner for big awards, emboldening studios to push harder for their movies; some competitors seek to exploit perceived opening resulting from Miramax cost-cutting; photos (M)

headline: Wal-Mart Sets Records, and Its Shares Drop
abstract: Wal-Mart reports record 10 percent rise in fiscal third-quarter earnings, to $2.29 billion and 9.7 percent hike in quarterly sales, to $68.52 billion; stock price drops on news, closing at $56.89 (M)

headline: World Business Briefing | Americas: Brazil: Steel Mill Planned
abstract: World Business B

headline: Names of the Dead
abstract: The Department of Defense has identified 1,297 American service members who have died since the start of the Iraq war. It confirmed the death of the following American yesterday:    SWEGER, Franklin A., 24; Lance Cpl., Marines; San Antonio; Third Marine Division, Third Marine Expeditionary Force.

headline: Amgen Says Trial Shows Drug Improved Bone Density
abstract: Amgen says its experimental drug for osteoporosis, AMG 162, increased bone density in women at least as well in clinical trial as Merck's Fosamax; has begun final-stage trial to test whether drug prevents fractures (M)

headline: Rebel Violence in Turkey Could Erode Kurds' Gains
abstract: Armed members of outlawed group Kurdistan Workers Party, operating in southeastern Turkey, are stirring up violence in region with spate of kidnappings and weekly skirmishes with army; Turkish leaders hold reason for guerrilla activity is unclear because recent reforms that have improved lives of Kurds, are taking hold throughout country, but some officials contend individuals are profiting politically and economically from violence; Abdullah Ocalan, PKK leader who has been in Turkish prison since 1999 but still holds more than symbolic control of group, is allegedly supportive of surge in violence; locals are concerned activity will develop into all out insurgency reminiscent of 15-year-long conflict that destroyed villages and killed thousands in region; others are concerned Kurds will lose rights gained in recent reforms; map (M)

headline: COMPANY BRIEFS
abstract: ARBITRON, New York, which compiles television and radio ratings for broadcasters, said it had won a four-year contract to provide software and other services to the radio unit of Clear Channel Communications, San Antonio, the media company.    NEW VALLEY CORP., Miami, a real estate company, said it had agreed to sell two office buildings in Princeton, N.J., to an undisclosed buyer for about $71.5 million.    SALLIE MAE, Reston, Va., the student loan provider, said its unsolicited $1 billion takeover bid for the Pennsylvania Higher Education Assistance Agency had been rejected.    L-3 COMMUNICATIONS HOLDINGS, New York, a maker of military electronics, said that Robert LaPenta, a co-founder of the company, would retire as president and chief financial officer on April 1. L-3 said Frank Lanza, the chief executive, would temporarily assume the duties of president while Michael Strianese, senior vice president of finance, would become chief financial officer.

headline: Expulsions in France test truce over scarves
COMPANY BRIEFS
abstract: BROADCOM CORP., Irvine, Calif., a maker of computer chips for television set-top boxes and personal computers, has been granted motions by a federal judge dismissing claims related to news releases announcing its purchases of VisionTech Ltd. and Silicon Spice.    BLUELINX HOLDINGS INC., Atlanta, a distributor for building products. Underwriters for the company set the terms of the company's pending initial public offering at 9.5 million common shares, with an estimated price of $15 to $17 a share, according to an amended filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission.    MEDIACOM COMMUNICATIONS CORP., Middletown, N.Y., the cable operator, said its chief executive, Rocco B. Commisso, sold about 1.4 million shares, about 5 percent of his holdings in the company.

headline: World Briefing | Europe: Russia: Union Says A Million Strike
abstract: Russian trade unions said that more than a million public sector workers across the country, including teachers, doctors and scientists, were taking part in a strike demanding a 50 percent pay increase and that several million more might join. They are protesting salaries that are far below the national average of $180 a month and often less than the poverty level of just over $70 a month. Deputy Prime Minister Aleksandr Zhukov promised that salaries would be raised next year.   Sophia Kishkovsky (NYT)

headline: China's Elite Learn to Flaunt It While the New Landless Weep
abstract: Real estate developer Zhang Yuchen copied 17th-century French chateau in suburban Beijing, hoping to attract China's new rich to rent its rooms and buy homes amid equestrian trails and golf course; 800 peasants who once grew wheat there have lost their land under new rules that allow elite to acquire trappings of America in age of robber barons; photos (M)

headline: Storm flags go up on Continent over euro
It's Hard to Be Neutral Nowadays
abstract: Advice on stock funds with strategies described as 'market neutral' or 'long-short,' meaning they divide holdings equally between long and short positions with goal of positive return every year; graphs (M)

headline: American and Norwegian Share Economics Nobel
abstract: Finn E. Kydland and Edward C. Prescott won the 2004 Nobel prize in economics today for their work in determining the driving force behind business cycles worldwide.

headline: Economic Calendar
abstract: These are the expected dates for the release of major economic indicators this week.

headline: Bank will pay dairy firm ‚Ç¨ 160 million : Intesa settles dispute over Parmalat bonds
GE Capital vs. the Small-Town Folk Hero
abstract: Aaron M Feuerstein, Polartec inventor who became corporate folk hero for treatment of workers after disastrous 1995 fire, is rebuffed in effort to buy back Malden Mills from current board and GE Capital, which became largest shareholder after he was forced into bankruptcy; Feuerstein, now 78, would keep 1,000 jobs in Merrimac Valley of Mass and provide low-cost local housing; photo; he has two years left on option to buy back company his grandfather founded in 1906, and Malden has not performed well under turnaround team, deepening mystery of offer's rejection (M)

headline: Donkeys bray their way back into vogue
Technology Briefing | Hardware: Broadcom Names Chief Executive
abstract: Technology Br

headline: Getting Off a Security Watch List Is the Hard Part
abstract: Airline passengers on Transportation Security Administration's watch list find it difficult to get off list; list comprises at least nine government databases estimated to include over 40,000 names, divided into smaller no-fly list of suspected terrorists or national security threats and much larger list of people requiring more rigorous screening; passengers can get on second database for activities like paying with cash, booking seat at last minute, flying one way or even having no luggage; photo (M)

headline: A Disappointing Fall for Some Big Names in Clothing
abstract: Major apparel makers that began offering moderately priced clothing last spring, including Calvin Klein, Tommy Hilfiger and Liz Claiborne, are experiencing disappointing sales; Ralph Lauren clothes by Polo Ralph Lauren seem to have emerged as overall winner for summer and fall, although president Roger Farah concedes that there has been autumn slowdown; photo (M)

headline: BFI CANADA WILL PURCHASE IESI, TRASH HAULER IN TEXAS
abstract: Trash hauler BFI Canada will acquire Fort Worth, Tex-based IESI Corp, another trash hauler, for 1.1 billion Canadian dollars ($927 million) in equity and debt (S)

headline: Experts Say Accurate Toll Is Hard to Calculate
abstract: Experts say that rapidly climbing death estimates from earthquake-generated waves that struck dozen countries around Indian Ocean are likely to be highly inaccurate for some time; estimates of dead climb to 57,000, which would make tsunami toll worst in recorded history; table shows death estimates from previous catastrophic events, and actual final count (M)

headline: The Profits and Pains of Outsourcing
abstract: Six American business executives discuss their experiences sending work overseas.

headline: Diverging Fortunes, Tied to the Dollar
abstract: Article compares impact that falling dollar and rising euro is having on American and European manufacturing companies; focuses on Markel Corp, family-owned business near Philadelphia, Pa, and Alfred H Schutte Co of Cologne, Ger; while Markel is scrambling to fill orders from Germany, Portugal and Czech Republic and pricing its products, insulated wire and tubing for cars, more competitively, Schutte, another family-owned company, is losing orders for its million-dollar auto-related machines; photos; graph (M)

headline: At Last, a Microsoft Search Tool
abstract: Microsoft is planning to introduce its long-awaited Internet search engine on Thursday, a person knowledgeable about the announcement said.    Word of the introduction of the service, which will compete with Google and Yahoo, was leaked on Tuesday after the company began phoning reporters offering briefings for Wednesday. A company spokeswoman declined comment on the announcement.

headline: Thou Shalt Not Increase G.D.P.
abstract: Daniel Gross article on increasing efforts by scholars to use conventional economic methods to understand way in which religion relates to rest of society, particularly economy; cites finding that countries economies may perform best when people have relatively higher levels of religious belief than religious participation; drawing (M)

headline: Powell Arrives in Israel in Latest Push for Peace
abstract: The visit is focused on an American financial aid package that would facilitate Palestinian elections and improve their security forces.

headline: Madison Avenue Ponders the Potential of Web Logs
abstract: Advertising agencies and communications professionals are using Web blogs to create discussion about ideas within their industries; for many agencies, particularly large networks, potential risks still outweigh benefits; some ad agency executives comment (M)

headline: Dublin won't sell Aer Lingus to managers
What's a Flier to Do, Check the Children as Baggage?
abstract: Joe Sharkey On the Road column on frequent fliers who believe infants and children should not be allowed to fly commercial airliners because they are annoying; drawing (M)

headline: F.D.A. ALLOWS EXTENDED USE OF JOHNSON & JOHNSON MEDICINE
abstract: Johnson & Johnson wins expanded FDA approval to market Remicade, which it began selling in 1998, for patients with rheumatoid arthritis (S)
